PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Button (from 151 citizens) and Tate (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed national ID Card and numbering system threatens the privacy of law-abiding Australians opening the door to computer matching of personal information, will cause inconvenience to rural people in particular, and will result in massive compliance costs for private business.

That the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee Report of 1986 showed that the Australia Card will not be effective in combating taxation and social security fraud and illegal immigration, as its cost savings are based on faulty estimates.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject the Australia Card Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Government has no clear mandate to introduce the Australia Card.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled insist that the Government not proceed with the Australia Card without the consent of a majority of the Australian people in a majority of the States as determined in a national referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Injection Pumps and Turbocharger Spare Parts: Duty Increase
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned are totally opposed to the impending duty increase from 2% to 25% on Diesel Fuel Injection Pump and Turbocharger Spare Parts . . .
And we call on the Senate to reject the legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting Act 1942, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for a major new package of commercial radio ownership rules and will provide an efficient and equitable framework for the future development of radio services in Australia. The opportunity has also been taken in the Bill to accomplish some substantial rearrangement and consolidation of existing ownership and control provisions in broadcasting legislation, in a way that should be welcomed by all those who have to deal with the labyrinthine complexities of that legislation.
The new radio rules, which implement the policy announced on 28 October 1987, will substantially complete the Government's unprecedented reform of the ownership structure of the Australian media.

The Bill presents the results of the review of ownership limits for commercial radio. It also completes the review of cross-media ownership by addressing this issue in the context of revised radio rules. The new cross-media limits will effectively mean that media proprietors will have to choose between a major role in television or radio or newspapers.
The existing radio limits in the Broadcasting Act 1942 are:
one metropolitan radio licence in any State;
a total of four metropolitan radio licences;
a total of four radio licences in any State;
a total of 8 licences.

The factor that triggers the application of these limits is the holding of a prescribed interest in a commercial radio licence or the holding of a directorship in a company in a position to control a commercial radio licence. Broadly speaking, the threshold for attribution of a radio prescribed interest is the holding of more than a 15 per cent direct or indirect shareholding in a licensee company. This Bill does not propose changes either to this threshold level for radio prescribed interests or to the methods of tracing indirect interests. A change in the current 5 per cent prescribed interest level for commercial television licences is proposed, for the purpose of the revised television/radio cross-media limit. I will explain this change in addressing the provisions of the Bill in more detail.
Since the inception of the radio limits in 1935, the number of commercial radio licences has more than doubled, and more new services are in the pipeline.

In February this year the Government announced plans for 27 additional commercial FM radio stations in regional areas over a 3-year period, and in October I added 8 stations to this list. By 1990, commercial FM radio services will have been planned and licences invited to service more than 4.2 million people living outside the mainland State capitals.

This expansion of commercial radio services represents a radical change in the commercial radio environment in non-metropolitan areas which is not catered for by the existing radio ownership and control limits.

The Government believes that the public interest will best be served if commercial radio services are competitive. A competitive industry will strive to present the best in commercial radio programming in order to attract audiences and, consequently, advertising revenue. Competition within radio markets will also promote diversity of programming in terms of news, information, opinion and entertainment.
In summary, the new package of ownership rules introduced by this Bill will consist of:
A national limit of 16 commercial radio licences;
A State radio licence limit of no more than half of the service areas in that State;
A limit of one radio licence to a service area; and
New and revised cross-media ownership limits.
National Limit

The new national limit for commercial radio licences is to be 16. The total number of these licences presently available has more than doubled (from 65 to 139) since the eight-station limit was introduced in 1935. To maintain the ratio of permitted licences to the total available today would require a new limit of seventeen. If one takes into account the 37 new licences in the pipeline, the number would need to be 21 to maintain that ratio. When the new services are in place the new limit will represent just over 9 per cent of licences as compared with 6 per cent under the current eight station rule. In this context, the new 16 licence limit is both realistic and conservative.
State Limit
The present State limit of four licences impacts unevenly upon the States because it takes no account of the differing numbers of licences among them.
The new limit in the Bill will prohibit a person from holding prescribed interests in more licences within a State than half the number of service areas in that State.

For this purpose, service areas that are substantially coextensive with each other will be counted only once. If the revised State limit were to come into operation today, the maximum number of licences in the States would be:
NSW (including ACT)
Victoria
Queensland
South Australia
Western Australia
Tasmania
Northern Territory

The principle underlying the State limit is that no-one should be able to exercise too great an influence within a State. The combined effect of this limit and others included in the Bill will achieve this result.
Local Limit
The Government believes that diversity and quality of programming is best ensured by the provision of competitive services at the local level.

Under the current rules, there is a prohibition against holding two or more radio licences serving any State capital city. Only a few cities outside the State capitals have more than one commercial radio service and these are not commonly owned. However, with the planned expansion of commercial services in non-metropolitan areas, it is necessary to give the metropolitan area prohibition general force. The general application of the one-licence-to-a-market limit is consistent with the one-licence-to-a-market rule for commercial television.

The intent of the new rule is that, where licences are in direct competition, they should not be commonly owned. There are many services that are not in direct competition but whose service areas, for historical or other reasons, overlap. The ``one-radio-licence-in-a-service-area'' rule therefore has a built-in margin of tolerance of 30 per cent. That is, if two service areas overlap to the extent that more than 30 per cent of the population of one is also within the service area of the other, then the licences serving those areas will not be able to have common ownership links.
There will, of course, remain the case of supplementary licences. These will normally be granted only where the service area concerned is judged to be unable to support a competitive service.
Cross-Media Limits

Earlier this year, the Government introduced cross-media limits in connection with changes to the television ownership and control rules. Those limits restricted, for the first time, holdings across media-in that case, television/radio and television/newspapers. Since then there has been a considerable realignment of interests within the industry with a significant uncoupling of cross-media linkages.
The present Bill extends the cross-ownership restrictions to radio/newspaper holdings and amends the application of the existing television/radio restrictions.

In the case of radio/television, the current restriction is that prescribed interests may not be held in both a television licence and a radio licence if, anywhere within the television service area, there is a monopoly for the commercial radio service. The new rule will prohibit the holding of prescribed interests by one person in both a television licence and a radio licence if more than 30 per cent of the population within the service area of one of those licences is also within the other's service area. For this purpose a prescribed interest in a television licence will be attributed to interests of more that 15 per cent.

This television/radio limit will mean that there is uniform application of the prescribed interest levels to radio and television for the cross-media rule. The rule will apply universally across Australia-not just in monopoly radio markets.

For radio/newspapers, cross-media holdings will be limited in an equivalent manner to television/newspapers. That is, a person will not be permitted to hold prescribed interests in both a radio licence and a newspaper if that newspaper:
has fifty per cent or more of its circulation within the radio service area;
is published, in English, on four or more days per week; and
is sold, as a newspaper, to the extent of fifty per cent or more of its circulation.
The threshold for a prescribed interest will be fifteen per cent for both radio and newspapers, as already defined in the Act.
The effect of these rules will be that media proprietors will essentially have to choose between a major role in television, or radio, or newspapers.
Directorship

The existing radio directorship limits in the Act have also been changed to make them consistent with the revised radio prescribed interest limits. The existing television/radio cross-media directorship limit has also been amended to reflect the changes made to the corresponding cross-media prescribed interest limit. The new radio/newspaper cross-media prescribed interest limit is also supported by a corresponding directorship limit. The changes made to the cross-media directorship limits include an exemption to cover the circumstances where a person holds more than one directorship within a corporate group which has grandfathered cross-media interests.
Administration and Enforcement

For the purpose of the new radio rules, the Minister will be required to determine the percentage service area population overlaps between radio licences (to give effect to the one-radio-licence-to-a-service-area limit) and to determine the number of discrete service areas in each State (to give effect to the revised State limit). The Minister will also be required to determine percentage population service area overlaps between commercial radio and television licences for the purpose of the new television/radio cross-media limit. The determination of service area population overlaps is to be based on Census Count results published by the Australian Statistician. For the purpose of the new radio/newspaper cross-media limit, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be required to determine those newspapers having more than 50 per cent of their circulation within the service area of particular commercial radio licences.

The Bill will ensure that these determinations made by the Minister and the Tribunal are available to the public in the form of Ministerial Gazette Notices and the Tribunal's Associated Newspaper Register. The Notices and the Tribunal Register must also be updated to take account of new circumstances such as new Census Count results, changes in service areas, and changes in newspaper circulations. The administration and enforcement system closely follows the scheme which applies at present to the 60 per cent population reach television limit.

Investors in the media will thus be able to ascertain those investments that would contravene the new limits through reference to the Gazette Notices of the Minister and/or the Associated Newspaper Register of the Tribunal. Contraventions of the new limits will be treated in the same way as contraventions under the existing Act.
Grandfathering

In accordance with normal practice, provision is made in the Bill to grandfather (ie protect) those contravening prescribed interests or directorships which were held on or before 28 October 1987 (the date of the announcement of the Government's intention to introduce new radio and cross-media laws). These provisions are drafted along the same lines as the grandfathering provisions contained in the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act 1987, as clarified and refined by the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act (No. 2) 1987.

The only exception to those grandfathering rules which apply to the new television limits introduced by the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Act is that grandfathered protection for a contravention of a revised radio or cross-media limit will not apply where a person continues to hold prescribed interests or directorships that also contravened the corresponding existing limit on or before 28 October 1986. For example, if a person contravened the existing State limits (four commercial radio licences) by holding prescribed interests in five commercialradio licences in South Australia before 28 October 1987, that person would, if the revised statement for South Australia is three licences, be grandfathered for the holding of a prescribed interest in only four of those licences. On the other hand, a person who was grandfathered under the existing television/radio cross-media limits would continue to be grandfathered for contraventions of the new television/radio limit.
Consequential Drafting Changes

The Bill provides for consequential amendments of the licence grant, renewal, and transfer provisions of the Act to take account of the new limits. A cursory glance at the Bill will also reveal that significant structural changes have been made to the arrangement of the ownership and control provisions to accommodate the new limits. The existing and new cross-media provisions will be contained in a separate division of the Act. The existing and new grandfathering rules have been consolidated in a new division to avoid the need to refer to the transitional grandfathering provisions in recent broadcasting amendment Acts.

The parliamentary draftsman has also taken the opportunity to provide a more logical and coherent arrangement of the ownership and control provisions and to streamline the ownership and control rules by deleting duplicate radio and television provisions. I am sure that these changes will be welcomed by those lawyers and representatives of the broadcasting industry that have had to deal with the labyrinthine arrangement of the existing provisions.
Consultation

It is not intended to seek passage of this Bill in these sittings, only to introduce it. This will provide an opportunity for representatives of the broadcasting industry and other interested parties to examine the detailed provisions in the Bill prior to resumption of the second reading debate. Any comments received on the technical operation of the Bill will be taken into account and, if appropriate, Government amendments will be moved on resumption of the debate in the 1988 autumn sittings of Parliament.

In particular, I will be further examining the issue as to whether grandfathered protection should be afforded for contraventions of the new radio and cross-media limits caused by changes in Census Count population figures. I have also asked my Department to consider whether any such grandfathered protection can or should also apply to contraventions in relation to other limits in the Act.
Financial Impact

The new measures will place some additional administrative burden on the Department of Transport and Communications and on the Tribunal. These will be absorbed within current resources, although some reordering of priorities may be required.
Conclusion

This Bill marks the culmination of a process of reform for radio that commenced when my predecessor, early in 1985, asked the then Department of Communications to enquire into future directions for commercial radio.

That process has resulted in two major advances. Firstly, there is the program to provide additional radio services in regional areas, which was announced earlier this year. Secondly, there are the rules provided for in this Bill. These new radio and cross-media rules and the new radio services, together with the television rules and the television equalisation scheme, will usher in a new era of broadcasting that will increase the quality and quantity of broadcasting services available to the public at all levels and in all areas. This new era has not been brought about by new technology or outside or overseas influences. It is a direct consequence of the Government's policy initiatives.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned by the impasse we have reached in Australia in higher education. This impasse is our desperate inability under current government policies to provide the number and quality of higher education places that Australia needs. The same challenge also faces us in technical and further education. Everyone in this chamber acknowledges the fact that, by all international standards, Australia has too few graduates and too few people gaining higher degrees. We all know that if Australia is to take her rightful place as a strong player in the world's economic market-place and avoid sliding down the Argentinean road, our universities and colleges must be given the opportunity for significant expansion and the pursuit of excellence. Yet we know that under the present Government's policies, rather than having significant expansion, higher education enrolments have reached a plateau over the last five years.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been referring to this plateau for several years in Senate debates on education. We all have to face up to the fact that each year more and more Australians are demanding access to our institutes of higher education. The statement of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on 22 September and the Green Paper put down yesterday squarely seek to address this problem of the plateau. But I still believe that the approach put forward is inadequate and will not meet the challenge that is now being so squarely addressed. Each year more and more Australians who are willing and qualified to undertake tertiary studies are being locked out. There are simply not enough places to meet the demand.

The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education have for the past three years published an annual survey which shows the gravity of the situation. Their report for 1987 revealed that between 14,000 and 20,000 eligible applicants were excluded from higher education. This is the net figure after double applications and flow-on applications have been excluded. In any event this is a conservative figure. Tens of thousands more people would benefit from higher education if the doors of our universities and colleges were not so firmly closed against them.

There should be some freedom for citizens to engage in a market-place of education offerings. But this market-place does not exist, because of overregulation and the monopoly of decision making here in Canberra by the Minister and the Department of Employment, Education and Training-and it is getting worse. Under the present Government's policies we are moving from a centrally overregulated system which shuts people out to an even more centrally determined and more regulated system which will shut out even more Australians. I acknowledge that both the Opposition and the Government have recognised that Australia desperately needs to have a highly skilled and educated work force. However, the approaches of the Opposition and the Government now are starkly different.

It is pleasing to see that the new Minister for education has decided to give consideration to the problem-and that is an understatement; he has very squarely addressed it. It is refreshing to see the way the Government has set out objectives to address this plateau problem. There are a number of welcome changes from the status quo approach adopted by the previous Minister, Senator Ryan. I refer, of course, to the present Minister's Budget night paper on skills formation in Australia, his statement on 22 September entitled `The Challenge for Higher Education in Australia', and the Green Paper that was published yesterday.

In contrast, Senator Ryan, with the support of this present Australian Labor Party Government, was content for more than four years to adopt a policy which maintained the status quo in higher education, plodding along with marginal increases in additional places when funds permitted. There was no imagination and no freedom from the monopoly of decisions regulated from Canberra. Because of the complete commitment by that Minister to there being no introduction of tertiary fees, apart from the backdown of the administration charge, and because of the shutting out of private moneys from industry and commerce from the public due to a 15-year hangup in many elements of the Australian Labor Party-because there was a policy constraint-that status quo approach persisted for too long.

The objective of the new Minister appears to be a genuine expansion in higher education places, but there is no credibility yet in the means by which he has chosen to achieve his objective. Squeezing again the already squeezed orange will not yield much juice. Squeezing too much, even in the noble name of efficiency and management, has the consequence of rupturing the orange altogether-but, yes, the Minister's objective is expansion. Mr Dawkins realises that Australia will have to find an extra 75,000 places in higher education by the end of the century. He also realises that the financing of his proposed expansion of higher education will be crucial to the necessary reforms. He has stated that the money to fund the extra 75,000 places eventually will be about $750m each year. Mr Dawkins said in his speech on Friday that, when the technical and further education (TAFE) sector is included, some 125,000 places will have to be found by the year 2000, but he has already indicated that there is unlikely to be any real increase in Commonwealth spending on higher education in the coming years. Page 7 of the 22 September ministerial statement reads:
In current budgetary and economic circumstances, however, it is simply not feasible to achieve quantum leaps in participation in higher education by providing quantum leaps in public expenditure.

I agree with that statement, as does the Opposition. It is on that realistic basis that the Opposition's higher education policy was published and put forward openly and honestly to the electorate at the beginning of this year. Rather than spend any new money, Mr Dawkins has already indicated several ways in which savings will be made in the tertiary sector. It is these savings which he imagines will be used to finance the expansion in enrolments, but that is not credible. According to Mr Dawkins, the new funding bonanza will arise from greater efficiency in the tertiary education sector. These efficiency measures will include amalgamation of small institutions, reorienting research funds, rationalising external studies and improving what he calls staff efficiency and effectiveness. Even with all this so-called efficiency bonanza, he has also said that efficiency improvements alone would not be enough and that it would be important for industry and commerce to make a greater contribution, but these references are vague and the hard policy decisions are evaded.

In addition, Mr Dawkins has begun to hint about the reintroduction of tertiary education fees. It is easy to see that, when the question is asked, `Where is the money coming from, Mr Dawkins?', the logical answer must be that a substantial amount will come from fees. In a speech Mr Dawkins made in Perth last Friday, he said:

A central question therefore is where the resources to allow for expansion are to come from. In my September statement I pointed out that it will not be possible in current circumstances for the Government to provide for this magnitude in this increase in funding.
Mr Dawkins went on to say:
I would hope that Governments will be prepared to continue current funding in real terms.
The Senate must note that the Minister is not guaranteeing even the maintaining of funds in real terms. The expression he uses is that he hopes that will occur. Mr Dawkins went on to say:

It will be important however for industry and commerce to demonstrate a greater preparedness to contribute and I believe there is a crucial issue to be resolved in relation to fair and equitable contributions on the part of individuals and their families.

Mr Dawkins's expression `fair and equitable contributions by individuals and families' logically can mean only one thing-fees. Mr Dawkins has already demonstrated that he is perfectly willing to push ahead with his plans to impose fees in an area additional to that in relation to which Senator Ryan introduced fees. The 22 September statement enabled universities to charge fees in respect of certain post-graduate courses. I am still waiting to learn just how many students will be affected by that measure. I asked a question about that matter during the Estimates committee hearings, but my question was not able to be answered. Incidentally, that measure breaches Labor's long-standing promise not to reintroduce tertiary tuition fees. At present Senator Ryan's administration charge raises about $100m each year. That amount represents about 4 per cent of the total cost of higher education.

It cannot yet be estimated whether Mr Dawkins's second measure-the introduction of fees in respect of some post-graduate courses-will raise more or less than this 4 per cent amount. Of course, Mr Dawkins has been more than happy to stick with the controversial $250 higher education administration charge, which is now the $263 fee following a consumer price index related increase in this year's Budget. The Government has taken the first two steps down the path towards a general reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees: the first is Senator Ryan's administration charge, and the second is Mr Dawkins's opening the door to the introduction of fees in respect of some post-graduate courses. It is well known that the so-called higher education administration charge is simply an unconvincing attempt at rhetoric to avoid the use of the word `fee'.

I point out that Mr Dawkins's departure from Labor's long-standing no fees policy represents something much greater than doing away with one of Labor's fast dwindling stock of sacred cows. It shows that Mr Dawkins and the Australian Labor Party are now looking to achieve economic goals in the field of education. The social goals that were the very essence of the Party a few years ago have now gone out the window. There can be little doubt that fees will become an essential ingredient in the Minister's plans for higher education. Only one question remains to be answered: Can the Labor Left stop him at the national conference in June? The answer is, of course, wait and see.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no.
—That is the problem the Government faces with its higher education policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin interjects that the answer is no. I think he is probably right. The pragmatists in the Hawke Government, including Mr Dawkins, Senator Walsh and other proponents of tertiary fees, very genuinely recognise the plateau problem that I and other senators have been addressing in debate for several years now, and they recognise the Opposition's policy as being an open, honest and logical approach. However, they still have about their necks the great millstone of the Labor Party's past commitment to no tertiary tuition fees. But I believe that the pragmatists are likely to win in June. It is a wait and see problem. That is the problem with the Government's higher education policy now-it is a wait and see policy. It is a `let us take 1988 out of the triennial progression' policy; a `let us have a pause' policy. It is a `let us have a year off to try to win that policy debate' type of policy. It is an `objectives without explicit means of achievement' policy. It is not a credible policy; it may become so but it is not credible yet.

I return to Mr Dawkins's vision-his objectives for the future of the higher education sector. His view of objectives is not all that different from the views spelt out by the Liberal Party at the last election. He has tried to steal our clothes, as the Hawke Government has tried in many areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has done very well.

—Yes, I think it has done very well in a number of areas. It is good to see Liberal policies serving Australia well. Certainly, Mr Dawkins accepts our analysis that following the last few years of stagnation-the plateau dilemma I have often referred to-we need a dramatic infusion of newer and higher objectives. The then Liberal Party spokesman on education said in February that the Party:

SPEECH.PARA: acknowledged entirely the urgent need to increase the number of graduates especially in scientific and technological fields and to boost the number of young people participating in higher education.

Our plan for higher education was aimed at increasing the number of people participating and improving the quality of their studies, but not by imposing more control and depriving the sector of funds. The Opposition also said:
Our policy recognises the diminishing capacity of the Federal Government alone to finance the necessary expansion.

Mr Dawkins has certainly taken a chapter out of the coalition's book but it is only one chapter-the chapter on objectives. He evades the rest; he evades the logic of determining actual realistic means to achieve these objectives. Where we differ is on the question of means and how to expand the higher education sector.

Mr Dawkins is set to do this, firstly, by Canberra imposed thumb screws to get efficiency and, secondly, by inadequate hints about reintroducing fees. I refer to thumb screws because I am convinced that the so-called efficiency measures will be achieved by the Minister directly interfering in the administration of the universities and colleges. Real efficiency is not gained by imposition, by thumb screws and whips in the hands of the Canberra Minister and a more powerful Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training. Real efficiency is gained-and I ask honourable senators to look about them for concrete examples-by inspiring shared objectives, by giving sensible incentives and by ensuring there is freedom to act. Responsibility should be decentralised, not centralised as by Mr Dawkins's approach.

Another point I wish to make is that efficiencies do not necessarily come without costs. This is particularly true when dealing with such unquantifiable matters as the quality of research. These are issues that are not simple and I suspect Mr Dawkins will have a lot of trouble in an overcentralised and intrusive approach in this area. Mr Dawkins's objectives for higher education also involve a new responsiveness to the needs of the economy and a greater ability for our eduction processes to produce the skills we need in practice to be more prosperous. That is fine, but he believes that his own plan for higher education is correct and that others who oppose him are wrong and should be ignored. It is unwise to make all the key decisions before consultation. It is unwise to put even those key decisions into so much of a strait-jacket. Yesterday's Green Paper does call in the preface for consultation, for views. But has anyone seriously got an example to show how any of the consultation after 22 September has altered the key decisions that were already made without consultation? There is a great deal of danger in the Minister's strait-jacket.

In order to shape higher education after his own model he intends to do away with the independent statutory authority, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC), and replace it with a small Advisory Council on Higher Education. That Council will be a substructure of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and will deal only with matters referred by the Board or the Minister himself. In turn, the Board will base its work program and reports on formal references provided by the Minister. Council and Board recommendations and reports are to be put-and I quote from the Government's proposal-in the context of the Government's economic, social and resource allocation policies. In other words, the Council and Board might as well be part of the Minister's own staff or part of the already enlarged powers of the Commonwealth Department. I know that many in the higher education sector came to value the work and relative independence developed by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. Any amendment to CTEC, from the Opposition's point of view, would have been to give more autonomy to individual institutions so that the advice and decision-making could be even more independent, but this Minister has gone entirely in the other direction.

I am sure that academics, students and administrators of universities and colleges cannot and do not expect as much from the new so-called Advisory Council. Nor can they expect too much independence or security in the next two or three years in the area of Commonwealth funding. The Minister has already abandoned triennial funding, at least for the next year, in favour of mere annual funding. This will give him more power to force through the changes he wants in our higher education sector.

The conclusion to be drawn from all these developments, expressed now all around Australia and by Opposition senators and members in this Parliament, is that the Dawkins era is the most centralised and least consultative government regime ever imposed on higher education in Australia. Just consider the 1950s, when institutions were autonomous and were responsive to State governments, or the 1960s, the 1970s or the early 1980s, the whole 15 years of the Karmel period. Nothing compared with the present approach was so centralised and so dependent upon Canberra and the Commonwealth straitjacket.

In contrast to the approach taken by Mr Dawkins and the Labor Government, the Opposition spelt out its plans to reform and expand the higher education sector, not by imposing more control but by giving universities and colleges more autonomy and more control of their own affairs. Our higher education policy released earlier this year stated that the traditional approach-I call it the `traditional' approach; at least it has been traditional since the Whitlam Government-in higher education has been to seek ever-increasing public finance. There is still, of course, the unimaginative and less than responsible approach of the Australian Democrats. They still believe that the way out of the plateau is more and more public money from taxpayers, and I believe that that is less than responsible. But we in the real world, that is, most Government and Opposition senators, acknowledge that this solution of more public money-the traditional response that has led to the plateau of the last 15 years-is no longer feasible, given the nation's alarming debt, our excessive level of taxation and the other competing budgetary needs.

It is true that the previous Minister, Senator Ryan, adopted the traditional public funding solution-not successfully; but at best, as we now mostly agree, this has produced only marginal results. The Liberal Party has said that this approach is altogether inadequate. Mr Dawkins has obviously agreed with this. However, the Opposition policy also warned that the higher education institutions are becoming `ever more dependent on the directives of government'. We warned that the combination of bureaucratic management and insufficient funding for competing institutions was eroding academic freedom and institutional freedom, and it is imposing greater Commonwealth control. Canberra has eroded the very freedom which universities, institutes and colleges need to allow them to initiate many aspects of the solution to the plateau problem that we face.

Mr Dawkins is even using his fiscal strings to bring the tertiary sector under more control than we thought possible. Already academics are up in arms because they see Mr Dawkins's plans as totally unreasonable and intrusive. They know that there will be no additional funding in real terms. They know that he wants to create an additional 75,000 places by the end of the year 2000. They know that he is intent on forcing through onerous so-called efficiency and effectiveness measures, many of which will amount to real cuts in resources and serious downward pressures on teaching and research standards. Our vice-chancellors and principals and other academic leaders have argued that the higher education sector has always been able and willing to meet the economic needs of the nation. This is where the Liberal Party and many academics have serious differences with the current Labor Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

Mr Dawkins, in a less than helpful contribution to the debate on university reform, in a speech made recently in Melbourne accused universities and, in particular, the older institutions, of being `ossified bodies incapable of change'. This is a silly remark. It is a prejudiced remark. It is entirely unworthy of any Commonwealth Minister. Mr Dawkins should not be allowed to forget this shallow remark. It reinforces the view that Mr Dawkins's approach does not have depth and is, so very unfortunately, subjective. The Minister clearly is set on confrontation to force the changes he wants. I hope that he will repent of that approach. For example, in late October the Age reported that members of the schools lobby had been told to toe the Government line or be left out of education reforms. Mr Dawkins was quoted as telling the Australian Council of State School Organisations:

Those who decide that the new arrangements are unwelcome and not to be tolerated will, of course, run the inevitable risk of having their views ignored as we develop and implement our new arrangements.
Mr Dawkins has also said that his objective is to bring together limited resources to make the greatest impact for change. He said:
Those people who stand out against that simple, and I would have thought undeniable, objective will quickly isolate themselves.

In early November, Mr Dawkins refused to meet a delegation of student representatives who were seeking to open consultations with him. More recently, it was reported that Mr Dawkins had decided to abolish the Government's advisory council on overseas students. So we can see that consensus is out and control is in. As I said earlier, the Opposition has no problem with Mr Dawkins's objective to expand higher education. What deeply disturbs us is that Mr Dawkins proposes to achieve his own imposed changes through a centralist, dictatorial and confrontationist approach. We are disturbed that the end result of this approach will be failure. That is not good enough for Australia. This Labor Government and this Minister have borrowed the Opposition's published policy for higher education insofar as the objectives of the policy are concerned, but they have not yet accepted the necessary preconditions and the means proposed to achieve these objectives. The Opposition continues to maintain that these means require consultation and partnership as to objectives and then increased freedom and clearer autonomy for education institutions themselves to take up a wide range of realistic options, to map out their own destinies and serve more responsibly their own communities of students.

Had the Minister followed the approach of the coalition parties, Australia could now have been looking forward to a rapidly expanding higher education sector in which universities and colleges, enjoying far greater autonomy, could be initiating most of the solution we are looking to achieve. The Opposition believes that our higher education institutions are responsive to change and should be given the opportunity to contribute in a major way to the achievement of that change. The Labor Government and the Minister should wake up to the fact that our universities, institutions and colleges are dynamic institutions that will make major contributions to the economic well-being of our country if allowed to flourish.

I support all of the remarks of Senator Vanstone, leading for the Opposition in this debate, and the amendments moved at the second reading stage of the nine Bills before us. My remarks have been confined to higher education because, in these last days of debate in this session of Parliament, higher education is so prominently before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this morning to talk on this package of nine Bills covering a range of Government policy towards schools and tertiary education. To a great extent it reveals the sad deficiencies of this Government's approach. The Student Assistance Amendment Bill, which deals with Austudy, is to a large degree mechanical but, in establishing the right of the Federal Government to determine those institutions in which Austudy should be provided, its provision has been limited to those students undertaking courses wholly or substantially funded from Government sources. A government that supposedly is taking a more innovative approach to tertiary education has therefore at a stroke created a further barrier against private tertiary institutions, limiting the rights of their potential students. That is the aspect that we must never forget in this entire debate-where the rights of the students and the rights of the parents lie.

SPEECH.PARA: In effect this Government is supporting the self-interested criticisms of private universities by those union-minded academics who hate and fear the thought of free choice and competition and who are blind to the opportunities that private institutions will create for academics as well as students. I wish they would just get away from the myopic attitude they have and look at the broader side of this entire debate.

It is no coincidence that a viable private university is well on the way to being established in Queensland, because that State happens to be the State in which the proportion of young people denied tertiary places is the greatest. The Liberal Party of Australia believes very simply that Australia has to catch up with the rest of the advanced Western societies where 40 to 50 per cent of tertiary funding comes from the private sector, compared with a mere 5 per cent here in Australia. At the same time, it is also a fact that 65 per cent of tertiary funding in Australia in 1939 was from non-government sources. Sadly, we have seen a retrograde turning back from the position we were in in 1939. Private institutions catering for both overseas and Australian students are a means of injecting private funds into the tertiary system, promoting diversity and independence and creating opportunities for those unable to enter publicly funded institutions. They demonstrate the value of a free market in education in which students will not pay money for degrees of dubious credibility. The whole argument about whether or not private tertiary institutions will succeed can be very easily based on that premise, and that premise alone if necessary, because they simply will not continue to exist if the quality of the degrees that come out of those institutions is not accepted by the students.

Attempts by this Government in an otherwise uncontroversial Bill to restrict the free choice of students are to be deplored. I support the Opposition amendment to this Bill which criticises the Government for its administration of Austudy, inconveniencing students and their families. I am sure all honourable senators will know, from just the sheer number of people who have made contacts with their offices expressing grave concern about Austudy generally, the inconvenience that has been created for students and their families.

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 cover a restructuring of tertiary funding, notably, the deferment of the funding triennium that would have commenced in 1988, limited relaxation on the prohibition of fees and the transfer of administrative responsibility from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission directly to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. These changes add up to a dangerous centralisation of control of the tertiary sector by the Government, providing inadequate public funds while denying it the autonomy to raise funds privately.

The dangers of any government seeking to direct research and achieve excellence through ministerial direction must be recognised. We must look to a situation where institutions are in a position to raise funds privately and create a very viable organisation. This year has seen 20,000 young Australians denied tertiary places-a rise of 22 per cent on the previous year. That simply cannot be sneezed at. It is something that this Government should be looking at and it should be making its policies accordingly, in preference to just closing its eyes and pretending that the problem does not exist. The deeply held policies of this Government have denied all these students the opportunity that we rightly provide overseas students-that of paying a tertiary institution for the education that they need for their future working lives. Why should Australian students be denied what we are in fact offering overseas students? It is absolutely absurd. We have seen the Government go through the farce of imposing on students a supposed administration fee while actually lacking the honesty and imagination to ditch its ideological hangups and simply allow institutions to charge fees when quotas of publicly funded places are filled.

By both words and deeds the Government recognises one truth-that public funds are limi-ted and that it cannot provide what our tertiary institutions need. All that will be provided for 1988 with the deferred triennium is a net increase of $16m, which equates to a very small 2.1 per cent rise. That will in no way finance the demand for tertiary places. It will not go near it. What makes this financial stringency absolutely unacceptable to the Liberal Party is the fact that it is not accompanied by any realistic move to increase the autonomy of institutions to allow them the common-sense flexibility to offer places to fee paying Australian students, as we in the Opposition have been advocating. This legislation allows fees to be imposed only for vocational post-graduate courses, and that, I believe, is just far too limited.

The Australian Labor Party is, of course, supported in its bigotry and hypocrisy on the fees question by academic staff unions that increasingly are out of step with progressive academic opinion, motivated by a concern that fee paying students will demand greater accountability from less effective tertiary staff. The interests they seek to represent are opposed to those of the student as the education consumer. I think it is about time that the academic staff unions actually began to consider what the consumer needs at the end of the day. I strongly support the Opposition's proposed amendment to the second reading motion of this Bill, which draws attention both to the inadequacies of tertiary funding in the circumstances I have outlined and to the centralising measures which the Government has announced and which find expression in this legislation.

Clause 14 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill refers to the approval for targeted research activities `subject to such conditions as the Minister determines'. It is clear that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Government believe that they have sufficient wisdom to be able to determine what priorities shall hold sway in research-according to their perception of the national good. It is the same philosophy, sadly, that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has been peddling in its corporatist blueprint Australia Reconstructed. We in the Liberal Party wish to place on record our warning that academic excellence can never be produced by ministerial direction. Indeed, it can only suffer, just as private enterprise withers when Ministers and bureaucrats take it on themselves to pick winners and try to direct investment as they have done so often in the past.

There is concern that, through an emphasis on technology-desirable as that may be; let us not deny that-the humanities may at the end of the day be starved of funds. What Australia requires is excellence across the academic spectrum. This will not be achieved by any bureaucratic centralism of research funding. Of course, talk about excellence always brings to mind Senator Ryan's now famous statement when she was Minister for Education that the pursuit of excellence is elitist. I think it is the greatest tragedy of all time that the Government underpins its legislative program by saying that the pursuit of excellence is elitist. We should in fact be encouraging excellence instead of trying to belittle it.

Both the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 establish the basis of the new boards that will control education under close Government direction. This will be achieved through the transfer of responsibility for administering the Act from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I do not believe that education has a particularly bright future when its controlling board will have two representatives of the ACTU and four public servants among its 12 members. I must say that this is a cause of great concern for me. We can be confident that the views of academic and teaching unions will carry far greater weight than those of education consumers, whether those consumers be students or parents. The Opposition believes strongly that excellence can flourish only where institutions have maximum auto- nomy and education consumers have maximum choice to go with that autonomy. The centra-lised, corporatist formula that this Hawke Go-vernment is embracing will negate any of the worthwhile objectives that it may seek to promote.

Mention should also be made of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, which provides funding for go-vernment and independent schools in 1988. The Opposition takes this opportunity to place on record its opposition to the absurd and sinister regulation of independent schools, designed only to subvert the free choice of parents, especially those parents on limited incomes. Why should those people in particular be penalised? This Government always has difficulty in coming to terms with the fact that increasing numbers are now going into the non-government schools area. According to the Government's own Budget Papers of this year, 27 per cent of Australian school children are now being educated in non-government schools. The 1986 census of non-government schools showed that 800,000 children were attending 2,446 independent schools and that, of these, 60,000 children in 230 schools were in my own State of Western Australia.

Governments that attempt to arrest this trend by placing limitations on the formation or expansion of independent schools and by financial restrictions that impose penalties on self-help are betraying a generation of Australians who should be given that freedom of choice. If it is the parents' wish to go without other things to be able to send their children to private schools, they should not be hamstrung in doing so purely and simply by Government policy. The Government also indulges in a form of religious discrimination, as these restrictions bear hard upon Christian schools that so often cater for children from homes with modest incomes. Other denominations deserve the opportunity to replicate the Catholic system that has provided an alternative for so long to the state system.

To a large degree, these restrictions are imposed at the behest of the teachers unions. The teachers union in Queensland was quoted on 20 September in the Times on Sunday as fearing `that there seems to be no lid on the trend to freedom of choice in education'. That any res-ponsible group of people involved in teaching can so proclaim their desire to limit an essential human freedom is absolutely alarming. This Government, however, seems anxious to conciliate these collectivists at the expense of freedom of choice and that probably is even more alarming.

I am confident that a future Liberal government will do all it can to extend this freedom to more and more parents prepared to make some financial sacrifice for the sake of their ideals, always bearing in mind that 27 per cent of children attending independent schools receive only 15 per cent of the total public education dollar. So they are not receiving much, but they are getting a further kick in the pants at every turn under this Government's policies. A Liberal government will also increase accountability across the whole range of Australian schools through a national standards monitoring program, in co-operation with the States and independent schools, measuring levels of both basic literacy and numeracy and higher academic achievement. I believe that this will be welcomed by parents, and by conscientious teachers who do not fear any form of objective evaluation of their output. Many of those conscientious teachers advocate this choice and decision.

This package of legislation, I think, has demonstrated the philosophic divide between the Government, which believes in ministerial direction of excellence, and the coalition parties, which believe that it can be achieved by individuals only in a less regulated tertiary environment. It has also shown the difference between the Government view that choice in schooling is a privilege granted by the state and our belief that it is a fundamental civil right that governments have a duty to uphold. I support very strongly the amendments that have been moved by Senator Vanstone and I look forward to a more balanced and realistic education policy in the very near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been one distinct feature of the education debate over the years, that is, the whole debate has moved closer to the coalition's policies. It has been no mean feat to get a mass of Federal and State public servants and academics out of their ivory towers. This Government, with its dinosaur-like beliefs in education, is led by the left wing. There has been a great movement towards the coalition's policies in terms of new ideas in education in this country. There has been a great amount of pressure from industry and commerce, which have been saying for years that the education system has not reacted quickly enough to changes in this area. Parents who are totally dissatisfied with the decaying education system over the years have also brought some pressure to bear.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has led the debate and has put it in its proper perspective. I will read out some of our policies because they relate to a policy discussion paper entitled Higher Education which was put out by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). Five of the coalition's policies, in broad terms, are: firstly, broadening of access to fee paying students; secondly, requiring higher education institutions to seek funds from non-public sources; thirdly, closer relations between higher education and industry; fourthly, more respective attitudes to private higher education institutions; and, fifthly, increased flexibility in course offerings in technical and further education (TAFE) colleges and colleges of advanced education (CAEs). Those policies represent the cornerstone of the coalition's attitude to education. Turning now to Mr Dawkins's Green Paper, keeping in mind the coalition's policies, I will read three sections. Firstly, under the heading `Higher education in TAFE', the document states:

There is no good reason, however, why two-year full-time (or equivalent) courses in TAFE, funded by the States and leading to nationally registered awards, should continue to be differentiated from equivalent courses undertaken in CAEs . . .
That is the crux of one of our policies. Under the heading `11.2 Use of non-Commonwealth revenue for the funding of additional higher education places', at page 84, the paper states:
It is desirable that institutions pursue these opportunities, not least because of the improved links with the private sector and the community as a whole that will result.
Under the heading `Joint arrangements with employers', the paper states:
Employers have a direct interest-
that is a new admission from this Government-

in the quality and quantity of graduates from Australia's higher education institutions. Increasing the number of graduates in certain disciplines will, for example, help overcome the problems faced by employers of shortages of certain skills.

That has been said for years. The difference between the Green Paper and our policies is that, sadly, the Government will have great difficulty in introducing the proposals. As previous speakers have outlined, particularly Senator Teague, the Government will have to face its own left wing on such a new ideology. Of course, the Government lost out to the left wing on the privatisation issue. The Government must face up to changes in education policies. No amount of structural changes will count for much unless the educators are scrutinised in terms of quality. I see that as the most important part of the education debate. The foundations of our tertiary institutions-that is, our secondary schools-should also be examined.

The Victorian State Chamber of Commerce, of which I am a Board member, has a very deep concern about the lack of basic skills of secondary school leavers, particularly those from government schools, and of those leaving universities. So deep is its concern that it has introduced a commerce certificate, the holding of which will, it believes, better equip school and university leavers with the skills needed in commerce, which sadly are not being taught properly at the moment. There is evidence of that. Professor Lauchlan Chipman of the University of Wollongong has pointed out that between 80 and 90 per cent of the young unemployed are from the government education system. That is a very sad admission. I would point the finger at our teacher unions as one of the reasons for that, especially in my State. I believe that there are many fine teachers in Victoria but, equally, many do nothing but push their own political ends. I refer, of course, to the Socialist Left Victorian Teachers Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! They are as right wing as anything.
—So concerned were some teachers about such a left wing loony union that they formed a breakaway group made up of more moderate teachers. I give my full support to that group.

SPEECH.PARA: As I outlined before, one of the major complaints, particularly in Victoria, concerns the foundations of our tertiary institutions-that is, our secondary institutions-and the fact that radical left wing teachers have attempted to hijack the bureaucracies and curriculums of those schools. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review which really spells out the great problem we have with many of our teacher unions. It states:

The problems of the teachers' union to a considerable extent derive from the kind of leadership which the members have allowed to dominate their unions. To generalise, these are dominated by the hangover of the Vietnam war, inferior intellects who preferred activism to study and who are still fighting the battles of their youth. As they are entering middle age, they still mouth the slogans of a decade ago, and search for new causes, whether the anti-uranium movement or `peace studies'-anything except serious pedagogy and serious disciplines of study.

That sums up my concern very well. As Senator Knowles pointed out, there could well be a lost generation due to the lack of excellence in our schools. Concern by parents is putting pressure on the Government to loosen up its strict controls on our education system and to allow greater choice for parents between the private and government sectors, not only in our primary and secondary schools but now, hopefully and properly, in our universities. I support the concept of private universities. They are coming not before time. This is a step towards excellence in education.

I conclude by saying that young people today need to be taught a lot more hope, vision, responsibility and discipline. They need to be taught about leadership in society. They are not getting those things, at least not in my State, because, sadly, left wing teachers have neglected these basic values and prefer a society of very much freer values so they can push their own political ends. As I said before, so many parents are realising the bias in schools that teachers-and this very weak Government-have been getting the message sheeted home to them very clearly that there is a need to return to the fundamentals of education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Student Assistance Amendment Bill, the Maritime College Amendment Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill, the Australian National University Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, despite what Senator McGauran seems to think about them, actually cover a range of areas in which, allegedly, the Federal Government gives assistance via various States grants Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I say these Bills allegedly provide Federal Government assistance via the States because while the Bills certainly purport to provide assistance to tertiary education, overseas students, the participation and equity program (PEP), schools, students generally and the two major tertiary institutions in Canberra, the fact is that they do nothing of the sort. In many ways these Bills simply entrench the anti-education attitudes of this Government. They are certainly at variance with the pious statements and noises made by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins-and for that matter by previous Labor Ministers for Education-and the Government regarding their supposed commitment to education. This Bills package is the most recent in a long line of Budget and mini-Budget Bills which have eroded in very real terms the funding given by this Government to all sectors of education and to the students who are part of those sectors.

Particularly hard hit have been students in receipt of Austudy and those isolated and disadvantaged students involved in the participation and equity program and other isolated children's assistance programs. I was a little amused to read one of the amendments proposed by the Opposition to the second reading motion of one of the Bills, which requires to have added at the end of the second reading motion:

. . . but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to administer Austudy student assistance grants in a timely and efficient manner, thus causing grave inconvenience to students and their families.

I am not going to argue that what the Government has done to Austudy in recent months has not caused grave inconvenience to students and their families; I just find it rather astonishing that the Opposition parties, having assisted the Government in causing that inconvenience by passing legislation that cut back Austudy payments to 15-year-olds in the last two years of school, should then take the Government to task for doing precisely that.

A tremendous amount of inconvenience has been caused to a large number of low income families, in South Australia and Western Australia in particular, because the Government chose to remove Austudy payments to 15-year-olds in their last two years of school. Essentially that has made it a lot more difficult for 15-year-olds who come from low income families in the two States I have just mentioned, South Australia and Western Australia, to continue their secondary education. When we challenged the former Minister for Education on the fact that low income families would be losing up to $40 a week-that is, a little over $2,000 a year-as a result of this inequitable move by the Government, and asked what would happen to these 15-year-olds if they could not afford to stay in a secondary school system which is far from free, even in the public sector, Senator Ryan gave a version of the Marie Antoinette comment. She said, `Let them get a part time job'. She wants to let the 15-year-olds who are going to be deprived of this income, as a result of the cuts to Austudy payments to their families, work presumably in fast-food chains or on a paper round. Maybe somebody has not pointed out to her that kids from low income families have enough difficulty now in getting through their educational program, without having the burden of funding it placed on them. I do not know what cloud Senator Ryan has been existing on but she is off in cloud cuckoo-land if she thinks that those children should be responsible for funding their own education.

This change is particularly inequitable for students in South Australia and Western Australia because the majority of year 11 students in those States are aged 15 for all or some of their fourth year in secondary school and very many of them are still 15 years old when they enter their matriculation year of high school. Those students do not need this clip in the ear, the removal of this assistance, from a government which is supposed to be concerned about the quality of life and the prospects of low income families and of their children in particular. The participation and equity program was another Government initiative that was supposed to encourage qualitative changes in education in schools and technical and further education colleges.

It was argued by the Government that traditional practices and institutions were not always the best form of education for many young people, again especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. In the past, the education system did not have to worry too much about those from disadvantaged backgrounds because, when they left school before completing their secondary education, they were able to find employment. Until a decade or so ago, it was not abnormal for young people from disadvantaged backgrounds who could not continue in the edu-cation system to leave school, because employers were prepared at that stage to employ students at 15 years of age. This is now no longer the case, for a variety of reasons, including, I suggest, the fact that, in many States, public exams have been done away with at that level and employers are generally suspicious of internal school assessments. In any event, whatever the reason may be, it is now no longer possible for many youngsters who leave school before the normal final year to get employment. As I said, that changed and the education system had to respond. The Commonwealth, through the participation and equity program, was to be a catalyst for reforms. The Commonwealth Schools Commission wished the Government to continue in that role. In its paper The National Interest it is stated:

Systems, schools and, increasingly, the wider community, are acknowledging that PEP is a program with positive and lasting effects. PEP is bringing about marked changes in the climate, organisation and teaching in secondary schools.

The Commission states that it seeks a new secondary education program, that is, a new specific purpose program, `as a necessary logical development and focusing of PEP', yet the Government has refused to accept this recommendation. It will not provide a successor program to PEP and, worse, it has decided also not to continue the specific purpose program complementary to PEP, the basic learning in primary schools program. So, by and large, the Government has turned its back on those programs that were set up to assist disadvantaged children to provide some sort of equity in the education system. That is basically at the secondary school level, but the problem has not stopped there.

Funding has been cut from technical and further education (TAFE) colleges. We saw $30m removed from TAFE funding at a time when the Government also said that training and retraining programs were important; that flexibility in education was essential; and that our young people, the mature age unemployed, people made redundant and women wanting to get back into the work force had to be catered for through appropriate and adequate training and retraining programs. What did the Government do about it? It cut $30m from those programs. Fees-by any name the Government likes to call them, they are still fees-have been imposed on university students, and the rug is being slowly but surely pulled out from under the public education system across the board. The introduction of university fees-the so-called administrative fee of $250 which was geared to be increased according to consumer price index increases- has made it more difficult for low income families, women and certain people from ethnic groupings to get into the tertiary education system. That trend became obvious within months of the Government's tertiary fees program being instituted. People who were doing part time university and higher education courses were unable to continue with those, because there was no pro rata application of that tertiary fee.

I must say that I shared Senator Macklin's frustration and irritation during the debate on that legislation when we had no support at all from Liberal and National Party senators at least to have that fee imposed on a pro rata basis for students at universities. They hid behind their standard argument that it was a Budget Bill, that Budget Bills are sacrosanct, and chose to wave their arms and say how terrible it was and what damage it was likely to do to certain groups. But, when it came to the crunch, they were not prepared to put their vote where they alleged their sentiments were. It does not surprise me at all that the Government has announced that it will have another May mini-Budget. It might just as well have a Budget in August or September and then another one in May when it knows that, by labelling these Bills as Budget Bills, it has induced the Opposition parties to roll over and have their collective tummies tickled. Why should it introduce legislation by another name when, by labelling it `Budget', it knows that it will have it passed, no matter what the social and economic consequences are?

In relation to this sort of package, in many instances the Opposition parties are only too happy to support the moves by this Government, because they see them as reflecting the increasingly New Rightist attitudes that the Opposition parties have. It did not surprise me at all that Senator Teague claimed that his Party and the Australian Labor Party were the only political parties in this country that were living in the land of reality, because they have joined forces in this area to make education a prime target for further privatisation, for limited government funding and for increased government interference.

If that was not the Government's intention, why else would honourable senators see in the notorious Green Paper to which Senator Macklin referred last night a statement such as that on page 29 under the heading `Educational Profiles'? Here we have the following extraordinary statement:
Under the unified national system, the principal mechanism for defining institutional roles will be institutionally developed educational profiles.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?
—That is a good question. What does it mean? The statement contains a lot of words with more than one syllable, but it does not make a great deal of sense. It goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: These-
presumably the educational profiles-
will take the form of statements that identify the role and mission of institutions in broad terms including, for example, fields of study-
which, I would have thought, one could have worked out if one looked at the prospectus of any tertiary education institution-
areas of research-
I know that our universities provide annual reports on the research that they have been doing, so yet again there is documentary evidence of that-

and the enrolment mix to which they wish to give priority, as well as statements of intent on issues such as equity and credit transfer.
