These educational profiles should both describe an institution's existing course mix and indicate the areas that the institution wishes to develop as strengths for the future. They will be subject to a process of discussion with the Government to enable both parties-
that is, the institution and the Government; we are not talking about political parties here-
to agree on a contract that specifies:
the level of funding available to the institution from the Commonwealth to implement its chosen academic goals;
the ability of the institution to meet the higher education needs of its community; and
the institution's contribution to national priorities identified by the Commonwealth.

What a weapon to hold over the heads of institutions! It suggests, `Come to us with your plans. If we like them, we will fund you; if we do not like them, we will not'. It is as simple as that. There is no other way to read those statements under the heading `Educational Profiles' in the Green Paper. Indeed, on the front page of this morning's Australian, under the headline `Universities told: Reform or funds will be cut'-`reform' means that the universities must change what they do in line with that the Government wants, or the Government will take away their money-an article by Paul Austin, states:
Universities and colleges will have their funding cut unless they give a written commitment to comply with the Hawke Government's economic and social goals . . .
The article makes the following point:

But to be allowed into the new system, institutions will have to achieve a size nominated by the Government, submit a written ``educational profile'' detailing their plans for research and study and give a commitment to implement a new salary structure under which quality staff could be given more pay but redundant staff could be sacked.

One wonders exactly what `redundant' means. Does it mean troublemakers or people who do not stick to the Government's goals? What happened to the freedom of academic thought that tenure was supposed to provide? The article continues:
In return, the Government will promise to give institutions more autonomy in internal spending and course-creation decisions and allow them to bid for a pool of funds.

The point there is that they get the pool of funds only after they have indicated, and received government approval for, their internal spending and their course creation proposals. So, the Government is creating a nice little chicken and egg situation. It is doing so in a country that is supposed to be democratic and in which institutions of this sort should be autonomous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the funds be 2 1/2 per cent of the previous year's recurrent money?

—I think it is a case of pick a number; it could be anything. It could be 2 1/2 per cent as set out in the Green Paper or the figure could be subject to some other change by the Government. There is absolutely no guarantee that any funding will go to any tertiary institution unless those institutions succumb to government demands with regard to course content and educational profiles. It means essentially that if tertiary institutions do not toe the government line, if they do not meet the Government's perceived needs for the community, if they do not contribute to government determined priorities, they can wave goodbye to their funding. That is occurring at a time when government and private funding is being increased in other civilised countries. But we in Australia are cutting public funding to tertiary institutions and secondary schools and encouraging the establishment of utilitarian fee paying universities to pander to the needs of the New Right-something that is enthusiastically supported by such people as Senator McGauran and Senator Teague.

SPEECH.PARA: It is noted that there is no further commitment to knowledge for its own sake, as that sort of thing produces the so-called lunatic fringe about which Senator McGauran spoke. We must not have thinking in society, just utilitarianism. There is no more pretence that tertiary institutions are free of government interference, and there is no longer even the thin veneer of equity or claims that education is free and accessible to all. Despite the rhetoric, women and students from low income families will have even less access to tertiary education than they do now, and they will have less choice within those institutions if the Government, in return for funding, imposes the sorts of restrictions that are predicted in the Green Paper under the heading `Educational Profiles'.

As other senators have pointed out, this is happening at a time when this country is crying out for a skills based work force. Ironically, many of those cries are coming from the private sector, which not only does not contribute in the way of research and development funding or higher education assistance but actively resents government funding of these institutions. Those same people believe in the user pays system but do not allow themselves to be pushed into funding the very institutions that now and in the future will provide them with the benefits they need. On the one hand, the private sector is claiming that it needs a skills based work force and that a user pays system should operate but, on the other hand, it, the user of the end product of the education system, is not willing to pay for that end product. Indeed, I think it is worth examining the comments that were made in a fairly long article written by Kenneth Davidson in this morning's Age newspaper. He wrote:

The real issue, and probably the biggest question facing Australia at the present time, is how to build the skills base necessary to staff the high value-added industries we will have to create to generate the wealth necessary to replace the decline in income from traditional commodity exports.
These industries, if they are to be internationally competitive, must be at the cutting edge of the new technologies and skills.

Given our dominant corporate culture that stresses the short-term and sees employees as costs of production rather than a firm's major asset and the belief that skills can be pinched from down the road or overseas, business can only be quickly engaged in the education process on the scale necessary if it is subject to some sort of education and training levy.

That is, impose a levy so that the user pays, so that the employers pay for the end product of the education system. If that were tried, the private sector would squeal and claim that it was being excessively taxed. Far from ensuring that university education is no longer the preserve of the rich, as Mr Dawkins claims, the package of Bills before us today and the system proposed in the Green Paper, as well as the Government's actions over the past few years and promises by the Opposition, which would like to be in government, will ensure that access to advanced education is the prerogative of the privileged. Education is therefore yet another area in relation to which this Government and the Liberal and National parties are in agreement, if not in cahoots. Their mutual aims are to undermine the public education sector by cutting funds, lowering morale, imposing government demands and removing autonomy, while at the same time encouraging a deregulated, freewheeling, fee paying private education system which, by its very nature, will be utilitarian, shortsighted, and ultimately disastrous for the long term development of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. I point out to Senator Haines that everything I tried to bring to this debate was designed to enhance thinking and to increase the creativity of Australians so that originality is encouraged, new fields are developed and there is a readiness for change. My remarks should not in any way be interpreted as seeking to limit the bounds of thinking in Australians, not least among those in our higher education institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Teague set the record straight. If ever there was a misrepresentation of the Opposition's views on education, it was the last drab picture painted by Senator Haines. Obviously she was keen to present a picture of what life would be like under the Australian Democrats. Thank God that there is no chance that they will ever be in a position to put their views into effect in this country. The Liberal Party of Australia believes in choice in education; it believes in diversity; it believes in excellence; it believes in individuals providing their children with the best opportunities they can; and it believes in all of the resources in the country being brought into play to ensure that our children get the best education that we can possibly offer them. That does not mean that the education system has to be run entirely by the state. It does not mean that the education system must be one based on equality of outcome, which is what the Government seems to believe in. We are committed to equality of input and opportunity; we have no commitment to equality of outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I hoped that my reading of the papers produced and the statements made on this subject by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) since he was given responsibility for the education portfolio meant that the Government had changed its emphasis in the education field. I hoped, too, that the Government was looking for better outcomes than it has been willing to pursue in the past. Under the administration of the previous Minister, I feel that the Government was trying to turn out of our education system children at the one level of achievement. The Government has failed to recognise that people possess a variety of skills and talents and that those skills and talents must be developed to the utmost.

If it is our purpose to meet the needs of employers in the fields of technology and commerce in this country, which is the matter upon which Mr Dawkins places heavy emphasis, no longer should we be seeking to achieve just equality of outcome. We have to concentrate on getting everybody producing to the best of their talents. I am very proud of the fact that on this side of the Parliament we have always had a view that excellence should be encouraged and that there is nothing elitist in supporting our most talented to the fullest extent of their abilities. It is right and important to encourage the slower learners, and it is also very important to ensure that the average child gets the best education possible. But why have we had this cult of not giving the best education possible to our most gifted children? This anti-elitism view, which is so prevalent in many of our education systems, despite lip service to the contrary, and the behaviour of the education system over the years have tended to discourage and quench the thirst for learning in our brightest children.

Research which has been carried out since 1981 at the University of Tasmania Education Centre has followed the 1981 cohort of grade 10s through since that year. One of the most depressing outcomes of that research has been the high proportion of children who have not pursued education after grade 10 and who are in the very brightest percentile of their year. By not pursuing further education I mean not going on to apprenticeships, on the job training or to grades 11 and 12 and, obviously, not going on to tertiary education or any form of higher education. We are losing some of our brightest children because they have been wrongly diagnosed by their teachers at a very early stage in the education system as being troublemakers. I think that we are still putting through the training system teachers who are not trained to recognise the brightest children. They are frightened by their lack of training to educate these children to their fullest potential. This is a matter of terrible concern to Australia. If Mr Dawkins's policy of concentrating on making education fit the needs of employers is to be effective, then surely one of the end results of that will have to be doing better by our most gifted and talented children.

Nevertheless, I do sound a word of warning because if this country simply continues to concentrate only on the needs of employers and the needs of the nation we will have only half- educated people. The tradition that we have had through the universities in Australia, and in Bri-tain and the European countries since the Middle Ages, has been education for education's sake and not just for employment's sake. Many people who have led our nation were leaders because they were well educated and well rounded people, not because they were experts in some technical field or other. This country does not need just skilled technocrats. It needs people of vision who can lead the country through difficult times. An excellent education-even if not necessarily directed to some professional area-is vital in providing such people of vision.

I am glad to see that the Government admits that Australia languishes at the bottom of the league of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in relation to higher education participation by young people. I say this not because I am glad we languish but because I am glad to see that the admission is there. I am glad to see that there is an emphasis on improving that because one first has to recognise and admit the problem before one can take meaningful action. A recognition of that is obviously the first step. Nevertheless, there are somewhere between 13,000 and 20,000-goodness knows what the exact figure is-qualified applicants unable to secure tertiary places in this country and there is no promise of improvement in 1988. That is a matter of real concern. Even though we have this shortage of places there are other ways of getting people into tertiary institutions. The Government is just not opening up the alternatives; it is not remo-ving the regulations which would go some way towards solving the problem. It is not giving the students the freedom of choice which could be given and which could make a real and meaningful difference to the number of people who can get access to tertiary education.

I particularly point out that the Government is perfectly happy to accept fees from overseas students to get into Australian tertiary institutions. That seems to me to be a particularly blind spot-the Government is prepared to accept fees from overseas students but it is not prepared to accept fees from Australian students who could not otherwise get in. I am a product of the system whereby, many years ago, many thousands of Australians were in receipt of Commonwealth Government scholarships for university entry. These scholarships were gene-rously supplied. Those who could not get a Commonwealth scholarship could still get in provided they paid their way. I was on a Commonwealth scholarship but many of my contemporaries worked their way through university on waitressing and labouring jobs, as students continue to do today. I do not believe that they suffered in their education. In fact, I think it made them much more determined to achieve and to win through. I think it is character building, if not necessarily the most desirable way; it is certainly much better than and preferable to missing out on tertiary education altogether. I cannot understand the blind spot that the Government has in this area.

I see that the Government is prepared to allow tertiary institutions to charge for some post-graduate courses and yet it will not allow them to charge for undergraduate courses. It does seem to be a bit of a nonsense. The Government is reluctant to have private individuals or companies as providers of higher education and it has given no support to the private universities. This in itself would be a marvellous way of increasing the number of places available for tertiary students. It would also be a source of revenue for the nation in that it would open up more places for overseas students. Obviously, with the pressure that we have on our tertiary institutions now, we cannot take all the overseas students who would be prepared to come if there were more places. The other thing which I think is really very unsatisfactory is the fact that those who are attending private sector tertiary education institutions have the Austudy availability closed to them. I think that is quite disgraceful.

I want to canvass a few areas relating to schools. It is a matter of real shame that the Government discriminates against families who choose alternative forms of education. Firstly, there is the constant emphasis on the elitism of non-government schools and people who struggle to get their children into non-government schools constantly feel that they are maintaining their children at these schools and are contributing to the maintenance of the schools almost in spite of some members of the Government who have an ideological block against seeing those schools survive. The Government is continuing to fund them but I think it does need fearless and independent advice through the independent schools on the proposed National Board of Employment, Education and Training. It is very important that the voice of independent schools and the parents who choose that education for their children is heard clearly and effectively by the Government and is not kept at too low a level through bureaucratic processes.

There are other parents who choose not to send their children to school at all. I have several groups in my State who are banding together to give their children their time and devotion over a number of years in approved systems of education in their homes in co-operation with other parents. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that these children are ineligible to receive Austudy. Children who go to government schools are eligible for Austudy and children who go to non-government schools are eligible for Austudy, but children who are educated in schemes such as ACE-accelerated Christian education-by their parents, with devotion and with no claim on the Commonwealth for capital or recurrent funds, are ineligible for any Austudy payments. This is quite incomprehensible. Why should we have two classes of young Australians? Surely Austudy is designed to see that children stay in the education system for the longest possible time. Just because they are being educated by their parents under the approved supervision of the State Minister but without any capital or recurrent funding input from the Commonwealth, they are ineligible for Austudy. I urge the Government to do something about that as a matter of urgency. With the failure of so many of the Government systems around the country, more and more parents are looking around to try to find other ways of having their children educated to the standards that they wish for them. Some of them opt for non-government schools, but many are prepared to devote many years of their lives to seeing that their children receive the sort of education that they desire for them.

I feel that the excessive regulations on non-government schools do not seem to be being looked at by the Government. I know that independent schools and those in the Catholic system are continually looking over their shoulders because they are being bedevilled by the Government breathing down their necks on, first, one set of regulations and then another. I know that an awful lot of time, which costs money in the administration of non-government schools, is spent on satisfying the regulations that come from Canberra.

The tertiary fee has been the subject of debate in this place over the last year, and we are now up to a figure of $263. A number of women at home and on maintenance-I am talking about maintenance from their husbands and not maintenance handed out by this Government by way of the supporting parent's benefit-are looking after children, are dependent upon their former husbands for maintenance and are trying to get qualifications, subject by subject, so that by the time their children are off their hands they are able to be independent of their husbands. Yet they are trying to do a subject a year at a cost, this year, of $263. They are going to acquire very expensive qualifications, if they can afford them at all. But they are usually in a position where their income is so marginal that they have to opt out of tertiary education altogether when they do only one or two subjects a year.

I cannot understand how Senator Susan Ryan, who tells us how much she believes in women doing their own thing and being independent-and I for one, of course, support those things-can in all conscience remain a member of a government in which she was the Minister responsible for introducing this fee and see women in this position having to drop out of tertiary studies because of this iniquitous fee on people who are doing part time courses. Even students who withdraw from a course after teaching has commenced will be liable for this charge.

I want to draw attention also to the fact that I believe we badly need a national centre for research into gifted and talented children. It is something we do not currently have. If we are to have a skills-based work force, I think we have to do better, as I said earlier, in the education of our gifted and talented. A number of centres around Australia would be very interested in establishing a centre of research into gifted and talented children. Yet the Government has not seen fit to fund such a centre. This is something which I want to draw to Minister Dawkins's attention as perhaps something which will fit into his ideological perception of education of Australians, even if it did not fit into the perception of the previous Minister. I welcome the increased grants for the new arrivals element of the English as a second language program.

I want to conclude simply by saying that we cannot continue to wring more and more out of the taxpayers for education. People are not staying on at school long enough and people are not getting into the tertiary institutions that they desire to get into, yet we are not maximising all the resources that this country has at its disposal in the education system, both in non-government schools and in private tertiary institutions. By the use of the taxation system, I believe, we could do very much more to widen the choice for Australians in secondary and tertiary education, to give the diversity and to encourage the excellence which I believe the country desperately needs. The private sector can take some of the responsibility. Despite Senator Haines's drab and dismal picture, private enterprise is showing a willingness and an interest to be involved in education. It is a responsibility which it is willing to take, but it is being prevented from making that commitment and from taking that involvement because of the heavy regulatory hand of this socialist Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately nine education funding Bills whereby the Government has appropriated funds for schools, government and non-government, special purpose programs, technical and further education (TAFE) colleges, universities and colleges of advanced education (CAEs), research, and in relation to overseas students. Because the range of the nine Bills is so wide we have had, from the Opposition particularly, a very wide-ranging debate on various principles and philosophies of education. I do not propose to address most of the points that were made, because they are really expressions of a different policy or a different approach to what the Commonwealth's role in assisting education throughout Australia should be. However, I should point out that the issuing yesterday by my colleague Mr Dawkins of the Green Paper on education will provide the opportunity for the Senate, and for everybody else in the community who is interested in future directions in higher education, to make their views known.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has indicated that it has an open mind on certain aspects of the funding and administration of higher education and will be very interested indeed to receive the views of those who feel they have something constructive to offer. However, it is the case that the Green Paper builds on the dramatic and constructive changes and improvements in education that the Government made during its first four years in office. I would simply draw attention, for example, to the dramatically increased participation by Australian students in the final years of schooling.

When we came to office in March 1983 we did have, indeed, the worst secondary school participation rate in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. That is no longer the case. Now more than half of our young people are finishing secondary school-an achievement of which this Government is proud but, of course, progress about which we are not complacent. We have announced a further target of achieving, by the 1990s, 65 per cent of our young people completing their secondary education and, in addition to that, many more young people at the ages of 16, 17 and 18 engaging in vocational training through our large and ever improving network of TAFE colleges. With that very clear indicator alone, we can see that there have been enormous increases in opportunities for young people in education.

I should point out, too, that the young people who are now participating but who did not prior to our Government's policies being implemented are generally young people from disadvantaged backgrounds. We have known that for some time there were very high rates of participation of students from advantaged backgrounds through to the end of year 12, over 90 per cent in some cases. So the real growth in participation of young people, to the end of year 12, has been largely from disadvantaged students, students from disadvantaged areas and so on, a fact which Senator Macklin, at least, I believe, will be aware of and will welcome.

We have also seen greatly increased participation in higher education in TAFE, but we have never been concerned with numbers alone. We have also been concerned with quality of education, quality of outcomes and relevance. During the first two periods of Labor's administration we have seen, for example, a 50 per cent increase in enrolments by higher education students in areas such as computing, business studies, engineering and so forth, areas where there had been very serious gaps in the labour market and very inadequate provision for the economy. So we have achieved not only a quantitative surge in enrolments in education over the last 4 1/2 years, but also very dramatic quality improvements and improvements in terms of the relevance of the training of young people for the needs of the economy and society.

We have seen other great advances in equity. For example, in 1983 there were only a couple of hundred Aboriginal students enrolled in full time college or university degrees. Now there are almost 2,000. That is a huge increase, again one about which we are not complacent at all because the Aboriginal community is still very seriously disadvantaged in education, but it is progress of which we can be proud.

Senator Newman suggested that the non-government sector had not fared well under the Labor Government. That is wildly wrong, as everybody who is seriously interested in education would know. Under our non-government schools funding policies-needs-based funding policies-the non-government sector has achieved more security and stability of funding than it has ever had, and it has acknowledged this on numerous occasions. Funding to non-government schools is now, as a result of our policies, distributed on a much more equitable basis than it has ever been before. So all sectors of education have benefited enormously from the policies of the first two periods of Labor administration.

There have been other initiatives, such as the export of Australian education services, an initiative which was slow and complex to negotiate in the first phases but which is now flourishing and will return, I believe, this year and in subsequent years a very healthy result for our balance of trade figures. We also have unprecedented close and harmonious relationships with industry. We have a number of mechanisms now which allow direct input of industry into the education process. Similarly, with the Australian Council of Trade Unions there is a much closer relationship and a much more considered sharing of policy ideas. So education now, insofar as the Commonwealth can affect what is happening, is much improved in terms of curriculum content, relevance, direction and so forth.

We have also achieved other initiatives for which sections of the community have been waiting for a very long time, such as those contained in our national language policies-long awaited by the ethnic communities, but also long awaited by those people in the business sector who recognise that we are never going to improve our trading performance in our region substantially unless the study of Asian languages and Asian economies and political systems is much more available within our school and higher education systems. As a result of the early implementation of our national language policies, that objective is starting to be realised. We have also put in place a national strategy for the education of girls which, for the first time, will ensure that the broadening of and improvements in girls' curriculum choices will be a commitment of every State system, with the exception of Queensland-and I hope that that is only a temporary exception-and including the major non-government systems, the Catholic systems and the bodies representing the independent schools.

So in many areas massive changes and improvements have been made. We are now at the stage where we wish to take another very serious look at where we are going in higher education in order to ensure that the improvements that have been made can be the basis for developing a dynamic, flourishing and equitable high standard, higher education system. I hope that the publication of the Green Paper yesterday will bring about constructive discussion rather than tired and stale point-scoring and a rehashing of debates that were well and truly concluded by the end of the 1970s. There is no place, I believe, for harking back to old debates. There is every opportunity now to look at the needs of Australia through to the year 2000 and beyond, from the point of view of both economic growth and social equity. I hope that the debate about education will address itself in those ways.

As I said, there has been a wide-ranging, somewhat philosophical debate on these nine Bills. I am sure that the matters which honourable senators want to take up specifically will be taken up in the committee stage. Before I conclude the second reading debate, I point out that there have been a number of amendments to the second readings, none of which are acceptable to the Government. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The original question was that these eight Bills be now read a second time, and Senator Vanstone has moved second reading amendments with respect to four of the Bills. The first question is that the amendment moved in respect of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1987
Clauses 1 to 8-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a question with regard to clause 8, which deals with liability with regard to charges. We have a concern as to what precisely the Government is attempting to do and how it is attempting to do it. I presume that the exercise is to make an imposition upon students by in some way assisting the institutions to collect the funds which are likely to come from the higher education charge. My concern with that is that what seems to be being introduced here is an enrolment date. An enrolment date is likely to provide much greater restrictions on institutions. I can well imagine that the institutions may find this useful.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the contents of the Green Paper, it seems that the thrust of clause 8 of this Bill is moving in completely the opposite direction. It does not seem to give any discretion to the institution with regard to the charging of that fee. What I want to know is: Is it possible for an institution to enrol a student who fails to pay the fee by the set date for enrolment? One can well imagine many circumstances in which that may not be possible. An institution may wish to provide some additional time for the student to pay. One can also imagine that if, say, there were a break-down of the computer on the relevant day, students would not be able to pay their fees and hence would not be able to be enrolled. I wonder whether the institutions will have any discretion with regard to that fee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can reassure Senator Macklin that his concern is adequately covered. What we are doing in clause 8 is defining a relevant day on which the students become liable for the charge. Institutions have been informed that in each State that date will be the first day of teaching in the institution which is the latest to start teaching, to allow for second round offers and so forth. On that date all students in that State will be liable to pay the charge. If an institution wishes to defer collection of payment in certain circumstances, it may do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 9 (Student fees).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 14, clause 9 to be opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin, your amendment opposes clause 9. It is not strictly an amendment; you are merely opposing the clause.

—Yes. I will explain our position on this and ask some questions of the Minister with regard to the item. If the Opposition parties support the Government and leave the clause in, I will seek to move to my second amendment, which requires the Government to specify courses by regulation, instead of simply by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.
—Are you aware that, if you oppose the clause and it is then passed, you will need leave to move an amendment to a clause that has been passed?

—Yes, Mr Chairman. I want to ask the Minister about some items relating to clause 9 which I think will bring out the reason why we are opposing this clause. I foreshadowed in my speech at the second reading stage a number of concerns about the drafting of the clause. Of course, I am not the only one who has raised those concerns; they have also been raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Sub-clause 9 (2) refers to `a person who possesses educational qualifications', yet the term `educational qualifications' is not defined in the Bill. One assumes from the structure of the clause that it refers to educational qualifications which are precursors in some way to a post-graduate course. However, as the Minister well knows, the variations on that are absolutely enormous. It is possible in Australia to go into a post-graduate course without any formal educational degree having been received beforehand. My concern is with how far and how wide that notion of educational qualifications is to extend. Where a person is permitted to go into a post-graduate course without an undergraduate degree, as is possible, would those educational qualifications be seen as some prior tertiary education qualification, for example, a diploma from a college of technical and further education or a diploma received from an institution in another country which is not formally recognised but for which credit is allowed by the institution? Since we do not have a definition in the Bill, I ask just how broadly that reference to educational qualifications will be interpreted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Macklin's concern about the definition of educational qualifications to be accepted by institutions is that the institutions themselves will determine these matters. In my view it would be most inappropriate for it to be handled in any other way. An institution will decide what qualifications it will require before admitting a student to a course. Those qualifications may be educational; they may be other qualifications such as work experience or other attributes such as Aboriginality in the case of particular arrangements for Aboriginals. Such matters will be determined by the institutions themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Macklin's reference to the comments of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, I have here a reply from Mr Dawkins to Senator Cooney, the Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, pointing out that sub-clauses 9 (2) and 9 (4) are designed to give effect to the Government's Budget decision to relax the legislative prohibition on charging of fees in a limited range of post-basic award courses designed to upgrade vocational skills and income. The courses in question would be specified by the Minister in accordance with the provisions of sub-clauses 9 (1) and 9 (3) and would typically be courses in which all or the great majority of students involved would need to have completed a period of relevant employment or professional experience as a normal condition of entry to the course. In these circumstances, the process of course admission would serve to establish a prima facie liability for payment of a fee and there would be neither a requirement nor a need for an institution to undertake a separate and detailed examination of a student's curriculum vitae and financial circumstances. I am confident that there is no cause for concern about any trespass on the personal rights and liberties of individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that. I wanted to refer to the second issue to which the Minister referred after the item on educational qualifications. My concern here is not primarily with the policy item. I expressed in my speech on the second reading the opposition of the Australian Democrats to that item. What I am trying to get clear now is the legislative base and how it will operate. The Minister has said that the institutions will define educational qualifications. The difficulty of that in sub-clause 9 (2) is that the educational qualifications could very well have been acquired from another institution. We can take the cases of a typical student and an untypical student-two different individuals. A typical student who may undertake a post-graduate course in Australia, as I understand it, is somebody who has done an undergraduate course at the same institution. So the typical student is catered for because the institution is very well able to say, `These educational qualifications are acceptable for the post-graduate course because they are qualifications from our institution'. But what about a student who changes institutions or comes through an atypical line to undertake a post-graduate course? Is the Minister saying that the institution is able to make any judgment it chooses about the educational qualifications it requires for the purposes of sub-clause 9 (2)?
—Yes.

—I must say that that is an extraordinary derogation of the ability of this Parliament to impose a fee. What the Minister is saying is that every institution in Australia will be able arbitrarily to determine what fees it will charge by simply defining what the educational qualifications will be. It is a most extraordinary proposition.

—Senator Macklin has not understood. Certainly, as is the case now, it will be the institutions which will decide which educational qualifications or other qualifications they will accept for the purpose of enrolling a student in a post-graduate course. It is simply not the case that all post-graduate students do their post-graduate work in the institution in which they did their undergraduate work. That happens for some students; it is by no means universally the case. Students go from one institution to another, students come from overseas, and institutions make their judgments about the capacity of the student, given his or her background, to undertake a certain post-graduate course. That has always been determined, and will continue to be determined, by the institutions. The institutions will forward to the Minister for his approval the courses liable for charge, so there is some ministerial control over what is charged for what courses. But in terms of educational qualifications, of course it is a matter for the institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that under clause 9 (1) the Minister will in fact be the person who engages in the exercise. But he will now be relying totally, as the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) has informed us, on a judgment made by the institution as to what in fact will count as an educational qualification under this Bill. Presumably, according to the Minister's comments, anybody who objects will have nothing to stand on because the institution merely has to assert that it is the educational qualification for the purposes of the legislation. I do not see how a person will have any rights, under this particular piece of legislation, to dispute the decision that a fee is to be paid.

SPEECH.PARA: I go on to the next matter, which I find even more difficult to deal with. I refer to the words `has earned a living at any time'. This is the aspect to which the Minister has just responded using the terms of Mr Dawkins's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I thank the Minister for that response. Unfortunately, I think it was beside the point, with regard to both the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report and my objections. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee report in fact focused on what might be a definition of those words.

In seeking to come to grips with this piece of legislation and determine how people would know what their liabilities might be-that is, so that individual Australian citizens might know whether or not they would have to go through this exercise-I went through various Acts to find out whether there was any definition of `earned a living at any time'. The words `has earned a living' are one thing; the words `at any time' are even more extraordinary. There does not seem to be any such definition, at least not that I was able to discover. I would be interested to know whether the Minister could cite a pre- cedent for this particular exercise. In the taxation Acts, of course, we can discover some definitions with regard to what `earning' is. They in themselves are interesting in terms of what might constitute earnings for the purposes of an Act. For example, a judgment in one particular court case held:
The natural meaning of earnings in this context is money gained as the result of labour, work or services.

In many ways that has been a fairly standard definition throughout most of the court proceedings with regard to this particular matter. However, my concern is whether or not the notion of unearned income which is enshrined in the taxation legislation could be said to apply in this particular case. If it does, we may have an anomaly at the very outset, in that, if we apply the unearned income definition from the taxation legislation-that is, money which is earned by way of interest or dividends-a person who is living on interest from investments may be said not to have earned a living. I do not know whether that definition is the one which is proposed, because there is no definition in this Bill, which makes it very difficult to understand what this particular item is about.

In respect of the second part of the words `earning a living', one is led to ask what `a living' might be. I sought some legal advice with regard to how extensive this term might be. The advice I was given is that the words `a living' are qualified by the words `at any time'. `A living at any time' was considered to cover any work which was undertaken for any length of time for which any remuneration was paid. If it is that extensive, what we are now faced with-let us be very clear-is not the type of proposition set out in either the Government's previous paper on higher education or indeed that set out in the explanatory memorandum. We are dealing with a totally different structure. In fact, the explanatory memorandum is grossly inaccurate and misleads the Senate if this provision applies to a person who has worked for any length of time and received remuneration for it. Let us be clear about it: in terms of post-graduate students, we would be talking about every student, because I doubt whether any student gets to post-graduate level without having undertaken at some stage in his or her life-the Bill says `at any time'-some independent work exercise for which he or she is paid. A person could have worked part time serving behind a bar or whatever, as Senator Newman said a little while ago.

So the issue I am picking up here does not apply, as the explanatory memorandum suggests, to somebody engaged in work who has now gone on to a post-graduate course, in the manner of the doctor who practises as a general practitioner while studying to become a specialist-which is the example that is bandied about to get support for this particular proposition. In fact, we are dealing with the possibility of doing what the Fraser Government attempted to do. Once this Bill is passed, I do not see how there could be any legislative prohibition that would present this Government from doing what the Fraser Government attempted to do; that is, imposing a fee on every higher degree course. It would be permissible because there is no way of stopping it by regulation. The Government would simply have to gazette the fee. It could apply to any post-graduate course because, as I have suggested, the reality is that any student who reaches post-graduate level has undertaken some type of work in the past.

The Government may say, `This is not our intention'. I noticed that the Government's response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report referred to `the typical case'. The Government talked about what its intention was. I am not interested in what the Government's intention is; what I am interested in is what the legislation will enable the Government to do. My suggestion is that by some extremely clever drafting exercise the Government has managed to insert in this Bill a measure which the Fraser Government was not able to get through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Macklin had availed himself of the offer made to him to have a briefing on this legislation he would have understood it and would not have gone barking up the wrong tree in such an extravagant fashion. Senator Macklin needs to read clause 9 in the context of the rest of the legislation. The purpose of the clause is to allow institutions to charge fees, with the agreement of the Minister, for retraining or upgrading skills of people who have been in employment. The Minister will be able to examine whether the employment experience of the person really does relate to the course being offered; in other words, whether it is seriously an upgrading or a retraining kind of course. If it is, the Minister will give his agreement to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of whether a student has ever earned any money and so forth, on which Senator Macklin extrapolated with such vigour, is quite irrelevant. It is not a question of whether the student has ever earned any money at all; it is a question of whether the course being undertaken for which the institution is seeking to charge is genuinely an upgrading of the employment experience that the student has already had. So there will be an examination of the relevant employment experience-not of whether the student has ever served behind a bar, worked in a shop, done baby-sitting or anything of that nature, but of whether, for example, a student with a bachelor degree in computer studies who has worked in the computer field for a period will actually have his or her computing skills upgraded by the course proposed. If there is a clear link between the current state of the student's computing skills and the upgrading that would occur under the course proposed, the Minister will agree that the student has, for the purposes of this provision of the Bill, earned his or her living in that way and will therefore benefit from the course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is that in the Bill?
—I believe the explanatory memorandum makes it clear on page 20 that the purpose is--
—Explanatory memorandums are not gospel. They have been known to be wrong.

—In relation to Senator Macklin's concern, I think I have explained the meaning of the clause. I should point out, too, that we will oppose his attempt to have these decisions made by regulation rather than by ministerial agreement. If Senator Macklin's proposal were to succeed, it would be chaotic for the institutions. There is the Senate power of disallowance, and institutions would not know--
—That is precisely the point.

—I do not believe that it is appropriate for the Senate power of disallowance to be used in this case. Why would universities go to the trouble of putting resources into designing these sorts of courses, employing staff to teach them and attracting students to them, if they were not to know, until the Senate had had its deliberations, whether or not they were allowed to charge for them? It simply does not make sense. Also, because of the academic timetable to which institutions need to adhere, in many cases they would need to get the fee from the student before the regulation was disallowed. It would be absolutely chaotic. Institutions would not be able to plan. They would not be able to avail themselves of the new provision. I believe at least the Liberal Party agrees that they ought to be able to develop fee for service courses that have to do with the upgrading of the skills of people who are already trained and who have already worked in employment using those skills in which they were trained. I have now explained to Senator Macklin the meaning of the clause and have indicated that his proposal to remove the Minister's power and replace it by a regulation procedure is not acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I well understand that the Liberal Party agrees with this. At least it was up front and tried to impose fees for higher degree courses when it was in government. The Minister's remarks were an interesting extrapolation of what the Government's intention may be. I am not in a position to be able to dispute that. The Minister might call my attention to any part of the Bill which is relevant to clause 9. I would be happy to look at any other part which may bear on the questions I have raised; that is, an explanation of what it might be to have `earned a living at any time'. Indeed, the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills damning exercise with regard to that piece of drafting is well known to any senator who has read the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 9 is obviously a device to avoid something. Otherwise, there would have been the more normal drafting of that clause regarding remuneration. There are plenty of examples of the way in which such a clause could have been drafted. For example, there are oodles of them in the tax legislation. One could have been lifted straight from that legislation. There is a whole bevy of court cases giving us an explanation of what they are. This is a new and novel approach which is so broad as to be extraordinary. It is breathtaking. My interest is in how this is legislated. The Minister was patronising enough to say that I had not read the Bill. I doubt whether she read clause 9 before she came in here. Clause 9 (1) states:

On application by a university, college of advanced education or institute of tertiary education, the Minister may specify, by notice published in the Gazette, post-graduate courses for the purposes of subsection (2).

All that says is that the Minister may specify, upon application. My first question to the Minister was what would the educational qualifications be and I was told that the institution would decide. So the institution will make the application and it will decide the prior qualifications. What I was then interested in was how we define the words `has earned a living at any time'. The Minister told me that it would be a relevant connection. But relevancy does not appear in that clause. It could have been drafted into the clause. Plenty of Acts-we dealt with one yesterday-contain a relevant connection provision. All the clause states is this:
has earned a living at any time may be charged fees in respect of undertaking . . .

I suggest that my interpretation is correct. What this does is give the Government the legislative power, untrammelled by the Senate-because I understand that the Opposition will not support my amendment to try to get this to be done by regulation rather than gazettal-to impose fees on all higher degree courses. That is what the provision will do. Whether that is the Government's intention or not is beside the point. Once the Government has the power, it has the ability to do that. I suggest that, come next year when the Government will be seeking to impose fees on undergraduate courses, it will not even have to bother to get the legislative power for post-graduate courses; it will already have it.
Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 9-by leave-reconsidered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 14, subclause 9 (1), leave out ``the Minister may specify, by notice published in the Gazette, '', insert ``the regulations may specify''.
(3) Page 14, subclause 9 (3), leave out ``the Minister may specify, by notice published in the Gazette, '', insert ``the regulations may specify''.
I move these amendments for the reasons I proposed in the debate which has just ensued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Macklin's proposition. What has just happened is somewhat disturbing. As a parliamentarian, I am concerned at the approach that has been taken by a number of Government departments and, unfortunately, acceded to by a number of Ministers; that is, government by gazettal. The matter of student fees is a major question of public policy. It has been cause for substantial debate in the community and quite large numbers of petitions about it have been presented to this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is the Government's intention that fees should be charged, I have no objection to that matter coming before the Parliament in a precise and defined manner. But the Government is dealing with the matter here by including a clause, clause 9, entitled `Student fees', which passes over to a university, college of advanced education or institute of tertiary education the right to determine which post-graduate courses are to be regarded as such for the purpose of proposed sub-section (2) concerning the application of fees. At this stage we do not know what those courses will be. In effect we are being asked by the Government to buy a pig in a poke. I will not go along with that. Admittedly, the institutions concerned may not have had the opportunity thus far to determine their policies on what courses will be recommended for gazettal by the Minister and will attract student fees. I understand that. However, the fall-back position explained by Senator Macklin does, in fairness, deserve the support of the Parliament.

As Senator Macklin has said, for the Government simply to gazette those courses and thus enable student fees to be charged for them it is really taking a decision about a major question of public policy out of the hands of the elected representatives of the people and passing it over to the institutions. The Government is virtually rubber-stamping this. The elected representatives will not then be answerable to the students or their parents or whoever pays the fees. If we are going to take unpalatable decisions, let us take them and vote upon them.

The reason I voted against clause 9 was not necessarily that student fees should not be charged in certain circumstances but that, as I understood it, the Government was not going along with a proposition which would enable parliamentary audit and control of what occurs in this area. Therefore, I support what Senator Macklin is proposing. It is a very legitimate proposal. I thought it would be attractive to the Opposition if the Opposition is concerned-as I am sure it is and as a number of members of the Government are-that decisions on major questions of public policy not be taken out of the hands of the elected representatives of the people.
Amendments negatived.
Clauses 10 to 38-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 39 (Additional conditions etc.).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 46, clause 39, leave out subclauses (2), (3), (4) and (5).

I raised in my speech on the second reading the need to give to higher educational institutions flexibility and autonomy with respect to wages. I understand that the Australian Democrats agree with this amendment. Many speakers have referred to the need for universities to be able to compete to attract the staff that they want. With the new private universities, which can pay whatever salaries they like, the pressure on universities to attract high quality staff will be even higher than it is now and it will become more difficult for them to do so. Therefore, they need the flexibility to do that. The passage of this amendment will ensure that they can do it without fear of the Commonwealth reducing their funds by the amount by which the universities exceed the salary payments that are accepted by the Government. Accordingly, the coalition supports this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendment moved by the Opposition. We had circulated an amendment in identical terms. Basically, our concern is to enable the institutions to have the ability to undertake exercises of hiring staff where there is a major disparity between the salaries they are able to pay the staff they seek to hire and those which are paid in comparable jobs in the private sector. In the second reading debate I raised a number of issues, one of which I wish to refer to. It relates to the National Remuneration Centre and the salary for an engineer grade 5, that is, somebody of approximately 40 years of age who has a university degree and 15 years experience. The total cash payment to such a person is in the range of $56,000 to $82,000. It is interesting that the maximum salary of a professor, somebody who certainly has higher qualifications than those applying to the engineer grade 5, is in the $56,000 bracket, unless he happens to be in the medical profession. Interestingly, the Government in its Green Paper accepts the arguments put by the Opposition and the Democrats. At page 61 of the Green Paper the Government talks about the need for increasing salary flexibility. The following sentence sums up the position:

SPEECH.PARA: The obvious demand for more flexible salary packages would be better met by more appropriate and openly recognised methods.

I think the Government in this measure is again seeking to close the door. That is inconsistent with its position. I believe that, if we are attempting to raise the ability of all institutions-and certainly State institutions-to compete, we need to go down that track. This is the first time this particular provision has been inserted. Similar provisions have been inserted in previous Bills with regard to the Academic Salaries Tribunal, but we have never had one with regard to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The reasons for that are obvious. For the first time we have an industrial award at the national level which requires that certain standards be set. I think it is odd that, in acknowledgment of these new industrial conditions, the Government should continue with the proposition and, indeed, expand it to include for the first time the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I think the Government would be better set to press ahead with the recommendations contained in paragraph 8.3 of the Green Paper, and that is what the Opposition's amendment proposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it quite clear that the Government will not accept this amendment. If the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats wish to persist with it, the Bill will be sent back to the House of Representatives. The Opposition parties and the Democrats will then be responsible for preventing institutions receiving the $170m which they will receive next week if the legislation is passed. It seems that both Senator Vanstone and Senator Macklin have been under some serious misapprehensions about the meaning of the provision and the effects of what they are trying to do. Neither was willing to accept a briefing from departmental officers, so they have remained in a state of semi-ignorance. Senator Macklin has claimed that this is the first time the provision has appeared. In fact it was inserted in the legislation in 1980. In relation to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Act was amended last year to make a reference to that. So Senator Macklin is wildly wrong on those points. Senator Vanstone seems to think that there is some application of this provision to salaries that may be paid in private universities. That is also wrong. She mentioned that private universities would not be able to pay what they want. They can pay what they want.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision has been in the legislation since 1980 and it has been applied. It was used by me to penalise institutions who were overpaying vice-chancellors and also in the case of a South Australian institution which consistently paid above the Federal award and still does. The reference to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission came in last year. The desire of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to allow institutions to have more flexibility in what they pay academics is something to which the Government is sympathetic. I should point out that the Government has had that under consideration for a number of years. Those honourable senators who have read the efficiency and effectiveness review, for example, will know that there is a lengthy discussion of the benefits of moving to a more flexible situation. That was one of the first issues which I, as Education Minister, discussed in 1983 with the academic unions. We have certainly had it on the agenda for some time and we believe we will move in that direction.

We are not prepared to take a decision which pre-empts decisions arising from discussion of the Green Paper. The proposal for more flexibility for institutions in regard to payment is put forward in the Green Paper. We will have discussions on that with unions, managers of institutions and the Opposition, if they wish to discuss it with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, you will let the unions keep on running your policies for you.

—Senator Stone has come into this debate very late and, really, he should stick to his jousts with my colleague, Senator Walsh. What I have said is that we have had under discussion for some years the possibility of a more flexible approach for the payment and we will now proceed to bring to some conclusion those discussions after everybody has had an opportunity to comment on the proposal in the Green Paper.

SPEECH.PARA: But this provision remains only for 1988. I predict that it is very likely that next year we will have different and more flexible provisions. Again, I do not want to anticipate the discussion. But for next year the payment should be made under the conditions which have prevailed to date. We cannot suddenly change. There would need to be a policy change. We cannot say, `Okay, the institution in your State, Senator Vanstone, which has persisted in above award payments, can get away with that', whereas other institutions have already been pulled into line. All institutions have been required to abide by Tribunal decisions in order to bring to a conclusion this stage of the policy in 1988.

I should point out that that was not only a policy of our Government but also it was a policy of the Fraser Government. We are still in that mode. The academics are still working under those awards. The changes which we anticipate, and which some people are keen to see, have not yet taken place so it would be inappropriate to make the change this year. What I suggest to the Opposition is that it give serious thought to withdrawing its amendment at this stage in the full knowledge that there is every likelihood that different provisions with regard to flexibility of payment will come into place next year after there has been a response to the Green Paper.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

That the report of the Committee in relation to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987 be adopted and that the Committee have leave to sit again in relation to the other Bills at a later hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order the Senate will now proceed with the debate on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During November 1 was fortunate to have a four-week visit to the People's Republic of China. This is the first opportunity that I have had to speak in the Senate about that visit. On the first 12 days I was a member of the first official delegation from the Liberal Party of Australia to China. That seven-member delegation, of which I had the privilege of being deputy leader, was led by the then Federal President of the Liberal Party, Mr John Valder. This most successful visit demonstrates the close relationship between Australia and China and the bipartisan approach between the two major parties in this country-the potential governments of this country for years to come-in the important relationship that Australia has with China.

SPEECH.PARA: Our magnificent host, the Chinese Association for International Understanding, introduced us to leaders at every point-in Beijing and other cities and in the provinces. We were able to visit Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, Hagnzhou and Guangzhou. I then had the opportunity as an individual and as an Australian Liberal senator to make an extended visit to Kunming and Dali in Yunnan, Chengtu and Chongqing in Sichuan, and Nanjing. It is certainly exceptional to have the opportunity to visit an important country like China for one month and I am grateful to my Senate colleagues for the leave granted to me.

This was my third visit to China in the last three years and on each occasion I have had the benefit of parliamentary overseas travel allowance. In 1985 with my wife, I travelled to a dozen centres in China for a month. In 1986, as deputy leader of the Joint Parliamentary Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee delegation to China, hosted by the National People's Congress, I visited China for one week. In this recent visit I was able to build on the earlier visits.

In the 15 minutes that are available to me, I can refer only to part of the longer speech I would have liked to have made. The Australia-Chinese relationship from 1973 to 1987 has been 15 years of constructive development. The Fraser Government built on the foundations of the Whitlam Government, and the present Hawke Government is building on the constructive developments that took place under Fraser. We have a bipartisan relationship with China and I wish that to continue for a long time. We need to be aware, critical and frank in ensuring that we have only the best and most refined foundations for the many aspects of our relationship.

I continue to be struck by the special quality of China's regard for Australia. We are a small country of 16 million people; China has more than a billion. Australia has a short history of 200 years; China has a vast history of several millenniums. Yet, because of the open door, modernisation, approach of China and our ability in the field of advanced technology, our educational experience and a number of other qualities, it seems that a special relationship has grown between China and Australia. Australia does not offend by having been a major imperial country in the last century. It is not disadvantaged by having been entangled politically in recent times. I believe that this special quality in the Australia-China relationship is unique and we have a great opportunity to work together, to the mutual advantage of our two countries.

In terms of Australia-China trade, in 1986 Australian exports to China totalled $1,587m and imports from China totalled $500m. This 3 : 1 trade balance runs in Australia's favour and I know that the Chinese are keen that we take up more imports from China. But there is no limit to the exports that we can send to China. So China has displaced New Zealand as Australia's third largest market. After Japan and the United States of America, China is the most important trading country for Australia. In 1986 Australia's principal exports to China were wheat, 29 per cent; wool, 21 per cent; iron ore, 13 per cent; and aluminium products, 7 per cent. Wheat exports in 1986 increased by 88 per cent on the previous year, wool increased by 16 per cent and iron ore by 18 per cent. China's principal exports to Australia were clothing, textiles and cotton fabric.

The last decade has abundantly demonstrated China's rejection of the Cultural Revolution period which is universally known as the `Ten lost years'. My first visit to China was in January and February 1968 as the leader of a National Union of Australian University Students delegation to China. We were the last Western group to visit China during the Cultural Revolution and before the doors were completely closed for some years to foreign visits. Therefore, I had a responsibility, especially in the years immediately after that, to continue to think about developments in China.

Certainly, my own assessment of my first visit to China accords rather closely with the title `Ten lost years' and my own articles run somewhat parallel with the current views of the Deng Xiaoping-Zhao Ziyang Government's assessment of the leftists' dominance in China at that time. It was an economic disaster for China; it was a social disaster for China; it was the result of a giant political mistake. As is well known, the schools and universities were closed for a considerable period and there was no contact with the outside world for several years. Most high officials were dismissed from party positions and went to work in the countryside. Most of those leaders have now been reinstated, as has been demonstrated in the case of China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping. We need to be alert to the potential for some minor leftist reassertion in the coming years. Not everything is smooth in political developments in any country, but I am convinced that there will be no repetition of the disastrous Cultural Revolution period.

China is overwhelmingly not an arrogant country. It is a country that does not have a world power aura about it. It does not seek to assert itself, as the United Kingdom had in the earlier part of this century or as the United States and the Soviet Union do now. China has an enormous potential to become a world power. But it has suffered in six ways: foreign exploitation flowing from the opium wars of the 1840s; feudalism; the incursions of the war lords following the early failure of the new republic after 1911; Japan's invasion in north China and China generally from 1937 and then through the World War II years; the civil war that continued to consume China in the 1945-1949 period; and, finally, the self-inflicted 10 lost years of the Cultural Revolution. The end result of those 150 years is that the world is not alert to the present potential for the emergence of China. I do not believe it is sufficiently aware of the humanity, the sensibleness and the consolation of suffering which is evident in China's domestic and international policies.

I believe that China represents a huge human resource, and I place the emphasis on `human'. Its international policy again and again has the touchstone of non-arrogance, of a country emerging from a century and a half of suffering. In Australia we should think about not only the current year or the next five years, but the next 50 years, and see what historical precedents there are over recent centuries for the emergence of a country with so vast a human resource to escape the 150 years of suffering that I have outlined. The emergence of China, in partnership with Australia and the other Pacific rim countries such as Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Canada and the United States, will ensure that the pacific will become the economic centre of gravity for this world in the twenty-first century. I believe that the future lies more and more with an increased Chinese influence in our region, and that region is this important area of the Pacific.

The turning point in China came after Mao Tse-tung's death in September 1976. In October 1976 the Gang of Four were arrested and Deng Xiaoping was restored to his former posts. The Senate will be aware that he was, as early as the 1930s, General Secretary of the Party. He has made as large a contribution towards China's development over the last 50 years as did Mao Tse-tung, Chou En-lai and a number of other leaders. His resumption of his post in 1977 led on to, if you like, getting the numbers. The turning point was at the third plenary session of the eleventh party congress in December 1978. From December 1978-I note that this was a few months after my own election to this Senate-China concentrated all of its efforts on modernisation. There has been no turning back for these past nine years.

The thirteenth party congress, which was held in Beijing the week before the Liberal Party delegation went to China, further consolidated that line of an open-door policy, an orientation to market economics and a complete resolve towards modernisation. The Central Committee elected by the congress met for the first time on Monday, 2 November, the day before our delegation arrived in Beijing. The highlights are well known. Zhao Ziyang was given a pre-eminent leadership position as General Secretary of the Party and as First Vice-Chairman of the Military Commission of the Party's Central Committee. He is aged 68 and has worked in the core leadership group for the last seven years. His experience in the transformation of Sichuan early in the last nine years and his leadership nationally have been the platform from which he has emerged as the successor to Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader.

The standing committee of the Political Bureau, also elected on that occasion, has five important leaders, all of whom are committed to the policy line that I have outlined. The fourth position happens to be filled by Hu Qili, a person whom, with my Foreign Affairs and Defence colleagues, I was able to meet a year ago. We engaged in our conversations in Beijing most happily, refreshingly and intelligently. I certainly wish the leadership of China every success in achieving the goals of modernisation of China.

One other important aspect of the thirteenth party congress was the addressing of some theoretical issues and the reference to China being in the primary stage of socialism. I observe that addressing the theoretical basis of the party is an important and essential aspect that will give coherence to the achievement of consolidation and stability in the policy line that China has set for itself. I observe that Hu Qili has been given the pre-eminent responsibility for taking these theoretical issues in an education campaign to every area of China.

I am an Australian Liberal; I am not a Marxist. I believe that the Marxist analysis is flawed; it was last century and it is this century. However, the gaining of national sovereignty and the modernisation of China has been undertaken by a Marxist party. I can only recognise that that party is now enormously flexible, pragmatic and objective in determining the best way forward for China. There are two fundamentals in China to which I will refer when I speak on the adjournment later on this evening.
