SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of the Opposition to the Australian National Airlines Amendment Bill 1987. The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. However, I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) placing Australian Airlines at a $4.9 million per year competitive disadvantage with its major competitor, Ansett Airlines; and

(b) failing to defer this measure until the Advisory Group on Australian Airlines has reported to the Government in March, 1988, on Australian Airlines' future capital requirements, especially considering that the Advisory Group's Terms of Reference include a specific reference to superannuation.

The main effect of this Bill will be to burden Australian Airlines with an additional yearly bill of at least $4.9m. The legislation will force Australian Airlines to pay back $4.9m to the Commonwealth for the 900 employees who opted to remain in the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. There will be increases in later years, depending on actuarial assessments. I think one could confidently expect that, with the fallout in the stock exchange this year, that figure of $4.9m has already increased substantially. This in itself will be a tremendous handicap for Australian Airlines and it will also provide its competitor with more competitive edge. The airline has one major problem-the lack of money. This has been alluded to by, I think, Senator Evans on a few occasions.

Any money taken off Australian Airlines is money it cannot use in competing for its share of the airline market in Australia. The airline desperately needs substantial injections of capital if it is to be able to compete on the national market. It needs at least $400m over the next three years if it is going to be able to offer similar services to its competitor, Ansett Airlines of Australia. The airline has many problems and many of them, of course, stem from management problems. The only way the airline's problems are going to be solved is by some form of privatisation, and this should have been done years ago. The previous coalition Government was fully aware of this and in 1981 had legislation in place to convert Australian Airlines into a company-to incorporate it. But the legislation was repealed by the Hawke Government in 1984. Now the Hawke Government is introducing legislation geared to privatise Australian Airlines. This is another example of the multitudinous policy about-turns and back flips for which this Government has become famous. The Government is only now admitting the huge mistake it made in repealing that legislation. That mistake has cost us untold millions of dollars and it has also has the effect of keeping Australian Airlines dramatically behind its competitor in equipment and technology.

The Government is playing internal politics in not deferring this measure until the Advisory Group on Australian Airlines has reported to the Government next March and is jumping the gun on its advice. The advisory group is made up of the Chairman and Commissioner of Australian Airlines, a member of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, a leading left-wing member of the Australian Labor Party and the Secretary of the Department of Transport and Communications. The choice of members of the advisory group is designed to ensure that the various interest groups who would normally object to privatisation will be locked into the Government's intention to eventually privatise the airline.

The airline, as is the case now, is unable to operate efficiently under the constraints of being a statutory authority. Examples of this are well known, but to name a few: it does not have the same lending ability of an incorporated company; it does not have the same borrowing ability; and it is hampered in acting quickly and competitively in a commercial sense. For example, it needs to be flying the A320 Airbuses, but it just cannot afford to buy them. Australian Airlines is confronted with an acute financial crisis as it prepares for the new challenge of competition which will arise with the termination of the two-airline agreement in 1990. While the Government has correctly signalled the deregulation of domestic air transport, it has not followed the logic through to privatisation. This must also be done.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE 1986-87

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 24 September.
Motion (by Senator Richardson) proposed:
That the Committee approves the Statement, for the year 1986-87, of the Heads of Expenditure and the amounts charged thereto, pursuant to section 36a of the Audit Act 1901.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion which the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) has moved, not because I wish to direct particular criticism to the Government in relation to the amounts being proposed, but rather to draw attention to the importance of this particular head of expenditure. In doing so, I wish to draw attention to some interesting and, I think, significant developments in relation to this area of the Budget and to appropriations over the years. As all honourable senators are well aware, what used to be called the Advance to Treasurer, and is now called the Advance to the Minister of Finance, is a key element in the total budgetary process because, in effect, it provides the government of the day, the Executive, with a contingency provision which will allow the Executive, subject to the prospective and, certainly, post-dated nature of scrutiny of the Parliament, the authority to deal with unforeseen circumstances that may arise in the course of the financial year and which cannot be provided for in the appropriations that are brought before the Parliament in the Budget itself or, for that matter, in the Supply appropriations.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the very special nature of this appropriation, there was for many years a very strong view within the financial arena that these provisions should be extremely limited, and that very little leeway should be given to the Executive to undertake spending which had not been specifically provided for by the Parliament-in other words, which had not been specifically provided for within the Appropriation Bills or otherwise under special appropriations. Over the years, I have to say, that view has been somewhat eroded and, I think, in some ways that is to be regretted. I do not wish to exaggerate the importance of that development, but I think, nevertheless, it has been a development which has occurred in a very gradual way and which needs to be kept under close review.

Perhaps I could mention for the information of the Committee-and I have not gone back perhaps as far as I might have done-that in 1979-80 the appropriation the Advance to the Minister for Finance under Appropriation Bill (No. 1) was $125m and under Appropriation Bill (No. 2) it was $100m. Without wearying the Committee with a recitation of the totality of the figures over the years, we now have a situation where in the Budget of this year we have an appropriation of $170m for Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and $140m for Appropriation Bill (No. 2). I seek leave to have the table of figures incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. Equally of some significance perhaps is, of course, the experience which successive governments have had with their spending under these heads of appropriation. Generally speaking, I think with some qualifications, it is fair to say that as the size of the appropriation for the Advance to the Minister for Finance has increased, so has the use of that appropriation increased. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. I make that point and incorporate those figures because it is, I think as a matter of experience, the case that when the Executive and the departments which serve it have at their disposal an appropriation such as that to the Advance to the Minister for Finance, they are not as closely limited in the bringing forward during the course of a financial year of new spending proposals as they would otherwise be. That is so obvious as hardly to need stating. We do find, therefore, that the Advance to the Minister for Finance tends to be fairly fully utilised, whatever the size of that advance may be. The figures that I have now had incorporated will, I think, bear out that comment.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, I think-I will not foreshadow remarks; I will not repeat remarks now which I will perhaps make later this afternoon when we discuss the paper that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will table on the Forward Estimates-we have a situation where, for the purpose of those Forward Estimates, the Minister is now in fact beginning to incorporate in them contingency provisions which take account of this expenditure creep, or decision-making creep, so to speak, throughout the course of the financial year and which I think needs to be kept closely under review by the Parliament.

So much for that particular aspect of my remarks, Mr Chairman. I want to say one other thing. I am aware that increasingly-and this is understandable, because of the great burdens which Ministers do carry-it has been necessary to delegate to officials the authority to make decisions in relation to the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. For example, there are two major categories in the advance under Appropriation Bill (No. 1)-there is in fact a third, but for the purpose of these remarks I will concentrate simply on the first two under division 310. The first is to enable the Minister for Finance to make advances-I am referring to page 88 of Public Account Budget Paper No. 2-that will be recovered during the financial year in respect of expenditure that is expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government-that is to say, in relation to decisions that are taken, say, by the Government during the course of the year and which will later in the year be the subject of additional appropriations.

For that purpose, or at least for the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for advances of that category, I am informed that today a first assistant secretary-no doubt the relevant first assistant secretary of the Department of Finance-has unlimited authority to approve expenditure under that category. I am also advised that, indeed, even an officer at the class 11 level of the Public Service which, while a very responsible level, of course, is nevertheless not even a position within the Senior Executive Service of the Public Service, is delegated authority to approve expenditure under this category-that is, the first category I am referring to of division 310-under this advance of up to $5m, which is not an insignificant sum.

It is true that under the second category, which I will come to now, the delegations are smaller. The second category is to enable the Minister for Finance to make money available for expenditure, firstly, that the Minister is satisfied is expenditure that is urgently required and, secondly, was unforeseen until after the last day on which it was practicable to include appropriation for the expenditure in the Bill before the introduction of the Bill into the House of Representatives and, of course, particulars of which will afterwards be submitted to parliament. In relation to that more significant, in many ways I suppose, category of expenditure, the delegation to a first assistant secretary in the Department of Finance is in fact limited in the first place to $500,000 or half a million dollars. Limitations also apply further down the line of delegation. That, of course, is entirely appropriate.

I want to say that in the short space perhaps of a decade or so-and it is a short space in the life of a nation-we have seen the usage of the appropriation in what, as I said, was originally the Advance to the Treasurer and is now the Advance to the Minister for Finance, move from a point at which previously, I believe I am correct in saying, no expenditure would have been approved under this head other than by the Minister, to a point where today we have delegated authority to officials-reasonably senior officials, but nevertheless, not even, as I said, Senior Executive Service Officials-of up to $5m and, of course, unlimited delegation authority for more senior officials than that.

I will not delay the Committee further. I wish simply to place on record that I think this particular Advance to the Minister of Finance is of very considerable constitutional significance because it is one of the areas of the Appropriation Bills where the Parliament, with full knowledge, in effect surrenders temporarily its authority to the Executive to commit expenditure even though details of such expenditure have not been put down in detail in the Appropriation Bills. It does so of course, subject to safeguards, reporting and so on. Nevertheless, it is a delegation by the Parliament to the Executive-in this case the Minister for Finance-which needs to be kept under very close surveillance because it has a capacity to grow and to provide the Executive with a further capability for acting in a manner which could give rise to concern. It needs to be kept under constant review.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table supplementary explanatory memorandum No. 3. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 has previously been dealt with by the chamber. As is usual with these miscellaneous provisions Bills, the opportunity has been taken to tidy up a number of pieces of legislation. In fact, 87 Acts have been amended and 24 repealed. In the course of that debate, the Opposition was successful in securing the deletion from the principal Act of the amendments which related to the Acts Interpretation Act and the Audit Act. These were subsequently referred to committees for investigation and report. The Government having had the benefit of that investigation and report, amendments were subsequently moved in the House of Representatives and these amendments are the amendments which are now before the chamber and which the Opposition does not oppose.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, amendments have been made in respect of the Acts Interpretation Act and the Audit Act. An opportunity has been taken to make certain minor amendments under the National Measurement Act to require the use of metric units of measurement in real estate transaction-a weighty matter which, from recollection, must have taken 21 or 22 years to get around to.

Nevertheless, the principal House of Representatives amendments relate to the Acts Interpretation Act and to the Audit Act. The amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act seek to allow for more flexibility in the commencement of regulations. This matter was considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The Committee recommended certain changes which the Government has accepted. The Committee supports the changes that the Government has made. I turn to the Audit Act. I know that my colleague Senator Watson wishes to address some remarks to an underlying principle in relation to the way in which the Government is generally dealing with the oversight and scrutiny of the expenditure and examination of the Government's financial transactions in terms of both the scrutiny being imposed by the Auditor-General and the scrutiny being imposed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The indication was given in the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that amendments to the Audit Act were deleted when this Bill was first before the Senate. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has examined these amendments and reported favourably upon them. The Minister claims that the base gain of the amendments is to improve the efficiency of the Commonwealth's financial administration. As I say, Senator Watson will be addressing some remarks to this matter. The Committee has before it the House of Representatives amendments and, as I have said, the Opposition does not oppose them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has before it for consideration a number of amendments which have been agreed to by the House of Representatives. I want to take this opportunity to issue something of a warning. I think it was most unfortunate that the Government used the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 as a vehicle to introduce some pretty substantial changes in relation to audit. Because these changes are very significant, a much cleaner and more open approach should have been adopted and a separate Bill introduced. I also take some umbrage in relation to an explanatory memorandum which was issued by the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen. I wish to remind the Committee of the importance and particularly the independence of the office of Auditor-General which is fundamental to the Westminster system. In this explanatory memorandum the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The involvement of the Auditor-General in the issuing of appropriate amounts, which is, essentially an administrative process by the Executive Government, is also inappropriate and contrary to modern concepts of the independence of the Auditor-General.

I take exception to that because quite the opposite is the case. In fact, I take a very dim view of any changes in the role and functions of the Auditor-General and the Australian Audit Office, especially when they are dressed up in such terminology as `inappropriate' in the modern bureaucratic language. I even become more suspicious when the Government infers that it is a hindrance to the executive government to have the independent statutory office of the Auditor-General involved in this way.

In my involvement as Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I am becoming extremely concerned at the number of government agencies and authorities that are writing letters to us and saying, `Our investigations are causing a hindrance to our operations'. Really, this smacks at the very heart of the parliamentary control over expenditure. Here we are allowing another situation, albeit a very small one, dressed up in language such as `inappropriate'. As I said, the inference is that this is a hindrance to executive government. This is another manifestation of the fact that the Government is getting a little bit sick and tired of any sort of scrutiny of its financial dealings and is using all sorts of pressures.

I believe that this really is another small example of the Auditor-General's independence being undermined, especially in regard to his relationship with the Executive. The functional independence of the Auditor-General, in fact, has been a matter of debate for some years now. That debate seems to have accelerated in the last six months. I acknowledge that the Auditor-General has canvassed this issue in successive reports. On 4 October 1984, the then Auditor-General, Mr Brigden, suggested that it was:
timely to question whether the independence of the Auditor-General and the Australian Audit Office from the executive arm of government is not more apparent than real.

That is a very strident criticism. Yet this Government, I believe, has given scant recognition to the subtlety of the problem, choosing instead to answer rigidly, as Senator Walsh did recently in an answer to my colleague Senator Stone, who is in the chamber at the moment. He responded to Senator Stone in the following terms:
Every publicly funded agency or department or unit, including the Parliament, will have its appropriations set by the executive government.

I wish to emphasise that the point this Auditor-General was actually at pains to make in his annual report seems to have eluded the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Government. I believe it is possible to recognise the need to endow the Auditor-General with functional independence while simultaneously exerting indirect influence on the independence of the Australian Audit Office through pressure on resources. Nevertheless, this pressure on resources of the Australian Audit Office by the Executive has the potential to be damaging to the traditional relationship that has existed between the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General. The current Auditor-General, Mr Monaghan, said:
The practicality seems to be that . . . the pressure on the Department of Finance to achieve expenditure savings have ended the modus vivendi that I formerly perceived.

Perhaps I could translate the Latin into modern terminology. The Government's insistence on trying to achieve all forms of savings using the Department of Finance has changed the relationship that the Auditor-General previously enjoyed. That is a very serious indictment.

I acknowledge that a number of other countries have already moved to try to overcome this problem. I urge this Government to act in a similar way to which other enlightened governments are moving rather than taking this stringent position. For example, in the United Kingdom, the parliamentary body, the Public Accounts Committee, recommends the level of funding for the National Audit Office. This is one avenue open to us. Those who have read the Auditor-General's report would realise, however, that Australian conditions may be better suited to an alternative arrangement where a parliamentary committee would review funding for the Australian Audit Office. Whatever happens, I think we have to acknowledge this Government is making attacks on the resources of the Australian Audit Office. It is attacking the Auditor-General's independence. By allowing this amendment to go through, we are giving greater power to the Executive and hindering the wide operations of the Australian Audit Office. I believe that this Parliament should take up claims that the office is a hindrance to the executive government. The independent statutory office of Auditor-General should not be involved in this way. This is a serious issue.

I reiterate my earlier comment that, in future, I think this Opposition will have to reject certain statute law miscellaneous provisions Bills where they contain substantive amendments such as the ones that are now before us in respect of the Australian Audit Office. I think in future we should not be part of that because it is an abrogation of the generally accepted principle that only minor changes of largely a technical nature should be included in this sort of legislation. In future I think the Opposition will be insisting that there be a separate Bill dealing with such important issues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Sitting suspended from 1.41 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and concerns this Government's discrimination over the direction of the allocation of financial assistance to industry in Australia. Is the Minister aware that the livestock industry contributes $95m each week and $4.9 billion each year to the Australian economy? Is the Minister aware also that this industry has recently committed more than $30m of industry funds towards residue testing of cattle? Given this Government's contribution of $500m to the steel industry, $300m to the motor vehicle industry, and $40m to the coal industry to prop up the New South Wales Government at the forthcoming election, will the Minister inform the House why the Government has chosen to discriminate against the livestock industry by imposing a retrospective levy of 15c per head for additional testing under the national residue survey, the direction of which has not been fully discussed with industry?
—Why do you hate farmers?

—If I might deal with Senator Boswell's interjection first, I certainly do not hate farmers; I like them. It is just a pity that they do not have better representatives in this place than they have. That is the tragedy for farmers in this country.
—Don't you people over there represent farmers? Is that what you are saying?
—No, I am not saying that at all. I am just saying that it is a pity that they do not have better representatives than they have. Senator Boswell claims to represent them.
—An interesting slip: the Labor Party does not represent farmers.

—We are doing all right; do not worry about that. I am not able to agree or disagree with the various figures that Senator Bjelke-Petersen put to me in her question, except those that relate to my portfolio. I shall certainly make some inquiries to ascertain whether those figures are correct and obtain a more detailed answer to her question. If the figures mentioned by the honourable senator for rural industries are as inaccurate as the ones she mentioned for manufacturing industry, I think we will need to do a little work and it might take a while to get an answer to her question. This Government has not allocated $500m to the steel industry. It has not spent $300m on the motor vehicle industry. According to my recollection, this Government has not spent $40m on the coal industry. Insofar as those matters of detail can be checked, I will certainly do that. However, that is the position with regard to the figures the honourable senator mentioned. I shall make some further inquiries of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, to whose representative in this place the honourable senator's question might more appropriately have been directed. However, I shall certainly ensure that the honourable senator obtains an answer to her question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of publicity which the Press has accorded to Tuesday's Caucus decision on the proposed clampdown by the member for Canning, Mr George Gear, on taxpayers claiming rebates for their attendance at Australian conferences which are held overseas? Is the Minister aware that it has been alleged that many of these conferences are used by many to avail themselves of an overseas holiday which is subsidised by the Australian taxpayer? Will the Minister indicate whether the tax changes proposed by Mr Gear are receiving widespread community support?
—Perhaps he can also tell us what he told Caucus about the superannuation provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did indeed see on the front page of the Australian Financial Review an article dealing with George Gear's motion. Only the week before, I think it was, I saw an article about George Gear on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald. It must be a long time since a backbencher from Western Australia had articles written about him on the front pages of those two newspapers in the one month. I think that report also mentioned that the move had the support of both the Treasurer and me and, I expect, every member of the Caucus. Indeed, I think the motion was carried unanimously. That is what one would expect from the Australian Labor Party-that it would show unanimous opposition to any form of tax evasion or tax avoidance. Indeed, that principle has been applied in government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is too early to judge what effect this move will have on revenue, although some people believe it will be very substantial. I think it will have widespread community support outside the Labor Party, with a couple of exceptions: Dr Bruce Shepherd's faction of the doctors' union, for example, will probably oppose it, and I expect the Federal Opposition also will oppose it. I do not know whether that was the tenor of Senator Stone's earlier interjection as I was about to answer the question, but it certainly would not surprise me if the Federal Opposition opposed this move. The Federal Opposition is still in favour of taxpayer subsidised boozy lunches, tax deductible Mercedes motor vehicles, the payment of pensions to millionaires, and so on. At the same time the mountebanks who are in favour of all these rorts and lurks talk about fiscal responsibility and cutting government expenditure.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELLIOT-NEWCASTLE WATERS ABORIGINES PROGRESS AND HOUSING ASSOCIATION INC.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware that the Elliot-Newcastle Waters Aborigines Progress and Housing Association Inc. of Elliot in the Northern Territory, which for some time has been extended credit by suppliers on the basis that recompense is made when the Association receives its periodical funding from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, has had that government funding withdrawn, leaving outstanding debts of more than $200,000? Is the Minister further aware that creditors have been told that the assets of the Association cannot be sequestrated because they were purchased with government funds and as such are proscribed assets? Will the Minister take steps to ensure that the creditors who extended credit in good faith will be paid?
—I have no information on that matter raised by Senator Bishop in her question.
—That is very disappointing.

—No notice was given of the question and, as the Senate will understand, the question relates to the apparent collapse of a particular association which has been funded with Commonwealth moneys and which has left substantial debts. Its creditors are obviously distressed because they cannot regain any moneys owed by the Association. I shall take the matter up with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and ensure that an answer is provided as speedily as possible.

—I ask a supplementary question. If, when the Minister refers the matter to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the answer is in the negative, that is, that the Association's debts will not be paid, will the Minister then take steps to inform members of the business community of the consequences they face if they issue credit facilities to organisations whose assets can be proscribed?

—I undertake to ascertain whether any general principle can be gleaned from the particular instance that Senator Bishop has brought to the attention of the Senate and whether it warrants the sort of response that she suggests.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Following the inscription of Ayers Rock (Uluru) National Park on to the World Heritage List yesterday, further cementing Senator Richardson's standing as the most outstandingly successful Minister for the Environment since Federation and in the history of the world as we know it, has the Minister received information from Paris as to whether stage 2 of Kakadu National Park has now also been placed on the List and whether the World Heritage Committee had been pressured not to inscribe stage 2?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for his careful and accurate observations. Following the inscription of Uluru National Park on to the Register of the World Heritage List, it has now been announced that as of last night stage 2 of Kakadu National Park has also been inscribed. I think that is great news, not just for the environmental movement around the country but also for almost all Australians, and certainly for the traditional owners in Kakadu who have been so supportive of the listing for such a long time. Stage 2 comprises the catchment of the Wildman and West Alligator Rivers and also the downstream section of the South Alligator Rivers. It is, of course, outstanding in its own right and it is an area of magnificent Australian national heritage. It covers an area of approximately 13,000 square kilometres, so it is a huge tract of land. I think it is, undoubtedly, the most famous part of the country.

ANSWER.PARA: It is extraordinary, therefore, that the decision made last night to inscribe it on the World Heritage List should have been opposed by the Northern Territory Government. It is extraordinary that the World Heritage Committee should be faced with the spectacle of a cowboy politician from the Northern Territory spreading misinformation on what can be described as little more than a crude junket or just another trip. The eminent members of that Committee must have found his antics and misinformation a little more than they could handle. I think the most important thing to note for the future is that the Committee once again commended the Australian Government for its initiative and for the work that it had done. It also commended us for taking measures to stop mining in the park. It has, I might say, encouraged the Government to include more of Stage 3 on the World Heritage List at some future time. That matter will be considered by the Government over the coming months and years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. The Minister will recall that last year the honourable member for Moreton, Mr Donald Cameron, requested details from all Government Ministers of all overseas trips made during 1984-85 by the employees of their respective departments and all statutory authorities. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the information provided by the then responsible Minister in relation to overseas trips made by officers of the Australian Electoral Commission was complete and accurate?
—I am a bit miffed that Senator Short did not give the obligatory praise to a Minister before he asked the question.
—Next time.

—Yes, next time. The conclusion that Senator Short draws in his question is accurate. The information given in answer to a question on notice has, on further examination, been proved to be inaccurate. We are talking about the very early life of the Australian Electoral Commission when two of its officers visited New Zealand to coincide with the holding of the 1984 New Zealand election. This study visit was intended to check features of the New Zealand electoral organisation for the benefit of the new Electoral Commission being established here. The understanding of the Commission officers was that, under Public Service conventions, the visits by Australian Public Service personnel to Papua New Guinea and New Zealand were not regarded as overseas travel-certainly not in the same terms as visits to the United States of America, Europe, et cetera. Of course, for a person based on the east coast of Australia this may be understandable in terms of distance. The bill for the study visit for the two officers, incidentally, came to $3,222. However, I agree that those two trips, under any sort of criteria, should have been listed in that particular response. The conclusion that I draw from their omission is that I believe the officers are being truthful when they say that they misunderstood the terms of overseas travel. I suggest that if I were an official of the Public Service I would hardly try to cheat on this matter and then end up in Dunedin or Christchurch. That is not really the sort of junket that I would look forward to.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to comments made by Mr Howard on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) program this morning that the Government is imitating Mr Howard's proposals in the economic area. Can the Minister tell the Senate in what areas the Government is imitating Mr Howard's proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hear Mr Howard on the ABC this morning claiming that the Government was imitating him. No matter how hard I try, I cannot think of any example that confirms that but I can think of a huge number that show that we are certainly not imitating Mr Howard. For example, the Government is not running a wages policy, as Mr Howard did in 1981-82, that produced a wages explosion of 13 per cent in the first year and 14 per cent in the second year. We are not running a loose fiscal policy which has 8 per cent real growth built into the first year of the Forward Estimates or 6 per cent real growth built into the Forward Estimates, as Mr Howard ran for the last two years when he was Treasurer. We are not grovelling before the former Premier of Queensland. We do not make $1,500m worth of arithmetic mistakes when presenting a Budget. We are not presiding over 11 1/2 per cent inflation, as Mr Howard did, and 10 1/2 per cent unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: We do not intend to bring back the free boozy lunch or the tax deductible Mercedes or to pay pensions to millionaires, as Mr Howard would have us do. There are no mountebanks on the Government side who would seduce the people into believing-if they could-that living standards can be immediately improved with a mixture of voodoo supply-side economics and tax cuts which would deliver instant increases in living standards for all. In other words, far from imitating Mr Howard, this Government is doing all the things that Mr Howard said he would not do and we are not doing all the things that Mr Howard said he would do. In short, we are running a responsible fiscal policy. It has taken us five years to clean up the mess that John Howard left behind on the expenditure side of the Budget. We have done that. It took us a bit less than five years to clean up the taxation side of the Budget. We did that last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. Given the public concern regarding the use of 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D, what efforts has the Federal Government made to encourage State governments to adopt uniform measures designed to control the use of these chemicals? Further, has the Federal Government considered or will it consider banning the importation of 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D into Australia?

—Senator McLean did pay my office the courtesy of giving notice of his question. We are seeking information from the office of the Minister for Community Services and Health. It is not yet available, but I will make it available to Senator McLean as soon as I receive it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. I refer him to the answer he gave me on Tuesday, 24 November 1987, in which he explained that people convicted of Commonwealth crimes and given custodial sentences were imprisoned in institutions controlled by the States or the Northern Territory. Given the Commonwealth's use of those gaols, does the Commonwealth take note of what deaths take place in them? If so, can he provide statistics of the number of deaths that have occurred in the gaols of each of the States and the Northern Territory? Can he state in respect of each jurisdiction the numbers of deaths resulting from suicides, murders, accidents and natural causes?
—This will be pretty good without notice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney did do me the courtesy of letting me know that I might be answering a question along these lines. Unfortunately, I am not able to give the comprehensive answers for which he is looking, but I can go some of the way. His first question was: Given the Commonwealth's use of gaols in State and Northern Territory jurisdictions for Commonwealth prisoners, does the Commonwealth take note of the deaths that take place in those gaols? The answer is that the Commonwealth does not keep a comprehensive running record of deaths taking place in gaols in those various jurisdictions. However, in 1984, at the request of the Conference of Correctional Ministers, the Australian Institute of Criminology carried out a survey of deaths in prisons. The period surveyed, once it was undertaken, was 1980 to 1985 inclusive. The results, published by the Australian Institute of Criminology in 1986, were entitled A National Study of Deaths in Australian Prisons, over the name of Messrs Hatty and Walker. That is available under that title.

ANSWER.PARA: The second question was: Can the Minister provide now or at a later date statistics of the number of deaths that have occurred in the gaols of each of the States and the Northern Territory? When Senator Cooney reads the documentation he will note that table 1, page 13 of that survey gives details of the number of all deaths in prisons for the period 1980 to 1985 by State and Territory and the rate per 1,000 prisoners per year, and the number of suicides during the same period and the rate per 1,000 prisoners per year. I can table a copy of that. Table 2, page 14 of that survey provides details of all deaths and suicides and the sex of each prisoner concerned, and I can table that also.

Senator Cooney also asked whether I could state, in respect of each jurisdiction, the number of deaths resulting from suicides, the number from murders, the number from accidents and the number from natural causes. Senator Cooney will find that on table 3, page 15 of the survey there is provided details of all deaths-the numbers and percentages by mode of death, jurisdiction and sex. I table the various documents.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WATERSIDE WORKERS FEDERATION OF AUSTRALIA: PRODUCTIVITY RATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the closure tomorrow of a shipping terminal in Rozelle, Sydney, as a result of inefficient work practices, mainly by members of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia? Does the Minister agree that the productivity rate of between four and five containers a day is not only appalling in comparison with 10 to 12 in Melbourne, but even more appalling in comparison with terminals in other countries which have a productivity rate at least double that of the best terminal in Australia? Does the Minister consider that members of the Waterside Workers Federation from the Rozelle terminal who are to be returned to the waterside labour pool are entitled to any part of the productivity-related wage rise which is being negotiated at present for the members of this union, considering that their productivity rate has caused the closure of the terminal and the loss of jobs for other workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the closure to which Senator Hamer refers, but let me say that these things are likely to happen if the productivity performance of a company is as bad as he describes. However, I am not in the position of apportioning moral blame on the basis of ignorance. Productivity is an issue which in part relates to the labour force and in part relates to management. It is impossible to make assessments on the broad brush basis that the honourable senator does, which apportions moral blame in the way in which he would like to. I know companies in this country which had an appalling productivity record in 1981, for example, and which have a very high level of productivity now. That change has been accomplished largely by management direction and initiative, in terms of both investment and industrial relations policy and a wide range of issues which I believe are the responsibility of good managers.

ANSWER.PARA: It is said that Australian companies often look to Japan as a model of productivity. That productivity has not been attained simply by a particular Japanese version of the work ethic; it has been attained by a variety of factors, and prominent and foremost amongst those factors would be good and innovative management. I will certainly try to find out about the Rozelle terminal and see what the Minister's views are about it. Perhaps it was doomed anyway; I do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to chart 1 on page 6 of the Forward Estimates. Can the Minister provide any additional information to assist in interpretation of the chart, in particular information relevant to the Government's efforts to control the growth in outlays and to changes in the patterns of those outlays?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can supply some more information. I understand that for technical reasons Hansard cannot print graphs. It is a pity because, if that were not the case, I would seek leave to have this graph incorporated in Hansard, because it tells us more about the fiscal responsibility of this Government as compared to its predecessor than many pages of text or narrative could do. It shows at various periods over the last six years the immediate outlook, that is, the outlook in the next financial year, for government expenditure, on the basis of no changes to policy. It commences with the 1981 Budget and depicts graphically the expenditure on a no policy change basis for the next three years. It shows that, had there been no change to policy in 1981, outlays in real terms would have gone up by 6 per cent-that is, a 6 per cent real increase in government spending.

ANSWER.PARA: When the 1982 Budget came down, government expenditure got even more out of control. Had there been no policy changes following the 1982 Budget, government expenditure in real terms would have gone up by 8 per cent. Not only was John Howard presiding over runaway growth in government expenditure in his last couple of years as Treasurer, but it was actually getting worse. The 6 per cent real growth rate in his 1981 Budget was superseded by an 8 per cent real growth rate, on a no policy change basis, in his 1982 Budget. The succeeding lines or curves then show a not so gradual-in fact a fairly rapid-pegging back of that sort of growth pattern, until the line was almost flat at the time the 1985 Budget was prepared. Following the May statement and the 1987 Budget the outlook for government expenditure is actually for a small decline in real terms. On a no policy change basis there will be a small decline in real terms.

In five years we have turned the situation right around from a runaway, completely undisciplined government spending policy, with real growth of 8 per cent built into the first year with no policy changes, down to a negative growth rate, depending on what we like to measure it against, of either 0.2 or 0.5 per cent. It has taken five years to clean up the mess that John Howard left behind him, but it has been done and the days of fiscal irresponsibility are gone from this country, until such time as that rabble that sits over there, and sits on the same side in the House of Representatives, gets back into government. John Howard has shown us, in the alternative, hypothetical Budget which he presented in the middle of this year, that he has not learnt anything, that he has not mended his ways and that, if he had half a chance, he would go right back to presiding over the sorts of policies that he presided over when he was Treasurer in the early 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that the Government has received advice, or is considering proposals, from the Department of Transport and Communications or from other sources that departmental pilots should take over coastwatch duties? If this is so, what aircraft would the Department fly? Has any consideration been given to purchasing or leasing aircraft belonging to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd?
—If there is any such proposal it is complete news to me. I know nothing about it. I am sure that it is a furphy.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. If the Opposition provides a list of expenditure cuts for inclusion in the forthcoming economic statement, will the Government undertake to examine them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly the Government will examine a list of proposed expenditure cuts if Mr Howard cares to supply one. But I am much less confident that he will, because of what he said in an interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on 26 October in reply to a question regarding a mini-Budget before Christmas. One of the reasons the Government did not produce an instant mini-Bud- get, as the ABC called it, is that we do not believe that things should be done on the run. If one tries to produce on the run complicated economic documents, arithmetic tables and all that sort of thing, one is likely to make mistakes. I would have thought that even Mr Howard might have learnt that from his experience last June when, in great haste, the Opposition put together a hypothetical alternative Budget with a $1,500m arithmetical mistake in it. The question was:

ANSWER.PARA: If there were to be a mini-Budget before Christmas, as you're suggesting, would we need a big round of spending cuts as well?
Mr Howard said:
Oh, you'd need expenditure reductions as well, I would have, I assume that was implicit in my comment about a mini-Budget.
The interviewer said:
Well, what areas in particular would you like to see cut?
Mr Howard said:
Oh, I can give you a list if you want to give me another interview . . .

He got another interview this morning from the ABC. He was asked, `What would be on your hit list of spending cuts, Mr Howard? The reply was, `We are not in power. I have been through this nonsense before. The idea that at every morning doorstop an Opposition Leader is supposed to produce an alternative Budget is a ludicrous way of conducting a national policy debate.' So, in a bit over six weeks, we went from, `Oh, I can give you a list if you want to give me another interview', to `It is a ludicrous idea that we should provide such a list'. In other words, Mr Howard has welshed yet again on undertakings he has given to people. If he were to develop a spine and actually put forward for consideration by the public and the Government a list of proposed expenditure cuts, certainly the Government would have a look at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and follows his previous answer. In view of the fact that the Government has indicated that it is going to have an expenditure statement in May, will he give us the Government's hit list? In particular, will he tell us whether what he has described as the two biggest contributors to spending growth-long term income security programs and welfare services-will be cut?

—This Government has an unprecedented record of delivering ongoing cuts in government expenditure. I have just answered a question pointing out that when John Howard was the Treasurer not only was government expenditure out of control but also it was getting more out of control the longer he remained Treasurer.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is clearly debating the question. It is a simple question on what his list of expenditure cuts for May is. He is now debating his last answer, and I ask you to bring him to order.
—I ask the Minister not to debate the question.

—The Government will deliver in May, as it always has delivered. Senator Chaney need have no fear of that. Things have changed massively in the last five years. We now have a government that delivers, instead of a government that does not deliver. I will not go into specifics. Honourable senators opposite can wait until May. However, I would like an assurance from Senator Chaney, as Leader in this chamber of that ragtag and bobtail group that is a substitute for an Opposition in this Parliament, that Government attempts to reduce expenditure will not be sabotaged in the Senate as they were yesterday.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I acknowledge the contribution by the Minister in the process that led to the launching by the Government today of the Women's Sports Promotion Unit and the first ever national policy for women in sport, which is a great milestone for women in sport in Australia, as well as being of considerable satisfaction to me. Can the Minister elaborate on how the Women's Sports Promotion Unit will be staffed and what its priority program will be over the next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that Senator Crowley's question has drawn attention to the launching this morning by Mr Brown, ably assisted by Senator Crowley, of the Women's Sports Promotion Unit and the first national policy and plan for women in sport by the Australian Sports Commission (ASC). It is a very sound document and I commend it to the Senate and to all those who are interested in seeing women get better access to sports facilities and getting the achievements of our many outstanding women athletes better recognised in the media and the community.

ANSWER.PARA: The establishment of the Women's Sports Promotion Unit will be welcomed not only by most honourable senators but also by sportswomen throughout Australia, by competitive women athletes and by the hundreds and thousands of women who are not outstanding athletes but who are involved in sport for recreational purposes-the netball players, the bowlers and so forth. I do not know whether the Senate is aware of the extent to which Australian women participate in sport, but they certainly participate to a very large extent. As a part of our overall commitment to better health for all Australians by the year 2000 the women's Sports Promotion Unit has a very important role to play.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they all get their surfboards free to go with it?

—All women who are involved in sport, including surfing, will be very pleased to see that the Government is advancing the possibility of women's participation in sport. The Women's Sports Promotion Unit will have a budget of $50,000 for the forthcoming financial year. It will be chaired by Ms Margaret Pewtress, an Australian Sports Commissioner and the previous Chairman of the Australian Sports Commission's Task Force on Women's Sport. Other members include Ms Libby Darlinson, an ASC Commissioner who is an acknowledged authority on women in sport issues. There will be another co-opted member with marketing and business skills, and a media consultant will be appointed to the Unit in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: The Unit will draw up a program for women's sport and recognition of women's sport in the media, but because the question of getting better and fairer recognition of women's sport in the media has been crucial for women involved in sports, one of its first tasks will be to draw up a handbook for the media so that those people in the media, and there are some, who are keen to give women's sports a better go will know how to go about it. So, all in all, it is a very constructive step forward in the interests of women's sport, in the interests of equity and in the interests of the Australian community understanding what contribution our women athletes make to the outstanding sporting achievements of our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I direct my question to you in your distinguished high office as President of the Senate. I draw your attention to comments made in the House of Representatives on 8 October 1987 by Mr Leo McLeay regarding the future of the President's chair. Mr McLeay said that the chair is to be left in this building when the Parliament moves into the permanent Parliament House next year. I remind the Senate that this chair was a gift of the Government of Canada to the people of Australia and symbolises the shared parliamentary heritage of Ottawa and Canberra. Can you assure the Senate that, as was the original intention, this chair will take pride of place in our new chamber on Capital Hill?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to Senator Watson's question, of which he gave me notice some time ago, the functional brief for the new Parliament House which deals with the Senate chamber stated:

INTERJECT.PARA: It is possible that some of the major items of furniture in the existing Senate chamber will be transferred to the new chamber because of their historical significance. A decision on this matter has yet to be made. Items which may be transferred are the vice-regal chair . . . and the President's chair and desk.

During 1985 discussions took place between my predecessor and Canadian officials about a suitable gift for the Canadian Parliament to present to the Australian Parliament in recognition of the opening of the new building. These discussions resolved that a new President's chair, fabricated in Canada, would be an eminently suitable gift. I understand that the Canadian Parliament was anxious to continue its close association with the Australian Parliament, and the gift of a President's chair was considered to achieve this aim.

The necessary correspondence was exchanged between the parliaments and the offer of the gift was formally accepted by the then Presiding Officers in October 1985. The Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House noted the acceptance of the gift at its first meeting in 1986. The President's chair in the new chamber, which will be in sympathy with the overall design of the chamber, will be a fitting symbol of the shared parliamentary heritage between our two parliaments. The President's chair in this chamber will remain here to remind visitors in the future of the strong and continuing bond between the Canadian and Australian parliaments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications a question. I refer to reported statements in today's Canberra Times by Mr John Dart, Chief Executive of the Australian Federation of Travel Agents, that the practice of multiple booking by passengers is artificially restricting the availability of airline seats into and out of Australia. For instance, he is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Qantas records show that many of their flights which are listed as overbooked are in fact leaving with 50 or 100 empty seats because of the `no show' problem caused by multi-bookings.

What is the Minister's reaction to these reports? Is he able to say how much multiple booking is initiated by passengers and how much by travel agents? Can he advise on the accurate picture of current airline capacity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates added a few bits of his own to that question which I do not think I can answer at this stage, but I will be happy to answer them in due course. What I can say at this stage is that the reported statements by Mr Dart of the Australian Federation of Travel Agents about overbookings by passengers bear out what I have been saying for some time, that claims of a capacity crisis have been overstated. It is the case that Qantas Airways Ltd has confirmed that flights are arriving with as many as 50 to 100 empty seats and that this situation is not helped by passengers making double or triple bookings because they fear they will not get a seat. Whether it is the passengers who are doing that on their own behalf, or their travel agents doing it for them, is the bit that Senator Coates threw in and the bit that I am unable to answer. I am not sure whether there is any evidence on that point. But, clearly, all the publicity about a so-called crisis is making it more difficult for airlines to deal efficiently with the great demand for travel to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As I indicated earlier, Australia is not alone in facing the problem of increased demand. The latest figures from the International Air Transport Association, which have just come to hand, show a jump of about 18 per cent in world-wide traffic in October. On 20 November I advised the Senate that Qantas would be operating more than 160 supplementary flights over the present summer peak period, which is a quite dramatic increase on the 50-odd such flights which operated over the corresponding period last year. I am now able to advise the Senate that Qantas will be increasing the number of supplementary flights to more than 230 this summer and that it has the capacity to operate up to 300 should market demand require this number. This increment in Qantas capacity has been achieved through leasing a B747 aircraft from Tower Air, a second 747 from Aer Lingus and a DC10 from the Dutch carrier Martinair.

Over the coming holiday season Qantas will be carrying about 700,000 passengers, making it very much the busiest season in the airline's history. In spite of this record number of passengers to be carried during December and January, Qantas still has some 67,000 outbound seats available through to February and some 53,000 inbound seats. Those numbers will be added to as additional flights are put into the system. Compared with Qantas's 230 supplementary flights, with the capacity to go up to 300, the situation with all the foreign carriers put together is that 121 supplementary services by foreign carriers have now been approved and a further six are being processed.
I hope this information will dispel a lot of the unnecessary concern that has been created, for one reason or another, some of it in good faith, about the current capacity situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister satisfied with the way in which mining royalties are administered in the Northern Territory? In light of recent developments in the Northern Territory concerning the payment of royalties by mining companies to the Central Land Council, will the Minister please explain the method of payment by the mining companies to the Central Land Council and the passing on of these royalties to the traditional owners to ensure that they get their lawful payments? It appears from last Sunday's Sunday Territorian that $25m paid by a mining company to the Central Land Council has been paid to the wrong people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided a brief which I think covers many of the matters raised in Senator Sheil's question. The land on which the Mereenie oil and gas project is situated is former Aboriginal reserve land, the title to which was transferred to an Aboriginal land trust under schedule 1 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The land rights Act provides that determination of traditional ownership on schedule 1 land is the responsibility of the relevant land council. About $1.5m has been distributed to the traditional owners as part of a settlement negotiated by the Central Land Council on behalf of the traditional owners of the area of the Mereenie project.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some criticism of a lack of long term benefits from these payments, which in many cases were used to purchase vehicles and other commodities. However, the Minister wishes to emphasise that these Aboriginal people live in a remote area and are among the poorest people in Australia. In such conditions, the process of community development is very gradual. The land rights Act also provides that 30 per cent of an amount equivalent to that paid in royalties by a company mining on Aboriginal land should be paid to incorporated Aboriginal communities and groups in the area affected by the mining operations.

The Ngurratjuta/Pmara Ntjarra Aboriginal Corporation, an association of the communities affected by the Mereenie project, has been formed to receive these statutory royalties. To date Ngurratjuta has received about $1.3m and has a policy that these moneys must be invested or used for community purposes. Ngurratjuta's investments include real estate and a local airline company. The Northern Territory News article was based on assertions by an individual to the Land Commissioner which has not been commented on by the Land Commissioner or assessed in any way. It is therefore wrong to assume the accuracy of the comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. I ask: Is there a Facom computer in the national computer centre, Kent Street, Deakin, containing information on all Australians? Secondly, was the information from the 1986 census forms processed into that computer? Thirdly, which departments share the computer facilities? Fourthly, how much taxpayers' money has been spent on the building, the hardware and the software? Fifthly, will this computer be interlinked with similar computers in other parts of the world via satellite? Sixthly, have identification cards already been printed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Burns's question, for reasons of which I think some honourable senators will be aware. Quite an hysterical, irrational campaign has been promoted by certain persons, including one in the media, about all kinds of sinister and otherworldly dealings going on at the Deakin exchange. Of course, these allegations are quite wrong and I will give some specific replies to Senator Burns's question in a second. But I just place on record my concern that people, particularly those in the media who have influence over their leaders, would give some credence to crazy suggestions of this kind and upset some gullible members of the community with the nonsense that they like to put about.
—But the man who is making these suggestions thinks Gareth Evans is still Attorney-General, so he is way out of touch.

—There are even stranger things than Gareth Evans still being Attorney-General that the mind can contemplate. I am aware of the assertions and can state unequivocally that the Health Insurance Commission, whether as the Australia Card authority or otherwise, has never used space at the Deakin telephone exchange for a computer room or for any other purpose, has never expended any funds for the purpose of installing equipment at that location and has never printed Australia Cards.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, I refer the Senate to a report in the Canberra Times of 8 December 1987 which publicises the recent visit of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts to the Deakin telephone exchange for the precise purpose of investigating the allegations by Mr Sawyer, the gentleman who originally made the allegations. The report discounts the allegations entirely. It is most interesting that the report advises that Mr Peter Sawyer was formerly a junior officer in the Department of Social Security who rose to prominence last year when he published a book called Dole Bludging: a Taxpayer's Guide. Mr Sawyer and his wife were subsequently charged with defrauding the Commonwealth over unemployment and other welfare benefits. If, as I understand it, people are so gullible as to pay Mr Sawyer money for his newsletter and cassette, which contain such unfounded allegations regarding the national surveillance systems, I can only say: caveat emptor-let the buyer beware.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) suffered a loss of at least $400m from its 30 June balance sheet levels because of the stock market collapse? Does this represent a worsening from the $300m, revealed in the annual report released this week, in the value of equities from June to October, from which time the Australian stock market has fallen a further 12 per cent, and involve a loss of up to $100m on its very large holding of shares in Mr Robert Holmes a Court's Bell Group? How does this loss compare with similar superannuation funds in Australia? Does it indicate that, contrary to rhetoric from Government and Australian Democrat senators in this House, ordinary Australians are directly affected by the share crash? Has the bulk of this loss come from the local equity portfolio rather than the $331m holding of foreign equities-all acquired since June, indicating the benefits of foreign investment by local institutions? Finally, as this $400m loss will have wiped out more than half the $791m available for distribution to contributors to the fund from its 1986-87 surplus, what will be the impact on contributors of this reduction of $1,200 per head in contributors' funds? Does it mean that public servants' lump sum pensions or other entitlements will be cut this year-and if so, by how much-or will taxpayers be called in to make up the difference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were more questions asked by Senator Michael Baume than I could take note of, but I remember the last one clearly enough. Taxpayers will not be called on to make up the difference in anything, because the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust is funded entirely by employee contributions and there is no taxpayer subsidy involved in it, other than, one could perhaps argue-and it would be a quite small item-some administrative assistance from the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office insofar as it keeps records for the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust.

ANSWER.PARA: When Senator Baume started to ask this question I thought I had slipped back in time by about six weeks, because a question was asked about this matter-I cannot remember by whom-early in November, I think it was. I then remembered that, like most of the revelations that came out of the Waste Watch Committee, this was really a bit of old news-although some of the figures I gave at that time probably could be revised. At that time I pointed out that only 23 per cent of the SFIT total portfolio, which had been valued at $4.3 billion, was invested in Australian shares, and about 8 per cent of it was invested overseas-which is a very low percentage investment in equities compared with a number of other funds. Insofar as what Senator Baume asks can be quantified, I will get the information as soon as I can.

When talking of a loss, some qualification should be added. It is a paper loss from what in the case of many superannuation funds it is legitimate to regard as a paper gain. That is to say, funds that had shares-selected at random even, because the whole market was going through a boom-recorded very large apparent paper gains. But in most cases they were just that-paper gains. It is a bit like a Patrick Partners underwritten company-what had been promised really was not there at all. Not all people recognise this. Indeed even somebody as astute as Daryl Dixon in an article published in, I think, the Business Review Weekly two or three months ago said that many employers who funded defined benefits schemes would not have to make any contributions for five or six years because the earnings of the funds were so high that they would not require any topping up to meet the drawings on them. That sort of thing cannot go on forever, any more than the land boom in Melbourne in the late 1880s and early 1890s or the Poseidon boom in the 1970s could go on forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his undertaking to get the answers to the various elements of my question. But I ask him specifically about the $791m available for distribution. In view of the fact that the $791m available for distribution is made up of so-called paper profits-profits which have not in fact been taken but which relate to the valuation of the portfolio-will the Minister now amend his answer in respect of the loss so that we can have a clear view of the impact of that loss on the amount available for distribution to contributors?

—I will see what extra information I can get. But I think that the point Senator Baume is making is that those people who got out and took their money when the fund had declared earnings rates of about 28 per cent, I think it was, for the last financial year received the benefit of that. Had the boom gone on for another 12 months, however, the same people might have thought that they were being unfairly treated because they did not get the benefit of an even higher declared earnings rate in the next year. I really do not see what we can do about that, unless we have a defined benefits scheme. Since this is not a taxpayer funded component of the total Commonwealth Public Service superannuation arrangements, I personally would not consider making any changes to that fund unless clearly that was desired by a majority of the contributors to it.

—Has the attention of the Minister for the Environment and the Arts been drawn to an article which appeared in the Melbourne Age last Saturday which outlines claims made by the north Queensland timber industry that World Heritage listing will result in the loss of 2,000 jobs? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the claims made in that article are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claims made by the timber industry in north Queensland are matched in their inaccuracies only by the claims made by the Queensland Government. I know that inflation has been worse in Queensland than in any other State-as is the case with most economic indicators; Queensland usually seems to lag behind. However, the inflation rate that appears to have set in is really quite remarkable as it affects the timber industry in north Queensland. It has to be noted that just on two weeks ago the industry's main spokesperson, Mr Kenane, put out a statement saying that the ambit claim, as he called it, of the industry was $66m. A couple of days ago he said it was now $120m. I am not sure of what sort of mathematics are used in the north Queensland timber industry, but I do know that that is not its only error.

ANSWER.PARA: Part of Senator Zakharov's question related to prospective job losses as a result of World Heritage listing. This figure of 2,000 for the number of jobs to be lost through World Heritage listing should be scotched. The industry itself has never claimed that more than 700 workers were working in the industry, and no one in north Queensland now suggests that all of the mills will close. It is quite obvious that a number will remain open using resources from private land. It has to be remembered also that some of the mills there are not using rainforest timbers anyway. There are other sclerophyll forests that have been available to the industry and will continue to be available. The real factor in unemployment in the timber industry in north Queensland has been the Queensland Government's action in reducing quota. In the last 10 years, quota has been reduced massively and between 1,000 and 2,000 jobs have been lost.

It should always be remembered that for those workers who lost their jobs during that period there were no redundancy or compensation packages, as the national Government proposes. They were simply shown the door. They were told, `There's the gate; walk out of it with nothing in your hand and no future'. There is no way that this Government will be a party to that. Given that Senator Puplick has returned to the chamber, I remind him that we still wonder what his policy and the Liberal Party's policy will be on the listing. Given the announcements that I will make tomorrow, no doubt we will hear next week. Certainly, the people of Australia will not wait until next August to hear what the Liberal Party thinks about it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 December I undertook to Senator Knowles to provide further information in response to her question concerning allegations against individuals associated with Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, or Continental Venture Capital, the company which financed it. Accordingly, I seek leave to incorporate a response in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
On 18 September 1987 I tabled documents in the Senate relating, among other things, to:
(a) a Bureau of Criminal Intelligence report, and
(b) allegations made purporting to link Amann Aviation planes with the importation of drugs and purporting to present Mr Amann as a drug user.
On that occasion I indicated, in paragraph 4 of the tabling statement, that the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence had carried out investigations into Amann Aviation and its associates.

I received a report on 1 September 1987 from Mr Roger Beale, Associate Secretary of my Department (based upon that Bureau of Criminal Intelligence report) which wrongly identified a Mr Spiridon Apokis as a Director of Continental Venture Capital. He was, in fact, Director of Josa Investments, a major shareholder of Continental Venture Capital.
Among the documents tabled on 18 September 1987 were extracts from Mr Beale's Minute. The relevant extracts read:
``In June 1987, a Bureau of Criminal Intelligence report . . . The Department was shown that report today. The responsible AFP Officer (Chief Superintendent Dixon) concluded, however, that

`(5) The matter in issue is the possible embarrassment to the Government if the CVC Directors or corporate associates are disclosed to be of ill repute or with organised crime connotations. This has not been established, nor do I believe the information available to me that an initial suspicion of such connections can be substantiated.

(6) Accordingly, I am of the view that unless some significant matter can be identified by the BCI as a concern to them or with implications of the Government and/or the civil coastal surveillance system I see no reason to (a) pursue this probe further or (b) initiate actions to altert any other persons/Department of the initial BCI report.'
The recommendations were accepted by the BCI and the Deputy Commissioner of the AFP.''
The investigation ceased.

I further indicated in my tabling statement that on 31 August 1987 allegations connecting Mr Amann with the use and/or smuggling of drugs were made to the AFP. Investigations were put in train by the AFP and the Australian Customs Service. No adverse findings were reported arising from these investigations.
My tabling statement pointed out that Mr Beale had further discussed these matters with Deputy Commissioner Farmer of the Australian Federal Police on 4 September 1987 who,
``confirmed that the AFP's conclusion was that there was insufficient information of an adverse nature relevant to the contract to justify either:
Further detailed investigation of CVC, for example through interviews;
Any action to terminate the contract on these grounds.''

Mr Beale briefed me on these matters in Melbourne on 7 September 1987 and it was agreed that they were not such as to justify any action to terminate the contract. These matters were accordingly not further investigated or considered by my Department.
I would further note that in my tabling statement and indeed in any public discussion of these matters I have not named individuals because:
the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence report contains details of the private affairs of a number of persons including their credit and other financial dealings;

it contains speculation about persons being involved in illegal activities which have not been the subject of full investigation or charges and the disclosure of which would be very damaging to the persons concerned;
it could prejudice criminal investigations in relation to matters unrelated to the subject contract and the principals involved in it.
That continues to be the case. I did, however, arrange for Senator Durack to read the report and for him to be briefed by Chief Superintendent Dixon.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any ministerial statements? If not, we will proceed to the consideration of Government Papers.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chaney-I thought that the Government was to make a ministerial statement on Aboriginal affairs.
