Senator Gareth Evans-We are not bringing it down this afternoon.
Senator Chaney-The statement was put down in the House of Representatives this morning and I have been given a copy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I asked whether there were any ministerial statements.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-No. A statement will be made next week. Hopefully, time can be found to debate it then, if that is the desire of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make it quite clear to the Government that the Opposition expects the Government to bring the statement into the Senate. A copy of the statement was supplied to my office in the usual manner today. It was indicated that it would be made in both places. It is a major statement on a matter on which Government senators have had a great deal to say over the years. It is not satisfactory for the statement not to be made in this place. I seek an assurance from the Minister that the statement will be brought in and that there will be an opportunity to comment on it.

—by leave-Yesterday a Green Paper on higher education-a major discussion paper-was put down by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), but it was not tabled here and has not been circulated to honourable senators. It is a grave omission in the procedures of this parliament that papers of such major importance are not placed in this chamber on the same day as they are placed in the other place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have been asked to give an undertaking that a statement on Aboriginal affairs will be put down. I have already done that and I do so again. I was acting under the belief that the statement would be put down later today. I had no idea that it had been put down already. Certainly, I have no desire to stop debate on it although, as is the case with the education statement, the Senate has obviously been operating under time constraints-not that some honourable senators opposite seem to have been too acutely conscious of that. Hopefully, there will be a little more time next week to spread out the debate and enable responses to be made accordingly. I will not go into some of the private discussions I have had on this subject, which are in accordance with that proposition and were the basis on which I acted as I did, to the extent that I had knowledge about the statements at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have received a letter from the Deputy Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Flood. He advises me:

SPEECH.PARA: During consideration by the Committee of the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I advised the Committee that 300 officers from a range of departments passed on assignment through the Embassy in Jakarta in the period 1983 to 1986. This figure is incorrect. I apologise for this and would be grateful if you would inform the Committee of the correct position.

Over the period in question 133 officers at the Embassy had the right to purchase a locally assembled vehicle tax-free. Those officers with diplomatic status also had the right to import a vehicle duty-free. Of these 133 officers, 27 were found to have engaged in questionable transactions involving vehicles imported or purchased locally under diplomatic privilege and 11 were charged with misconduct under the Public Service Act.
I realise that the Estimates have been dealt with, but I thought that the letter should be read into the Hansard so it can be on the public record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FORWARD ESTIMATES OF BUDGET OUTLAYS-1988-89 TO 1990-91-DECEMBER 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

When the Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays was tabled in the Senate this morning, it was noted that the paper was not available prior to tabling. I draw attention to the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) held a Press conference yesterday afternoon based on this paper. Two honourable senators have just raised in this chamber an act-I accept the response of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans)-of inadvertent discourtesy to the Senate in not having put down in this place statements on Aboriginal affairs and education. Now we have what seems to be a somewhat similar act of discourtesy in that two Ministers of the Crown held a Press conference yesterday afternoon based on a paper which was not available to the Senate at that time and which we have been told was not available prior to tabling.

To be fair to the Minister for Finance, the paper contains some worthwhile improvements in presentational arrangements, which I take note of and endorse. The Minister has included under `contingency reserve' an additional item which takes account of what I would call-and the paper uses a similar term-policy drift as a result of the accretion of a whole series of often, in themselves, quite small decisions which, nevertheless, over the course of the financial year add up to a significant range of expenditure commitments. The inclusion in the documentation of such a provision is entirely admirable.

However, having entered that note of appreciation for the technical quality-I underline the words `technical quality'-of the document, I make it quite clear that that is as far as my appreciation extends. In these Forward Estimates we do not have the position to which the Minister for Finance referred on, I think, at least two separate occasions in Question Time this afternoon of an all virtuous government having brought expenditure under control. Page 6 of the paper states that in 1988-89 completion of projects such as the new Parliament House and expiry of programs such as the Bicentenary celebrations contribute particularly to the decline in outlays in real terms in 1988-89. Similar comments are scattered elsewhere throughout the text but, in the short time available to me, I am unable to elaborate on them.

I devote the last couple of minutes of my speech to a rather more general aspect of the report and, more particularly, the use which has been made of the report by Ministers, especially the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer. The fact is that whatever may or may not have been-and I do not have time now to debate that-the fiscal policy record of this Government during its term in office, that record clearly has not been good enough. Had it been good enough we would not have today the international debt of all Australians being something like $108 billion compared with the figure of $35 billion when this Government came to office. Nor would we have a continuingly growing interest bill to foreign creditors which is already eating up something like $8 billion a year of our export earnings in interest payments alone. Nor would we have the rather desperate state of affairs in the labour market that the Government is attempting to address. Again, I do not have time to deal with that.

Since the Budget was brought down the Opposition has been pressing this Government to introduce a mini-Budget. We have redoubled our efforts since the stock market crash and, following that, the crash in the foreign exchange markets. Finally the Government has admitted that the Opposition has been right all along. But because the Government has not been prepared to admit that at the time it was proper to admit it-because it did not wish to do anything of that kind before the New South Wales election-it has done a double-shuffle of five months' duration and promised us a mini-Budget in May next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to make a few remarks on the Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays which was tabled today. I compliment the first comment made by Senator Stone by saying that I find it quite extraordinary that a matter of such apparent importance to the Government was made yesterday by way of Press release when the House of Representatives was sitting. Why on earth did the Treasurer (Mr Keating) completely ignore the Parliament by releasing a Press statement and having a Press conference on it? As far I know, no statement has yet been made to this Parliament and, therefore, to the people of Australia. This is part of the continuing prostitution of the parliamentary processes by which this Government, over 4 1/2 years, has put itself above the law and above the Parliament. It is about time it realised it is accountable to the Parliament and the people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, in his statement yesterday, said, `The Government will not do anything at all between now and next May, in terms of economic policy; we will announce now that in five months time we will have a May statement'. We were going to have a May statement anyway, presumably. It has been the pattern in the last few years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government has just said so.

—As Senator Stone says, Senator Button attempted to make that point during Senator Stone's contributions. Why on earth should the Government make a statement such as the one made yesterday? Contrary to the way much of the media has been conned into thinking, as demonstrated by its coverage of this matter today, the paper will not restore confidence in the economy and in the Government's ability to manage. As soon as people look through the charade, the facade and the superficiality of yesterday's statement and the figures produced by Senator Walsh, they will say, `What are we going to do? What will the climate be next year? We have to wait five months before the Government will tell us'. Quite frankly, I find that to be totally unacceptable, as it must be acceptable to any sensible, reasonable businessman or investor.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if one discounted a little of my concern-and I do not believe it should be discounted one iota-the Government is still making statements in relation to what it is going to do in six months time on the basis of statistics and assumptions which, at this time, can only be of the most dubious accuracy. That is not to say that the best effort has not been put into reaching the conclusions but, in December 1987, how can the Government say that over the next year there will be an exchange rate value on a trade weighted index basis equal to 54, when, I remind the Senate, today the trade weighted index is 52.2? Does the Government seriously believe that with the economic prospects facing this country the level of the Australian dollar will rise over the next six to 12 months? If it does believe that, it is making at least one of two assumptions; that is, either that interest rates will rise very substantially to attract capital into this country to prop up the dollar or that the trade balance will be far better than even the most optimistic of economic forecasters would portray. I find it absolutely extraordinary that the Treasurer said, for example, in his statement yesterday:
. . . the Government is determined that the very substantial progress we have made to date in reducing our trade imbalance will continue.

What improvement has been made in our trade imbalance? We still face a balance of payments deficit on our current account in excess of $11 billion. Our foreign debt is increasing by $1 billion every month, and the Treasurer says sanguinely that we are making substantial progress. That is absolute nonsense. This statement yesterday by the Treasurer and the Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays are a con of the Australian people and will do them and the economy a great deal of harm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in expressing grave concern about the outlook for the Australian economy, particularly following the Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays, which is cast again in the well-worn mould of saying, `Everything is all right. We have everything in hand. There is no need to worry because the best of all possible Treasurers in the best of all possible worlds has the best of all possible solutions'. We have to recognise that the premises on which this document is based seem to be incapable of being achieved. This is a matter of major concern to us all.

SPEECH.PARA: On prices, for example, achieving the objective of this paper and the parameters within which this system works would involve all the deflators used to calculate the outlays being subject to only a one per cent increase over the course of 1988-89. If the pressures on our external balance, which now seem inevitable, come to fruition there will be a strengthening of inflation, not a weakening of it. If interest rates are forced to rise to protect the Australian dollar, that will add to internal costs. If interest rates do not rise and the dollar is left to run, there will be an inflationary impact.

Let us look at some of the other criteria on which this Budget surplus outcome is based. The Government is expecting a one per cent increase to be applied to all wage and salary rates during 1988-89. That seems to be a fairly optimistic outcome. Prices being one per cent higher than the inflation rate that already exists means that there is not just a one per cent price rise, but that it is one per cent higher than the inflation rate. For economic activity, a one per cent increase is applied to the rate of growth of gross domestic product. I do not know where that one per cent higher growth rate than whatever it will be this year came from but, in view of the world slow-down in economic activity which is widely expected to follow the share crash, one would have to be fairly optimistic to look to a higher rate of economic growth-even one per cent higher than is currently taking place. The expectation is for a one per cent increase only in interest rates over those currently obtaining.

The exchange rate, the key item, is assumed to be a one index point increase over the Australian dollar on a trade weighted index basis. In other words, that is a 1.9 per cent increase on the current assumption of a trade weighted index of 54, lifting it to around 56. I believe that very few forecasters would be prepared to accept the view that our currency will be so strong in the following year of 1988-89 that we will have a trade weighted index of 56. All the indicators point the other way. With great difficulties emerging in the area of oil, there are enormous difficulties in the sense of our commitment to pay something like $1,200m a month in gross income debits. That is the basic amount that we have to pay to pay interest only on what we have borrowed. That amounts to about $1 billion a month, and that simply will not go away. Nothing that this Government has done or said in these Forward Estimates papers or in its statements-particularly its statement that it will not have a mini-Budget until next May-will improve the situation.

I simply remind the Senate that, when one compares the outcome under these Forward Estimates in terms of real growth in Government expenditure over six years with the contained growth over the first six years of the Fraser Government, one sees that, because of the profligacy of this Government's first two or three years, it is still a far bigger spending government, even after this forecast reduction-which I do not believe can come about-than the Fraser Government ever was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to the Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays. Once again, this Government is up to the trick in which it has been indulging through its term of office, that of misleading the media, and, crazily, the media accepts being misled by this sort of nonsense. It goes on all the time. What are these figures? They are Forward Estimates, what one might call the wishbag of Ministers and public servants. They are nothing more than a guess as to the sort of money we would like to spend if we had the opportunity to spend it. The Government produces this wishbag of money requests and says, `Aren't we marvellous? We are going to cut it back'. It conducted a media interview yesterday, produced this 148-page document, which contains a lot of nonsense, estimates, figures and all sorts of things, and said, `Look how marvellous we are'.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is, as honourable senators can see when they read the document, that after 1988-89 the Forward Estimates again show a rise in real outlays. As my colleague Senator Michael Baume has just said, at the end of the day this Government is still spending much more than the Fraser Government ever spent or ever got around to spending. The Opposition keeps saying that this Government has to cut back its expenditure, but it will not cut back any expenditure in real terms; it cuts back on the expenditure estimates of some departments for the future.

For anyone who does not believe that these estimates are just guesses, I refer to a paper issued today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in which it acknowledges that a clerical error has been detected in the compilation of estimates of private gross fixed capital expenditure on equipment which resulted in an overstatement of the growth in this aggregate in the September quarter 1987. The Bureau explains:
In addition, a downward revision has been made to this aggregate as a result of more complete capital expenditure survey data becoming available since the initial estimates for 5206.0 were compiled.

The Acting Australian Statistician then goes on to explain that the result of these changes in estimates is a revision of the growth figure previously published for constant price private gross fixed capital expenditure on equipment in the September quarter 1987 from 11.8 per cent to 0.5 per cent. Now that we have the real figures, the estimate drops back from 11.8 per cent to 0.5 per cent. The Australian Statistician has come forward with this admission and has given the real figures after he has had another good look at them, and this Government presents a nonsense estimate and says, `Aren't we great? We have cut it back'-and the media falls for it. I cannot understand the media falling for this absolute nonsense. Where are the decent journalists with some sort of expertise?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all out to lunch.

—They are all out to lunch. Only one journalist is sitting in the gallery. Where are the rest of the journalists who might have some guts to stand up and say to Walsh and Keating, `You are kidding us; this is nonsense.'? When will we have journalists with that sort of guts? We had one called Pru Goward, but she was kicked out. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) would not have her there because she asked too many difficult questions. The ABC is doing the same thing with another woman. I say to the journalists of Australia: Where are you? Why do you not stand up to the relevant Ministers and ask them some sensible questions? This 148-page document is absolute nonsense. It is about time some of the journalists who went to the Press conference asked some decent questions of these Ministers instead of accepting their gibberish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition senators who have already spoken have described why the Opposition is very sceptical about the material that has been put before the Parliament today. It is a matter of serious concern that the latest sort of hypnotic gesture used by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, to befuddle observers into thinking that the Australian economy is in good shape appears to be the set of figures before us. When the Budget before last was brought down, I can remember saying to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) that getting the fiscal settings right was a very important element of the strategy for restoring Australia's economy but that other essential things needed to be done, such as microeconomic reforms and reform of the labour market.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental point I make is that, even if one accepted at face value what has been said by Government Ministers about the fiscal position as represented by the Forward Estimates, it is quite clear that the Australian economy is in the deepest trouble and that this Government is not making any realistic efforts to come to grips with the many difficulties. The Government is focusing on this one area-the question of the fiscal deficit. It is hanging everything-its comparison with the United States performance and its belief that the economy is in good shape-on a single statistic.

On behalf of the Opposition, I remind the Senate that when one looks at the situation that was described by Senator Stone, who was the first speaker from the Opposition on these papers-the growth in our external debt-and asks what our prospects are of getting out of the dire predicament in which our country stands at the moment, one sees a series of statistics which would strike despair in the heart of any sensible observer. The foreign debt in this country is now at 40 per cent of our gross domestic product compared with 13 per cent of GDP for the United States of America. That gives the Senate a clear indication of the comparative burden of foreign debt between the two countries. What are the prospects of our cutting down our foreign debt as against the United States? We know that the Government has predicted another $11.5 billion deficit this financial year on the external account. That means by definition that we will have a continued growth in our foreign debt during the current year.

On the other hand, are we moving into a stage of higher productivity and great growth which means that we will turn the corner and start reversing that trend in a serious way? Are we becoming more internationally competitive. The figures show that the answer to that question is no. Let us take the area of wages. Here again the Government engages in a sleight of hand. It talks about a reduction in real labour costs in this country. The reduction in real labour costs has occurred as a result of the collapse of the Australian dollar. The nominal wages in this country have continued to rise, while living standards and real wages have fallen as a result of economic mismanagement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—That is true. The reality is that nominal wages in Australia-we could use the measure of unit labour costs-have gone up by between two and three times the amount of increase in our competitor countries. This year the Government is predicting that unit labour costs will rise to a much larger extent than will the unit labour costs in our competitor countries. So we are going backwards. The chief apologist for the Government, Senator Maguire from South Australia, would justify the massacre of the innocents if it was carried out by Mr Keating; he justifies in a most craven and pathetic way everything that is done by this Government. The reality is that the Government has presented us with Budget Papers that show that productivity in Australia did not increase at all. The figures of Senator Maguire's Government show that there was no increase in productivity in the last period. What increase in productivity is predicted in the current Budget Papers? Maybe one-half of one per cent. The reality is that our inflation rate, our employment rate, our proportion of debt compared with our gross domestic product, our interest rates and our unit labour cost increases are all negatives when compared with the situation of our trading partners. That guarantees a continuing declining position. This Government must accept that Budget policy is but one of the legs of a successful economic policy. It must come to grips with its fiscal policy in a far more effective way than it has to date; that is the considered view of the Opposition. It must also come to grips with the fact that it is continuing to promote a wage fixing system and a general labour market approach which are not working for Australia; it is continuing to cause Australia to slide down the drain. It is important that the Opposition record these views at this time. Though 1988 may be Australia's birthday year, I can only say that no parent, no government, should present to its child or its country a birthday present that reflects the economic situation that this Government is presenting to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: LEMONTHYME AND SOUTHERN FORESTS COMMISSION OF INQUIRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the first part of the report of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests of Tasmania. It will be recalled that the legislation establishing this inquiry was passed through Parliament in the face of strong opposition from this side of the chamber. We did not believe that the establishment of the Helsham inquiry was necessary following on the steps that had already been taken to give protection to the World Heritage areas of South West Tasmania. We still wait for the final report of the Helsham inquiry. This interim report is brought to us in order to indicate those parts of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests which should be excluded from additional protection under the World Heritage regime. In fact, this report nominates four areas, totalling 226 hectares out of the whole area of some 283,300 hectares which is under consideration by the inquiry, as being areas which ought to be removed from the jurisdiction of the Commission and from the imposition of any controls over their exploitation.

The report draws attention to the difficulty which is presented to the Commission in identifying the sites under section 8 (5) of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Act. The Commission must be satisfied not simply that the areas to be excluded do not qualify for World Heritage status but that, in the words of the Act, they are `definitely not qualified' areas. The Commission draws attention to the very strict standard which is therefore imposed upon it. It is required not simply to assess that an area is not qualified but, indeed, that an area is `definitely not' qualified.

I make two points arising from this report. The first is that by accepting the determination of the Commission in this regard-a determination which was urged upon the Commission by the Chief Justice when dealing with an application for an injunction to prevent logging from taking place in the area-and by accepting the principles of the exclusion, the Government has made it clear that there is no reason for World Heritage areas or areas relevant to the World Heritage to be treated in a blanket fashion. It will be of some considerable importance to note tomorrow, when Senator Richardson announces his final boundaries for the World Heritage area which he proposes to seek in north Queensland, that the argument that the whole area, a contiguous and continuous area and an area which in the jargon does not constitute a `Swiss cheese' approach to national park management, should be included is not sustainable on the basis of the scientific facts or the proper evaluation or assessment of the values which it is important to preserve.

Senator Richardson will not be able tomorrow to get away with claims about blanket inclusions, given the clear fact that in assessing the value of areas for World Heritage and other preservation the Helsham inquiry has made it clear that each area should be evaluated discretely on the basis of the precise scientific data available and that the assessment should be made on the discrete basis. If this interim report does anything, it exposes the fact that the blanket approach which the Government has taken to World Heritage listing and to environmental protection is inherently unsound in principle and unsound on a scientific basis. That is why this interim report is a very important one. We shall await the final report with some considerable degree of interest, but this report needs to be noted for the important document which it is.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the response of Madam Speaker and the President to the report of the Joint Committee on Publications entitled Review of the Cost and Distribution of the Parliamentary Paper Series. Copies have been distributed to honourable senators and the text of the response will be incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: The document read as follows-
RESPONSE OF PRESIDING OFFICERS TO REPORT OF JOINT COMMITTEE ON PUBLICATIONS
Review of the Cost and Distribution of the Parliamentary Paper Series-1986

Although this response addresses all recommendations of the Committee's report it is recognised that the Committee, the Presiding Officers and the Government are each involved in the consideration and implementation or otherwise of sections of the Committee's findings. Thus the Presiding Officers see:
the Committee as responsible for action in respect of recommendations 1 to 5 and 10,
the Presiding Officers as responsible for initiating action in respect of recommendations 14 to 19 and 22 to 32, and
the Government as primarily responsible for evaluating and responding to recommendations 6 to 9, 11 and 12, 20, and 21.

Recommendation 13 is seen as involving all 3 elements-the Committee, the Presiding Officers and the Government-and in order to advance this matter the Presiding Officers will initiate discussions with appropriate Government agencies at officer level.
[For ease of reference, the recommendations of the Committee have been numbered.]
Recommendation of Committee
Response of Presiding Officers
Content of the Parliamentary Papers Series (Chapter 2, recommendations 1 to 5)
1. That the documents comprising the Australian Treaty Series should not be recommended for printing.
2. That reports of delegates to conferences and international visits should not be recommended for printing.
3. That all parliamentary committee reports other than final reports on an inquiry or final reports on aspects of the inquiry, should not be recommended for printing.
4. That ad hoc committees of inquiry reports should continue to be included in the Parliamentary Papers Series except when the historical or political interest is limited to the short term.
5. That the Committee's publishing guidelines be revised to read:
Recommendations 1 to 5
The content of the Series is determined by decisions of the two Houses based, in large measure, on recommendations of the Publications Committee.
As the Committee's publishing guidelines are a matter for the Committee to determine, recommendations 1 to 5 do not call for a response from the Presiding Officers.

The Presiding Officers would, however, make a comment in respect of recommendation 3. Some authors have, in the past, titled reports which have a continuing significance as a `progress' or `interim' report. An example of this would be the 203rd report of the Public Accounts Committee presented on 9 December 1982. It was titled `Medical fraud and overservicing-Progress report'. It would be unfortunate if reports such as these were, because of the title accorded them, not adequately considered by the Publications Committee.
(i) that all reports, returns and statements of departments, authorities, Parliamentary and ad hoc inquiries and royal commissions which are presented to Parliament be recommended for printing;

(ii) the previous resolution is not intended to include interim annual reports of departments and authorities nor reports of unfinished Parliamentary inquiries and reports of ad hoc inquiries with short term interest;
(iii) papers which are regularly presented and subsequently printed as Parliamentary Papers should continue to be recommended for printing on those occasions when they constitute a `nil' return; and

(iv) wherever possible, the reports of the Auditor-General which are presented in conjunction with annual reports and financial statements of statutory bodies be included in the one printed document with those reports and statements.
Production of Pamphlet copies of the Parliamentary Papers Series (Chapter 3, recommendations 6 to 13)
General response to recommendations 6 to 13

The Committee's report properly draws attention to the difficulty experienced by AGPS in administering the production standards for documents that are to be presented to Parliament and the need for the standards to be adhered to more closely if waste is to be avoided and costs controlled. The past record of disregard for the production standards by some departments and authorities supports the Committee's conclusions that the standards need to be supported by appropriate legislative provision, i.e. by incorporation in the guidelines made pursuant to section 25 (7) of the Public Service Act or by the passage of an Annual Reports Act. Mechanisms need to be developed to ensure that these provisions are oversighted by a relevant Government authority.

The Presiding Officers note that the Government has recently presented to the Parliament its ``Guidelines for the preparation of Departmental annual reports''. In particular the Presiding Officers welcome the statement that AGPS guidelines on standards of production must be observed. This is a timely strengthening of this aspect of the guidelines from those announced in 1982.

The Presiding Officers are confident that Parliamentary Committees, in particular the Joint Committee on Publications, will continue to monitor and to comment on the way in which departments adhere to the guidelines concerning production standards.
6. That the standards relating to the production of the cover of Class I reports be upgraded so that two colour designs may be included and that Class II be dropped from the production standards.
Response to specific recommendations in this chapter:
Recommendation 6

The Presiding Officers support the recommendation that the production standards governing the covers of Class I reports be changed to allow two colour designs. The recommendation that the Class II category of documents be omitted from the production standards for documents presented to Parliament is not opposed. The Government, however, may wish to consider whether this change may unduly restrict the format of the reports of departments and non-commercial agencies.
7. That the current Class III standards be applied only to reports of those government agencies competing in the commercial sector.

8. That the guidelines which are to be presented to Parliament pursuant to section 25 (7) of the Public Service Act 1922 include these references [e.g. to program budgeting and access to freedom of information material] and that the guidelines relating to reporting standards of statutory authorities also incorporate them.
Recommendations 7 and 8
Supported.
9. That a system of two edition annual reports be available to those organisations wishing to publish an annual promotional document.
Recommendation 9

Not opposed. The Presiding Officers recognise that expensive promotional reports which are tabled as annual reports significantly increase the cost to the Parliament of the Parliamentary Papers Series. In instances where an organisation opts to publish a promotional review of activities in addition to its annual report to Parliament, the Presiding Officers see it as essential in order to avoid confusion, that the promotional document be given a title other than `Annual Report'. While promotional annual reviews could be presented to Parliament, departments and authorities should be placed under no pressure to do so. Care would need to be exercised in any development of a system of publishing two documents-a simply produced annual report and a promotional annual review-that the costs of writing, preparing and printing two publications did not outweigh the advantages and savings seen in such a system.

10. That the edition which includes the financial statements and Auditor-General's report, and meets the other guidelines under the Public Service Act 1922 or those for statutory authorities, only be included in the Parliamentary Papers Series.
Recommendations 10 to 13
Supported.

11. That the Government consider the introduction of an Annual Reports Act as a means of ensuring that federally funded bodies report on their responsibilities to the Parliament and do so within the appropriate production standards.
12. That `camera-ready' production of reports which fall readily within the Parliamentary Papers publishing guidelines should be produced in accordance with the AGPS requirements.

13. That alternative technology [e.g. microfiche, computer readable material on disk and audio or video cassette recordings] may be used in the production of material that is not required to be read with the body of a report provided the Joint Committee is consulted prior to production.
Distribution of Pamphlet copies of the Parliamentary Papers Series (Chapter 3, recommendations 14 to 19)
14. That secondary schools no longer be eligible for the distribution of pamphlet copies of Parliamentary Papers.
15. That the members of the Parliamentary Press Gallery and newspapers be excluded from the free distribution guidelines.

16. That overseas addressees that are the main national or parliamentary library of a country be admitted on request to the free distribution list, if an exchange arrangement exists with the National Library of Australia.
17. That the stock of pamphlet Parliamentary Papers made available to AGPS be reduced from 100 to 25 or sufficient to meet subscribers' standing orders.
18. That free distribution to Federal Political Parties should be on the basis that the party has been registered by the Australian Electoral Commission.
Recommendations 14 to 19

Accepted. The Presiding Officers are aware that the Committee has expressed concern about the increasing cost to the Parliament of the Parliamentary Papers Series. We share this concern and believe that implementation of these recommendations will assist to contain and in some instances reduce costs associated with the Series. The Presiding Officers will arrange for these recommendations to be implemented with the publication of Parliamentary Paper No. 1 of 1988. The Presiding Officers note the Committee's consideration in its 1986 report of the use of blue covers for pamphlet copies and its subsequent request that the Presiding Officers determine a suitable workable cost-efficient alternative. This matter is being reviewed and any necessary changes will be implemented at the commencement of the Parliamentary Papers Series in 1988.
19. That the distribution guidelines be as follows:

Production of the Bound Volumes of the Series (Chapter 4, recommendations 20 to 22)
20. That AGPS, when supplying the pamphlet copies of Parliamentary Papers, provide a cumulative listing of all Papers issued in that year and a list of outstanding papers from the previous year.
Recommendation 20
Supported on the basis that AGPS provide the lists at regular quarterly intervals.

21. That any production of the Parliamentary Papers Series in microfiche should be accompanied by the appropriate amendments to copyright legislation to enable 100% reproduction of a paper in the restricted circumstances described [i.e. when a copy of the original paper is not available from the local AGPS bookshop].
Recommendation 21

This recommendation is supported in principle. No action is required on the recommendation until such time as a decision is made to publish the Series in a microform or other non-hard copy format such as read only memory (ROM) disc.
22. That the number of sets of bound volumes prepared annually be reduced to 27.
Recommendation 22
The response to this recommendation is related to the response to recommendations 31 and 32.
Distribution of the Bound Volumes of the Series (Chapter 4, recommendations 23 to 32)
23. That the practice of maintaining reserved stocks of bound volumes cease.
Recommendations 23 to 30
Accepted. The Presiding Officers will arrange for these recommendations to be implemented as soon as possible.
24. That AGPS dispose of the current reserve stocks by providing missing stock to current recipients and other interested parties.
25. That free distribution to the House departments (the Departments of the Senate and the House of Representatives) and the Parliamentary Library be maintained.
26. That the National Library of Australia should be maintained as a recipient of two sets of bound volumes as it houses Australia's national collection.
27. That the Australian Archives remain on the free distribution list.

30. That the issue of bound volumes be restricted to those overseas libraries that are the national or parliamentary library of a country which has an exchange arrangement with the National Library of Australia.
31. That the following categories be removed from the free distribution list for bound volumes:

Municipal Libraries
Universities
Colleges of Advanced Education

Overseas Libraries [which are not national or parliamentary libraries that have an exchange arrangement with the National Library of Australia]
Recommendations 31 and 32

The Presiding Officers accept the Committee's conclusion that the provision of full case-bound sets of Parliamentary Papers to the categories of recipients listed in recommendation 31 cannot be justified given the very high costs associated with the provision of this item.

Whilst not providing case-bound sets of papers to Australian universities and colleges in future, the Presiding Officers consider the value of the Series for students undertaking courses in the major tertiary institutions sufficient to justify the continued supply of two copies of each paper to universities and colleges:
the first copy, in pamphlet form, when the Parliamentary Paper is published, and

cumulative list of papers [recommendation 20].

publishing guidelines relating to treaties, reports of delegations, Parliamentary inquiries and ad hoc committee reports [recommendations 1 to 5]
