The speech read as follows-
Report 278-Response to report 241-Report of the Auditor-General 1983/84 and September 1984
Report 278 contains the Department of Finance Minute on the Public Accounts Committee's Report 241-Auditor-General's report of 1983/84 and September 1984. Report 241 was tabled in November 1985.

The Department of Finance Minute is the formal mechanism used by departments to respond to the Committee's conclusions and recommendations. The Committee is generally satisfied with the responses on this occasion.

The Committee's conclusions in report 241 concerned the results of audits into matters affecting various departments, most significantly deficiencies in the administration by the Department of Education of student assistance schemes, tardiness by the Department of Territories in the presentation of financial statements for agencies under its control and unsatisfactory procedures relating to internal audit in the former Department of Defence Support.

In view of the changes to student assistance schemes, the introduction of the Austudy scheme and the installation of a new ADP system in the former Department of Education and Youth Affairs the Committee has sought information to clarify that problems previously identified in the delivery of benefits to students will not occur with the new assistance scheme and the associated processing system.

The successor to the Department of Territories, the Office of ACT Administration, no longer has a backlog of unaudited financial statements. The Committee hopes the Office will monitor the situation to ensure the backlog commented upon by the Auditor-General does not recur.

The Committee is pleased to note that the Defence Audit Branch has remedied its internal audit deficiencies. An audit charter and annual work schedule have been established, reviews are carried out on the audit function and the methodology used by field-work staff, and more regular meetings of the Department's audit steering and policy committees are now held. These measures, together with adequate staffing, should ensure internal audits are finalised.
Report 281-Report of Activities July 1986-June 1987
The Committee's 281st Report continues the practice established in 1976 of informing the Parliament of the Committee's activities. This Report covers the financial year 1 July 1986-30 June 1987.
The report provides a convenient medium for the Committee to review its own activities and to suggest areas of public and financial administration which may require further review and reform.

In the period reviewed by this report the Committee presented 27 reports to Parliament, including such major inquiries as the implementation of the offsets program, the administration of the Commonwealth's property functions and the Department of Defence's computer acquisition. This latter inquiry continued the significant role played by the Committee through the Standing Reference on major ADP acquisitions.

During this last year, the Committee lost the services of two of its longest serving members. On 18 February 1987 the then Chairman Senator George Georges resigned from the Committee having served on it for over seven years. Senator the Hon. Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, DBE, who served on the committee for a total of eight years, retired from the Senate on the dissolution of Parliament in June. I would like to pay tribute to Senator Georges and Senator Guilfoyle for their active and effective membership of the Committee.
Report 282-Australian Wool Corporation-Property Operations

This Report, the 282nd from the Committee, outlines the findings of the Committee's review of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit of the Australian Wool Corporation's property operations. The Auditor-General's report was tabled in the Parliament on 26 November 1985.

The efficiency audit focused on the commercial management of the wool stores owned by the Wool Corporation. Audit's analysis was based on the assumption that the Corporation should maximise the income obtained from its property operations, arguing for greater risk taking in property investment decisions.

The Wool Corporation disagreed fundamentally with the Audit analysis. The Corporation did not disagree with the factual accuracy of the report, but rather with Audit's assessment of the commercial risks associated with the redevelopment of its wool stores and Audit's criticisms of the Corporation's commercial judgment.

The Committee regards this audit as highlighting and clarifying the difficulties of applying present efficiency audit guidelines to government business enterprises. The Committee considers the Corporation's serious disagreement with Audit's analysis and recommendations as reflecting a genuine concern about the legitimate scope and character of the audit.
The Committee therefore recommends that a detailed review of efficiency auditing guidelines for government business enterprises be undertaken.
Report No. 283-Response to Report 248-Report of the Auditor-General-April 1985
The Committee presented its 248th Report on the Reports of the Auditor-General for April 1985 on 19 August 1986. The 283rd report sets out the Response to its findings in Report 248.

The matters raised in the Committee's earlier report generally have elicited a satisfactory response from departments and agencies. Of the outstanding matters, the most significant were the procedures for the handling of grants by the Department of Community Services under the Children's Services Program and the recovery of overpayments and the matching of eligibility and entitlements for family allowances by the Department of Social Security.

In its earlier report the Committee was concerned that the Department of Community Services had breached the Child Care Act 1972 in the payment of certain grants to organisations and that financial control over the acquittance of such grants had been poor. Although some of these problems appear to have been remedied, the Committee will look for continued improvements in the procedures for the handling of grants under the Children's Services Program.

The Committee was also concerned at repeated findings by Audit that revealed either inadequate procedures or the non-compliance with procedures related to the recovery of overpayments by the Department of Social Security. The Department has implemented a range of measures aimed at improving its performance in the recovery of overpayments. The Committee supports these initiatives but would wish to see evidence of their impact before making a final assessment of their effectiveness.

The Committee also expressed its concern in the earlier report at the continuing error rate in the payment of family allowances to persons in receipt of unemployment benefits. The Committee notes that the introduction of STRATPLAN should go some way towards preventing such errors in future but also supports the development of further procedures at the earliest opportunity which will enable the checking of continuing eligibility and entitlement.

The Committee intends to keep the matters it has raised under review. I take this opportunity to reiterate the Committee's view that annual reports to the Parliament should contain information regarding any reviews by the Auditor-General or parliamentary committees which directly affect a department or agency, showing recommendations arising from such reviews and the action taken to address them.
Report 284-Stratplan-the Department of Social Security's Re-equipment Program
This is the Committee's third and final report on the implementation of Stratplan, the Department of Social Security's major computer re-equipment program.

In June 1983, the Minister for Social Security announced the Stratplan program and indicated that in view of its costly and complex nature the Government had decided to refer it to the Public Accounts Committee for monitoring and report.
The Committee's first report on Stratplan, Report 255, was tabled in October 1984 and dealt with the issues of:
the acquisition process;
health and safety;
industrial relations;
the resignation of a senior officer;
offsets arrangements;
project management;
financial management; and
internal audit involvement.
The Committee made a number of recommendations in respect of several of these issues.

In its first report the committee set out arrangements whereby the Department of Social Security would report to the Committee on a regular basis on various aspects of the implementation of Stratplan. To this end the Department forwarded quarterly progress reports.

In August 1985 the Committee tabled Report 237, which covered the Government's response to the recommendations of its first report. The Committee noted that there were several matters for which satisfactory responses were not provided and undertook to pursue them during the next phase of its monitoring.
In addition, the Committee has examined:
industrial relations;
applications development;
Computer Systems Officer Staffing and the use of contractors; and
cost-effectiveness of Stratplan.

The Committee has reached a number of conclusions concerning the area of industrial relations. The Committee concluded that the Department of Social Security had been unprepared for the level of industrial action which had occurred, it had developed no contingency plans before the onset of industrial action and it had therefore lost the initiative to the unions which resulted in concessions which generated totally unplanned and unpredicted increases in the Department's staffing levels. The relevant guidelines promulgated by the Public Service Board had been deficient in that they did not provide for the development of contingency plans for use in the event of industrial action, nor did they provide for the translation of some part of efficiency gains and associated benefits into improved opportunities for affected staff.
On the issue of applications development the Committee focused its attention on the National Index and Online Benefits Processing.

The National Index was an original objective of the Stratplan program: based on a centralised database allowing access to larger databases, it would have enabled prompt identification of the Department's clients on an Australia-wide basis. To date the National Index has not been implemented as planned because of the costs entailed. Instead, a national inquiry about a client must be processed against each State database; this results in delayed responses to such inquiries. The Committee does not believe that this provides an adequate alternative to the National Index as originally envisaged.

Online Benefits Processing is currently the Department's major strategic development project. It has always been identified as providing a major justification for the Stratplan project. To date Online Benefits Processing and its resulting benefits have not been realised. The Committee believes that delays which have occurred in its development could have been prevented.

The Committee has referred to the major problem of recruiting and retaining Computer Systems Officers in the Australian Public Service before. It has been a contributing factor to some of the delays in the implementation of Stratplan and the Committee has no doubt that it will seriously affect other major Commonwealth ADP acquisition projects. The Committee notes the initiatives being taken within the Australian Public Service to remedy the problem of recruitment and retention but feels that much more needs to be done.

In attempting to assess the cost effectiveness of the original Stratplan proposal the Committee found that not only had there been no adequate provision for measurement tools and performance indicators at the onset of the project but also that the identity of Stratplan and its outcomes had now become too inextricably confused with other departmental ADP initiatives. The Committee concluded that cost effectiveness could no longer be meaningfully quantified and that couching cost effectiveness in terms of foregone staff increases was of doubtful relevance to the decision making and review process.

It is anticipated that this will be the Committee's final report on its monitoring of the implementation of Stratplan, other than on any responses to issues raised in this report which result in the tabling of a further Finance Minute.
Reports 285 and 286-Advance to the Minister for Finance 1985-86 and 1986-87.

The Advance to the Minister for Finance is a provision authorised by the annual Appropriation Acts and made available to the Minister for issue in accordance with the terms of the appropriations and Section 36a of the Audit Act 1901.

Senators will be aware that each year the Committee examines expenditure from the Advance to ascertain whether that expenditure has been confined to urgent and unforeseen requirements for which provision could not have been made in the original or Additional Estimates.
The Committee also seeks to ascertain whether the departments concerned have maintained efficient administration in the expenditure of funds under the items examined.

Under current arrangements, the Department of Finance provides the Committee with copies of all approved applications for funds from the Advance where they would remain a final charge to the Advance at the close of the financial year. All these applications for funds must be accompanied by adequate supporting detail.

While the Committee is satisfied that in most cases expenditure from the Advance in 1985-86 and 1986-87 was confined to urgent and unforeseen requirements, it continues to be concerned by the many instances of insufficient documentary information being provided by departments in support of their applications for funds from the Advance.

The Committee has raised this shortcoming in previous reports. While the Committee recognises that the Department of Finance has attempted to ensure that departments comply with existing procedures to satisfy the Committee's requirements, it believes that the Department should now adopt a more rigorous approach to administering the AMF process. Departments are no less accountable for funds expended through this process than through any other.

At a more fundamental level, the Committee doubts whether the current procedure enables the most timely and effective means of ensuring accountability. Given the delays which now occur between the incidence of expenditure from the Advance and its examination by the Committee, the Committee feels that perhaps there is a case for introducing a procedure which enables more immediate Parliamentary scrutiny.

Further, the Committee questions whether the results it has achieved in the past in its involvement with the Advance to the Minister for Finance warrant the continued investment of its diminishing resources. The Committee intends to consider this matter in further detail.
Report 287-Australian Taxation Office-Computer System Re-equipment and Redevelopment

This report presents the findings of the Committee's review of the proposed computer system re-equipment and redevelopment program of the Australian Taxation Office. The report is the fifth to be tabled by the Committee under the terms of its standing reference (passed in the House of Representatives on 8 May 1985 and the Senate on 10 May 1985) to investigate and report on proposed acquisitions of Automatic Data Processing (ADP) facilities by Commonwealth departments and authorities staffed under the Public Service Act 1922.

On 19 February 1987, the Treasurer wrote to the Chairman of the Committee indicating that Cabinet had given in-principle approval for a major staged computer systems re-equipment and redevelopment project to be undertaken by the Australian Taxation Office. The Treasurer advised the Chairman that Cabinet recognised the importance and urgency of the proposal and had asked the Commissioner of Taxation to make an immediate formal submission to the Committee. The Taxation Office would, in parallel with Committee consideration of the proposal, be developing a draft Request for Tender. The Treasurer requested that the Committee consider the matter in sufficient time to enable the Request for Tender to be issued in June 1987.

While the Committee intended to table a report of its review before the end of the Autumn sittings of the 34th Parliament, the announcement of the federal election for 11 July and the concomitant dissolution of the 34th Parliament on 5 June prevented this from happening. On 2 June the Committee advised the Parliament that a report should be presented to the Parliament by the Sixteenth Committee of Public Accounts.
The Taxation Office subsequently released its Request for Tender on 17 August 1987 and tenders closed on 24 November.
The Committee regrets the delay that has occurred in the tabling of its report as a result of the federal election.

The Committee supports the Australian Taxation Office in its endeavours to make better use of information technology and is firmly of the view that the Taxation Office has no real alternative but to proceed with its computer system re-equipment and redevelopment proposal. Nevertheless the Committee has a number of concerns with matters that relate to the proposal and has made recommendations accordingly.

The Committee is concerned about the continuing shortage of suitably qualified computer personnel and the effects this problem will have on the Taxation Office's proposal. The Committee has recommended that the Tax Office look within its own ranks and train suitable tax staff to be qualified computer staff.

The Committee is concerned about the management expertise of those charged with `driving' the re-equipment and redevelopment program through to completion and has recommended that the Tax Office set up a task force to be dedicated to the re-equipment and redevelopment program and that the task force be managed by highly experienced external resources. The Committee notes the project before the Tax Office is one of the largest of its kind to be undertaken in this country;

The Committee is concerned with the justification of the project used by the Tax Office and in particular, the use of cost effectiveness analysis. The Committee is somewhat sceptical about the staff savings that are predicted by the Tax Office and which are the justification for the project.

The Committee has recommended that the Tax Office re-evaluate the justification for its proposal and identify the proposal's potential benefits in terms of the objectives and performance targets defined in the office's Corporate Plan. The Committee has also recommended that the Tax Office and the Department of Finance adopt a co-ordinated and timely approach to the specification of appropriate performance indicators for the re-equipment and redevelopment program.

The Committee notes that in justifying its proposal the Tax Office has not used revenue gains that might result from the new systems. The Tax Office advised the Committee that revenue gains had already been put forward to the Select Committee in the proposal for an Australia Card. However, subsequent to the Government's decision not to proceed with the Australia Card, the Tax Office advised the Committee that it was preparing for Cabinet consideration a proposal for the development of a high integrity numbering system as part of its computer system re-equipment and redevelopment proposal. The Tax Office advised the Committee that it would prepare a cost-benefit analysis of the re-equipment and redevelopment proposal which did not include the use of a high integrity number system. This analysis would be presented to Cabinet together with the proposal for the high integrity numbering system.
The Committee has made recommendations in a number of other areas. They include:
industrial relations;
systems design;
emergency computer sites;
project estimates; and
potential of participation by the Australian computer industry.

The Committee believes the conclusions and recommendations it has made demonstrate a continuing need for thorough scrutiny of ADP acquisition proposals. The Committee notes, however, that the Australian Taxation Office has shown in some aspects of its proposal that it has benefited from the experience of other Commonwealth organisations and the scrutiny given to their ADP acquisition proposals.
The Committee notes that this could be the last ADP acquisition proposal that it will review and report on.

The Block Efficiency Scrutiny Unit reviewed the Commonwealth ADP acquisition process in January/February this year and in March forwarded a report to Cabinet for consideration. The Committee understands that the Scrutiny Unit's report sees the Committee's role in the major ADP acquisition area being greatly diminished if not being entirely removed. As a Committee of the Parliament the Public Accounts Committee is concerned that a final decision on this matter is still to be reached. The delay means that at least two departments that are presently preparing submissions for the Committee to review could be well wasting their time.

The Committee is also having its Secretariat reduced from 15 staff to 5 staff so as to facilitate the new House of Representatives Standing Committees. So, even if the Committee should retain its standing reference to investigate and report on major ADP acquisition proposals it will not have the necessary staff to carry out its ADP work.

In concluding it must be stated that the present Public Accounts Committee is very grateful for the work done by the 15th Committee and in particular, the members of the 15th Committee who served on the Committee's Information Technology Sub-Committee. Particular thanks go to the Chairman of that Sub-Committee, Mr Roger Price, MP.
Report 288-Review of the Efficiency Audit-Administration of Capital Grants to Non-government School

The 288th Report outlines the findings of the Public Accounts Committee's review of an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General on the administration of capital grants to non-government schools. The Auditor-General's Report was tabled on 23 September 1986.
The audit identified serious deficiencies on the administration of capital grants to non-government schools. The Auditor-General's Report was tabled on 23 September 1986.

The audit identified serious deficiencies in a number of areas related to the administration of the program. The major problems identified were the adequacy of guidelines and of assessment procedures, the efficiency and effectiveness of the operations of some components of the program and the monitoring of the program.

The Committee noted that some of the findings and recommendations of the audit were out of date because of the delay in tabling the report after the collection of data. In addition, new arrangements for the payment of capital grants to non-government schools are being introduced. The Government has announced that as from January 1988, subject to the passage of necessary legislation, capital grants will be allocated as a block grant for internal distribution by authorities set up for that purpose.

The Committee was pleased to note that the Department of Employment, Education and Training had taken action on a number of matters highlighted in the Auditor-General's Report or in the Committee's public hearings. However here were a number of matters which remain of concern to the Committee.

A primary concern of the Committee was the need to protect the Commonwealth's financial interest. Section 26 (2) (c) of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1984 creates a Commonwealth interest, usually for a period of 20 years, in any asset valued in excess of $30,000 which is purchased with grant monies. Under this section school authorities may be required to repay to the Commonwealth an asset's depreciation value if the school ceases to use that asset for an approved purpose or sells it.

The Audit found that a substantial number of schools had failed to observe grant conditions. It also found that there were deficiencies with the procedures, legislation and other documentation which put in doubt the Commonwealth's ability to recover monies.

Notwithstanding advice that under the new arrangements schools will be required to provide security to Block Grant Authorities for the protection of the Commonwealth's financial interest, the Committee remains to be convinced that the new arrangements will be sufficient. The Committee has recommended that the Department develop comprehensive guidelines which address the protection of the Commonwealth's interest, that it ensures schools receiving grants are aware of their obligations and that it seek legal advice as to its current capacity to enforce recovery action.

The Committee is also concerned about a lack of clearly defined objectives for the capital grants program. The Committee acknowledges that the Department had indicated in its guidelines for the new program that the Government's primary objective is to `improve educational outcomes in schools catering for students from low socio-economic backgrounds'. However, the Committee believes the Department should have a more comprehensive agreed statement of objectives as well as valid performance indicators with which to measure achievement of these objectives.

The Committee believes that the Department should also develop clear assessment procedures for determining eligibility for grants. Of particular concern was the need for standard methods for assessing schools' financial and socio-economic need, as well as for determining the relative importance of financial, socio-economic and educational need.

In the course of its inquiry, the Committee examined the proposed formula for distributing funds under the block grant arrangements. The Committee believes that the formula as proposed may produce anomalies. It may also be at odds with the Government's objective for the program. The Committee has recommended that the Department examine funding outcomes for schools of equal socio-economic status affiliated with different block grant authorities to ensure that anomalies do not result from the current formula.
I commend the reports to Senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a number of personal comments on the report in my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments about report 281 on the activities of the Committee from July 1986 to June 1987. In doing so, I acknowledge the work of a former Chairman of the Committee, Senator George Georges, whose resignation took place earlier this year. I thank him for his leadership, guidance and contribution to the work and status of this Committee. At the same time I wish the new Chairman, Mr Robert Tickner, the best of success in what I think will be a difficult and traumatic period for the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, today is a very sad day for our Public Accounts Committee because the wreckers have actually moved and taken away a lot of the physical resources and facilities that were enjoyed by this Committee. Earlier this year the Joint Committee of Public Accounts received notification that its secretariat was to be cut to one-third of its previous level. Today the staff are moving out. It is a sad day. This is a wrecking not by the Parliament but by the Executive arm of the Australian Labor Party. As a result, the capacity of the Committee to fulfil its statutory obligations to the Parliament and to the people of Australia will be seriously limited. We have now reached a point in our history where it is the obligation of the Parliament-which includes this Senate-to take the Executive to task for this state of affairs.

I remind the Senate that it is a feature of our system of government that a check be kept on executive government to ensure that it is complying with the wishes of the people and the Parliament. The Public Accounts Committee is a vital cog in this mechanism. It is becoming increasingly apparent that the actions of the Government are working to restrict the scrutiny operations not only of the Public Accounts Committee but also of other scrutiny organisations within the parliamentary realm. Indeed, this is to be deplored. At a time when the Hawke Government is finally coming to terms with the need to reduce government expenditure significantly, it is surely a very false economy to restrict the operations of bodies that can keep a check on inefficiencies and the wastage of public money.

I mention not only the Public Accounts Committee but also the Auditor-General. He now reports that, in rounds of talks with the Department of Finance prior to the Budget, the Australian Audit Office was persistently lobbied in an effort to extract a commitment for staff cuts to offset the recurrent costs of implementing information technology programs. I have made this linkage because to some people the Public Accounts Committee is the parliamentary arm of the Auditor-General. In his latest report the Auditor-General acknowledges the important work that has been done by the Public Accounts Committee. There is an inference in that report that the Auditor-General is somewhat concerned about the cut in our resources.

I reiterate my earlier comments-that cost savings measures are not appropriate in an area where considerable savings are actually generated for the Government in the form of greater efficiencies, loss prevention and improved standards of accounting and accountability. I think that one of the features of the Public Accounts Committee since I have been a member has been the upgrading of the standard of its stewardship and reporting to this Parliament. To constrain the activities of both the Public Accounts Committee and the Auditor-General is short-sighted in the extreme. They both have an integral role in guaranteeing that the public accountability obligations of government departments and instrumentalities are fully met. The importance of this function of democracy should not and cannot be overlooked.

Despite this the Department of Finance has made it clear to the Australian Audit Office, and the Government has made it clear by virtue of taking away our resources in such a draconian manner, that it is the Department's ambition to circumscribe the future exercise of the external audit function. Specifically, the Department has announced its intention to initiate a comprehensive review of the administration and work loads of the Australian Audit Office. What a cheek! That Office is supposed to be an independent arm responsible to the Parliament. Yet the Department of Finance has announced its intention to initiate a comprehensive review of the administration of work loads of the Australian Audit Office should additional resources be sought in the future. That is blackmail. The Department of Finance is trying to blackmail the Auditor-General's Office. That is a serious matter and I think it is one that must be taken up by all parties in this Parliament. I hope we can get some support from the Australian Democrats as well as from the more enlightened members of the Australian Labor Party.

Such a move would be in breach of the Auditor-General's statutory responsibilities to determine the manner in which the audit will be conducted. I believe it is a measure of the arrogance of this Government that a Minister would allow his Department to act in such flagrant disregard of statutory provisions. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the words of Barry Jones, a former distinguished member of our Public Accounts Committee-a member when, perhaps, it was in its heyday. These words were said in 1979 when he supported the extension of scrutineering functions of the Public Accounts Committee. I believe these comments are pertinent to the current debate. Mr Jones, who is now a member of the Australian Labor Party Executive, said:
If the Westminster system is to survive-
these are pretty dramatic words; what we are really seeing is a demise of our Westminster system in this Parliament today-
it must depend on two elements. Those two elements are `disclosure' and `accountability'.

The importance of the functions of both the Public Accounts Committee and the Australian Audit Office in facilitating this disclosure and accountability should never be lost sight of in the rush to fulfil commitments in other areas. By means of the Auditor-General's reports and the Public Accounts Committees' examination of them, the Parliament-this Senate and the House of Representatives-has been able to identify numerous areas of waste that have been an unnecessary drain on taxpayers' resources. In several reports alone these savings have actually amounted to millions of dollars a year. I suggest that we cannot afford to restrict the effective operation of the Australian Audit Office and the Public Accounts Committee or any other parliamentary body concerned with the scrutiny of public money.

A comment has been made in another forum concerning parliamentary scrutiny in another equally important area-defence and intelligence. The comment is still very relevant. If the price of liberty is eternal vigilance, then the price of parliamentary democracy is eternal scrutiny. I believe that we are losing some of the scrutiny as a result of what is happening. If we examine some of the other things that the Government is doing we find that it has failed to appoint the Ombudsman, has increased the fees applicable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, has cut resources to the Australian Audit Office and has reduced the effectiveness of the Public Accounts Committee. Yet it expects it to fulfil its major statutory roles for which it is accountable not to the Executive but to the Parliament itself. I acknowledge that the Executive branch of Government has decided to increase the number of committees in the House of Representatives. In doing so it is going to take resources from the other committees, which include the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, a very big and important committee. That Committee will lose resources, so I ask its members to speak up, too. The Public Accounts Committee, which had a staff of 15, is now expected to operate with the same number of staff as the House of Representatives committee that deals with Aboriginal affairs. That committee has a staff of five, whereas Senate committees in such limited areas can conduct their hearings very effectively with a staff of three. The House of Representatives committee on the environment, also has a staff of five and has the same classification as the Public Accounts Committee. Surely it is quite unfair to have disproportionate work loads for some committees compared with others.

I submit that very little thought has been given to the establishment and staffing of these committees. I acknowledge that Madam Speaker believes that we need additional staff. I also acknowledge that she has written to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). But I certainly hope that he is not going to follow the line that he took previously, because we believe that we need to operate with a staff of about 10. We are prepared to cut our cloth, we are prepared to trim our sails, in line with the need for reduced government expenditure, but we are not prepared to be annihilated and we are not prepared to lie down so that we cannot adequately discharge all our responsibilities to this Parliament and to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to make some remarks concerning the tabling of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts reports. Senator Watson has pointed out that he has tabled nine reports and that the volume of work that is carried out by the Public Accounts Committee is in pursuance of the statutory obligation that it bears. A perusal of report No. 28, the report of activities from 1986 to 1987, which for the most part predates my coming on to the Committee, means that I rise on this occasion with a degree of sadness.

SPEECH.PARA: I was proud to become a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It has been a strong, vigorous and important watchdog committee guarding the rights of the Parliament and therefore the rights of the people. But I am disappointed to have to report that this Committee is now under attack. In my view, an attempt is being made to stifle it and the attempt is being made on two counts. Senator Watson referred to the various standing committees which have been established in the House of Representatives and which by definition are committees peopled by only one-half of the Parliament, that is, the House of Representatives, with no senators. They are, therefore, more susceptible to Government pressure than is a committee which has members of this House as part of its membership. This means that these committees have been set up to compete for business with the Public Accounts Committee. Indeed, we have seen the decimation of the staff that has been hithertofore provided to the Public Accounts Committee. The creation of those House of Representatives committees is being used as the reason for that loss of staff-truly a catch-22 situation. The argument goes this way: there are nine new standing committees in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —All with Government majorities.

—All with Government majorities, as has been pointed out. The Government then said that parity of staffing would be the order of the day-five staff each. That means that the Public Accounts Committee has to lose staff. Let us look at how reasonable that statement is. Let us look at those nine committees. The Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, with a staff of five, has no business, no reference, no work to do. The Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee has a staff of five and no reference-no work to do. The Employment, Education and Training Committee has a staff of five with two references. The Community Affairs Committee has a staff of five with no references-no work to do. The Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs has a staff of four with one reference-little work to do. The Industry, Science and Technology Committee has a staff of five with no reference-no work to do. The Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee has a staff of five with one reference-little work to do. The Finance and Public Administration Committee has a staff of five and has taken over the efficiency audit concerning the Australian Taxation Office covering eight areas, an area which the Public Accounts Committee, under its statute, is obliged to deal with. The Committee on Procedure has a staff of two, with no reference and no business.

SPEECH.PARA: The result is that, of the nine competing committees, five have no reference and no work to do, yet between them have a staff of 25; two have one reference; and one has one reference plus. It is very disappointing to compare the work that those committees are supposed to be competing for with the responsibility that the Public Accounts Committee has under the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951. Under that Act it is charged with the examination of the accounts of the receipts and expenditure of the Commonwealth; with the examination of the financial affairs of authorities of the Commonwealth to which the Act applies and of intergovernmental bodies; and with the examination of all reports of the Auditor-General, including reports of the results of efficiency audits. Those reports have now been taken over, in a cursory manner, by one of the House of Representatives committees, but that in no way excuses or abrogates the responsibility that the Public Accounts Committee has. It is charged with reporting to both Houses of the Parliament-not one House-in any terms it sees fit, on any items or matters that it is deemed correct for that Committee to examine, in its judgment. It is to report to both Houses of the Parliament on any alteration which the Committee thinks desirable in the form of public accounts. It is to inquire into any connection with the public accounts which is referred to it by either House of the Parliament, and to report back to the Parliament. One such piece of business that we are currently pursuing is the purchase, or the proposed purchase, by the Taxation Office of automatic data processing equipment valued at some $700m. That is not something of a cursory nature; it is something that demands the closest scrutiny. Yet we in the Public Accounts Committee are left in a situation of not knowing whether the Executive arm of Government will choose to let that reference remain with the Committee.

Let us examine the effective work which the Committee has already carried out. The Medifraud reports could have been deemed embarrassing to the Government but, nonetheless, served the Parliament and the people well and resulted in fundamental changes, both in 1985 and 1986, in the health legislation amendment Acts. Another report carried out by the Public Accounts Committee concerned a Department of Finance report on the selection and development of senior management in the Commonwealth Public Service. The Government, in 1983, brought down a paper concerning the reforming of the Public Service and subsequent legislation reflected the reports that were brought down by the Public Accounts Committee.

Therefore, the question that we are really addressing today in having these reports tabled is this: Will the Parliament allow the important work of the Public Accounts Committee to be jeopardised? Will the Senate condone the accountability of the Government being forgone? I would point out that the Public Accounts Committee is but one of five prongs of attack against lack of accountability in government. We have seen stringent fees introduced under the Freedom of Information Act to make accountability more difficult. We have seen filing fees for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal increased to $240. No more the time when appealing against government decisions was within the reach of the ordinary man, such as the $2 fee that used to apply in the tax area. People now have to find the sum of some $240. The Ombudsman has not been re-appointed.

Then we come to the crucial question of the Auditor-General himself-the Auditor-General who is taking advantage of early retirement, the Auditor-General who pointed out the important interaction between his Department and the work of the Public Accounts Committee. I think it is important to quote the conclusions from his report:
Continuation of some recent trends could well see the AAO in for a turbulent time. I hope that this will not prove to be the case.

Ultimately, of course, it is for the community to determine whether the Commonwealth is to continue to have a robust, effective and independent external audit institution; or, perhaps, to make do with some sort of docile client of the Department of Finance. If it is to be the former, the pre-requisites are a strong and clear audit mandate, and resourcing arrangements that do not prejudice the institution's independence.

The Australian Financial Review, in its editorial on 1 December, picked up this theme and said that if we are to have a vigorous, robust, independent Auditor-General, he needs to be properly financed, but that if there needs to be a watch-dog for that watch-dog-that is, who is to police the Auditor-General?-it ought properly to be the Public Accounts Committee.

The Auditor-General's report is very valuable in that it brings home the interaction between the accountability procedures of the independent Auditor and the watch-dog status that the Public Accounts Committee exercises. We cannot afford, in a democracy, as Senator Watson ably said, to allow scrutiny to become a second-class function of the Parliament. It is my hope that the Senate, in paying attention to these reports and in hearing, perhaps, the pleas of those who speak on their tabling will result in the Senate, of its own initiative, taking some action which will result in the watch-dog remaining able to carry out its function.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Some little time ago in this place, following the tabling of the report of the Auditor-General, I addressed a question on a matter arising out of that report to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in the course of which I expressed some concern about the comments the Auditor-General had made relating to what he clearly believes-although his words were more modulated than perhaps mine will now be-to be an attempt by the Department of Finance, wholly supported by its Minister, to suppress the activities of the Office of the Auditor-General and to restrict the inquiry and accountability enforcement functions of that office.

SPEECH.PARA: In his response to me on that occasion, the Minister for Finance said that the Government, including himself, was wholly supportive of the functional independence of the Office of the Auditor-General, and of the statutory officer bearing the title, the Auditor-General himself, but that he, as Minister for Finance, and the Government were determined to ensure that when it came to financial provision for the Office of the Auditor-General to carry out its duties, then that office, like any other agency of the Commonwealth, would be subject to the control of the Executive.

With the procedures of this place I did not make an opportunity to point out to the Minister for Finance the obvious disjunction between the two points that he had raised, namely, the functional independence of the Office of the Auditor-General and the financial provision for that office, and the potential incompatibility of what he had said. It is impossible to go on asserting that one supports and will maintain the functional independence of the Office of the Auditor-General and the functional independence of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this Parliament but at the same time, by executive action, to deprive both those bodies of the resources, in particular the staffing resources, which are required to make good that functional independence. The claim of functional independence is, in short, hollow unless financial provision to an adequate degree is made to ensure that that functional independence can be maintained.

Earlier today, in speaking to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, which had been returned to this chamber from the other place after certain amendments had been required of the House of Representatives by the Senate, Senator Watson also remarked upon the position today of the Public Accounts Committee. This afternoon, when presenting these reports in his capacity as Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, he reiterated, very ably, a number of concerns which he then foreshadowed. Madam Acting Deputy President, in view of your occupancy of the chair at this time I take particular interest in the fact that it is ironic that Government senators, who have almost made a profession, even in the short time I have been here, out of criticising the Government of Queensland for the fact that, at present, it has no public accounts committee, now want to emasculate the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this Parliament. It is a nice irony and as I said, Madam Acting Deputy President, I make the point in your presence as it is particularly apt.

Although I am not aware whether any specific statement has been made on this subject by the present Premier of Queensland, I should be very surprised if we do not find, before very long, that Government senators are deprived of that refrain.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a statement.

—I thank Senator Hamer for reminding me that there has already been a statement of intention by the new Premier, Mr Ahern, in that regard. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts is a very particular committee of the Parliament. It is, first of all, a statutory committee in line with, I think, the Joint Committee of Public Works, and in that sense it is in a different category from the committees which are established under sessional orders of the Parliament. I venture to say, in the light of the evidence that the Government has so far given us of its attitude towards the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, that had it not been a statutory committee it would already have been a great deal more emasculated than it has been.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not possible for the Government, when it sought to bring about a major restructuring of the committee system, particularly of the House of Representatives, and, in an associated manner, of the Senate, to move in like manner on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts or, for that matter, the Joint Committee of Public Works because to do so would have required legislation. Although one can never be quite certain about the Australian Democrats on these matters, I venture to say that even that Party would not have given its assent to legislation to disembowel the Joint Committee of Public Accounts by legislative act, as a consequence of which the Government has fallen back upon executive act.

I said that this Committee was an historic committee of the Parliament. Professor F. A. Bland, who I think was its first Chairman or at least an early Chairman, brought to the operations of that Committee a standing and a prestige, and above all an intellectual attainment, which gradually forced the operations of that Committee, after its establishment, into the forefront of the watchdog activities of the Parliament. Over the years it has grown further in that watchdog role.

There are indeed two vital instruments of parliamentary control, of which the Auditor-General's office is one and the Public Accounts Committee is the other. The situation today, as Senator Watson has pointed out, is that the staffing of the Public Accounts Committee has been arbitrarily reduced by the Minister for Finance, by the Government, from its previous complement of 15 people to five people, on the totally false rationalisation that the other committees of the House of Representatives are granted only five staff and that therefore it is inappropriate for the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to be more numerously staffed-an argument which Senator Watson and Senator Bishop have between them so capably and comprehensively blown out of the water that I do not need to spend further time doing so.

I could speak at much greater length on this subject but, particularly in light of the general constraints on the time of the Senate at this time, I do not propose to do so. However, I want to stress to the Government side of the House that I and, I believe, all senators on this side of the House regard these developments in the working of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts as a very serious matter. It is not a matter of normal political controversy nor a matter on which there could be tenable views on the other side of the chamber different from those on this side. This is a matter concerning the functioning of the Parliament, and I put it to the Government side of the House that it concerns honourable senators on that side as much as it concerns honourable senators on this side. The fact that I emphasised the word `senators' in that context has to do with my distinction between senators on the one hand and Ministers of the Executive Government on the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I start by picking up the point which has just been made by Senator Stone, namely, that this is essentially a parliamentary rather than an Executive or indeed an Opposition matter. I am pleased, therefore, that it was raised originally by Senator Watson as a member of the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts and supported by Senator Bishop, who has the same role. The intervention by a number of others is simply meant to indicate to the Senate, and to the Government in particular, that we regard this matter very seriously and are concerned at the range of actions being taken by the Government at the moment to reduce the scrutiny of government which is undertaken by various bodies, of which the Public Accounts Committee is one.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to go over the ground which was very adequately covered by other senators. I simply adopt the description given by Senator Bishop of the five areas in which there are apparent reductions in the capacity of the Auditor-General, along with the Public Accounts Committee and other bodies, to subject the acts of government to critical scrutiny.

There are a couple of additional points worth making which were touched upon, perhaps lightly, in earlier comments. Senator Walsh has sought to excuse his actions in this matter by referring to the inescapable obligations of the Executive Government with respect to the raising of revenue and the appropriation of moneys. It is true that the executive government has a fundamental role in that, along with the Parliament. It is absolutely true that the government bears the odium of imposing taxes which are used to fund whatever activities government undertakes, including the activities of the Parliament itself. But whilst the Opposition will always give due consideration to the broader responsibilities of government, and would not seek to make claims on the public purse lightly or recklessly or without regard to the burden of taxation involved, it is a fact that wasteful government expenditure is a far more significant burden to taxpayers than is the cost of scrutiny. Indeed, it is the proper scrutiny of government that will avoid waste.

Let us take the example of the waste that we have been discussing with respect to the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract-the gross inefficiency, admitted by the Government, with respect to the letting of a contract. That is but one very recent example of a very costly error. There have been many which involve far larger sums, but I do not think I need to labour the point that governments can be extremely wasteful with respect to expenditure.

The work of the Public Accounts Committee is not partisan work. The Committee is not a partisan committee in a political sense. It is a committee in which all parties are engaged. Until recently it was under the chairmanship of former Senator George Georges who, however controversial in some of his political attitudes, performed his Public Accounts duties as a senator and as a parliamentarian and had the full support of senators and members from all sides. I stress the fact that this is not a partisan political issue. I am glad that Senator Button is now back in the chamber because the main reason I wished to speak was to say to the Government that at this stage precipitate action by the Opposition is not necessary, as the Committee and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) have taken up with the Government the need for greater resources for the Public Accounts Committee. We hope the Government will give rational and principled consideration to that request. However, if the Government fails to do that, I do not think that the Opposition can accept that and say that that is the end of the matter.

Having earlier this week passed a resolution through the Senate about a matter which we thought was important, namely, the treatment of ex-servicemen who have had the statute of limitations pleaded against them after the Government said that it would not plead the statute-and having heard the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) say in this chamber that the Government did not intend even to consider the resolution of the Senate-I have to say that I do not think it would be adequate for the Opposition simply to tackle this matter by saying, `We will pass a motion'. I am sure that the Australian Democrats would join with us on this because I think they would share the common parliamentary view that there should be adequate scrutiny of the Government's actions. I am sorry that there is no one here from the Australian Democrats to respond to this point, but I have little doubt, given their past attitude to staffing of Senate committees, that they would support us in that.

I put the Government on notice that, if it is not prepared to give reasonable and principled consideration to the needs of the Public Accounts Committee, it is certainly my current view that the Opposition should take action in one of the few ways available to us and should simply say to the Government that there are elements of its legislative program that we will not be prepared to consider and pass until adequate arrangements have been made for the staffing of that parliamentary committee. I have given the matter very careful consideration. I cannot see that we have any other sanction to offer. I therefore simply put the Government on notice that that is a sanction which we will give very serious consideration to using if we do not get a rational response from the Government. I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), to advise his colleagues that that is our view. I ask him also to encourage the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Finance to give early and sensible consideration to the request which has been made of them. I would ask the Minister to remember that this is not a matter of party politics and the Labor members and senators, just as much as Liberal or National senators and members, are fully engaged in performing a duty which is quite outside the partisan political duties which take up the bulk of our time in this Parliament. I for one would wish to see us doing that job efficiently and well. I hope that the Government will give very careful consideration to that matter and provide adequate resources to this and other organs of scrutiny of government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I respond by saying, to use Senator Chaney's terminology, that I will convey the message, and the Government will give principled and adequate consideration to the matters he raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time constraints on us all at the moment are very acute. Therefore I will be very brief and say just a few of the things I would like to have said. I wish to say a few words for two reasons. Firstly, I was a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts during my first two years in the Parliament, 1976 and 1977. I have had first-hand experience of that Committee, as one of its members, and that alone was sufficient for me to be very impressed with its significance and importance. Secondly, as has been said very well today by Senator Watson, Senator Stone, Senator Bishop and Senator Chaney, the matter at hand is of the very greatest importance because it goes to the whole root of the role of the Executive compared with that of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Accounts Committee had its genesis in the Westminster system. Its traditions go back into the last century. It is one of the great traditions of the Westminster system that we picked up here in Australia a long time ago. Indeed, before Federation there was a Public Accounts Committee in the colony of Victoria. Also, in the early years of the Federal Parliament there was a Public Accounts Committee. I think it first met in 1913. It was disbanded in the early 1930s as a so-called economy measure and was resurrected, as Senator Stone mentioned before, under the leadership of that very notable parliamentarian, Professor Bland. So we are not talking about just another committee. We are talking about one of the basic institutions of our parliamentary system. It is a basic institution for two particular reasons and, as I said, they relate to the role of the Parliament as opposed to the role of the Executive. Of all the things that Parliament ought to be concerned about, surely the prime one is the scrutiny of the operations of government on behalf of the people that the parliament represents. The Committee is all about scrutiny and therefore it is all about the accountability of the Parliament to the electors of Australia who have placed their trust in us politicians to conduct the affairs of government properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you attacking me?
—Not on this occasion, but the point is well taken.
—A Short point.

—I will take the point shortly, yes. To emasculate this basic committee of the Parliament for the reasons given seems really to be neither logical nor comprehensible. The Committee has developed its work very assiduously and very efficiently over the past decade or more. It is now an even more important forum than it was in the past. To argue that it ought to have its resources reduced from 15 to five for the sorts of reasons that have been advanced by the Government-that that is the level that ought to be applied to all committees-really seems downright nonsense. It makes no sense unless, quite frankly, other more sinister motives are involved in the whole thing. I rather have a feeling that that is perhaps not too far from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several reasons why the situation is very serious and why the secretariat of this Committee should not be reduced. They have been outlined very well up to date. I will not repeat them all. All I wish to reiterate in support of the comments made by other speakers on this side of the House is that we are not talking about just an economy measure or streamlining and equalising resources available to the Parliament; we are talking about the future of possibly the greatest watchdog committee that this Parliament has on behalf of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This attempt by the Government to undermine the effectiveness of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (PAC) is indeed sinister. I go further than my good friend and colleague Senator Short, who said that it may be sinister. I believe it certainly is. I believe it is part of a pattern of attack by an arrogant government on the capacity of the Parliament properly to supervise its activities. I must say that when this attack on the Public Accounts Committee's effectiveness is added to the other assaults and attempts to diminish the capacity of any element of this Parliament to withstand the Executive and to limit its power-when we see this attack in that context-the word `sinister' certainly is appropriate. We are only too well aware of the close link between the Public Accounts Committee and the Auditor-General. Of course, the Auditor-General is also under attack. The agenda of the Public Accounts Committee is not set by the Government but by the Committee itself and the ambit of the Auditor-General's reports.
—By statute.

—And as my friend Senator Watson says, by statute. So any attempt by the Government to limit the capacity of the Public Accounts Committee to follow its statutory obligations and to respond to the statements by the Auditor-General-particularly on efficiency audits in various areas-is, I believe, a matter of major significance and concern. This relationship between the Auditor-General and the Public Accounts Committee was raised in an editorial in the Australian Financial Review at the beginning of this month. It is interesting to note what the Australian Financial Review said. Mr Monaghan, the Auditor-General, had expressed grave concern about Budget moves to cut his staff to pay for a computer re-equipment program which he said would have `crippled' the Audit Office and were `in no uncertain terms . . . a usurpation of the Auditor-General's statutory responsibility to determine the manner in which the audit function is exercised'. The editorial went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Monaghan feels: ``it is for the community to determine whether the Commonwealth is to continue to have a robust, effective and independent external audit institution-or perhaps to make do with some sort of docile client of the Department of Finance''.
With the current Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), that would certainly be a disastrous situation. The Financial Review then concluded:
As the Audit Office is our watchdog against the power of the executive, we should watch very closely any attempt by governments to interfere with its actions.

There is no doubt that the Auditor-General and the Public Accounts Committee have been very effective in pointing out areas of disastrous mismanagement by this Government. For example, the Auditor-General exposed inefficiencies in the Australian Taxation Office, scandals in the administration of the $1.1 billion community employment program (CEP)-I might say that the Auditor-General followed the Waste Watch Committee in exposing scandalous waste under the CEP, as the Auditor-General followed the Waste Watch Committee in revealing scandalous waste on the new Parliament House program-and he also outlined the failure of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) to meet basic financial control requirements.

Clearly, the attack on the Auditor-General seems to be part of this attack on organisations which have a duty to limit, supervise and publicise inappropriate exercise of government power and incompetent administration.

One can well ask why Mr Monaghan, the Auditor-General, is retiring early. I do not know the reason, but I feel confident that, if he had had greater confidence in the willingness of this Government to listen to, act on and respond effectively to the Auditor-General's concerns, he might have taken a different view. There is no doubt in my mind that in many other areas the Government has set out deliberately to reduce the power of those who seek to limit the Government's exercise of its power.

Because of the attack on the freedom of information area, one has to pay a lodgment fee whenever one wants to get information under the freedom of information legislation. This Government demanded that I pay a $400 fee to get information, which should have been public information, on grants made under the CEP to various political groups, trade unions and front organisation groups. Those grants should never have been made; they were a disgrace. This Government sought to cover that up. By imposing charges on gaining information under the freedom of information legislation, it is seeking to limit access to such information. In some instances the filing fee for a matter to go before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal exceeds the amount in dispute, particularly in taxation cases. There has been a failure to replace the now retired Ombudsman, or to advertise for the position.

This is part of a pattern of attack on any organisation, any proper structure, which is there to limit the exercise of power. Any government which has been in office and has adopted the arrogant approach of this Government would naturally seek to limit the capacity of senators, members of parliament and the public who seek to limit the exercise of its power. This effort is the latest example of that arrogance and determination not to be held accountable.

I do not wish to speak to this amendment at great length. I have rehearsed many of the points previously. I believe that the instalment plan would go a long way towards solving many of the personally difficult areas which we have encountered regarding the overseas students charge, particularly the bad name that Australia is getting in many countries-not because we are not assisting them but because we are assisting them in such a way as to give rise to bad publicity in those countries. I visited Malaysia and Thailand recently and in both of those countries this problem was raised directly with me. Obviously it is of great concern to many people in government.

I turn now to the exemption of overseas students holding post-graduate scholarships from Australian universities and the Australian-American Educational Foundation and awards provided by Commonwealth departments or authorities. As I argued last year, when the measure was introduced for the first time, it is an extraordinarily short-sighted measure. What is the point of trying to attract overseas students through scholarships if we intend to discount severely their value by demanding that they pay a charge of the order of $6,000 or $7,000 out of a stipend of little more than $8,000? I believe that a relatively cheap exercise has taken place. The total amount of money is negligible. What we ought to do is exempt those scholarships from the payment so that we do not seek to attract people from a whole range of overseas countries when they find, on accepting the scholarship, that they are required to pay a visa fee which is sometimes only $1,000 less than the total award. It makes a mockery of our exercise of trying to assist many of those students in worthwhile graduate and post-graduate studies and it makes a mockery of our attempts in the international education arena to provide educational opportunities particularly to developing countries.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1987TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FRINGE BENEFITS AND SUBSTANTIATION) BILL 1987SALES TAX (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill and the Sales Tax (Off-shore Installations) Amendment Bill. I make it clear that the Opposition will not oppose the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4); we will move an amendment, the terms of which have been circulated in my name, to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill; and we will not oppose the Sales Tax (Off-shore Installations) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I want to do in relation to this collection of Bills is once again remark on their magnitude, on their sheer volume. I think I am correct in saying that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is some 75 pages in length, running to 92 clauses. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill 1987 is an even more massive piece of work of the draftsman, running to 146 pages and containing some 75 clauses. We see here a process whereby, because of the innate complexity of the existing taxation system, the need to add to that complexity by further amendments for the purpose of blocking loopholes or making changes at the margin continues apace. We have already reached the point-if we have not reached it we cannot be far way from it-where even the most knowledgable tax practitioner, leaving aside the ordinary citizen, must doubt at times whether he or she any longer has any real command over the totality of the tax law.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is particularly notable for the fact that it is the Bill which reintroduces to the tax law negative gearing in respect of investment in dwellings. Of course the Government never did restrict negative gearing in investment in shares or other forms of property. It simply had a view that somehow it was wrong to undertake investment in providing dwellings for rental to other Australians, and it moved to deny the appropriate taxation deductions for doing so.

At the time, the Opposition sought to point out to the Government the folly of its action in that regard-folly on two quite different counts. First as a matter of taxation principle, of fundamental approach to the tax law, when a taxpayer acquires assessable income from a return on property, whether it be interest, dividends, or rent, as in this case, it is appropriate that expenditure necessarily incurred in the production of that income be a deduction from the income to be assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation. That, of course, is the principle followed throughout the tax law, including in the case of companies which earn profits. But to the extent that the earning of those profits requires them to borrow, the costs of that borrowing become, quite properly, a deduction in the accounts of a company when arriving at its assessable income as distinct from its gross profit.

The Government's action of introducing its so-called anti-negative gearing provisions was therefore a breach of that fundamental principle of taxation law. The Government justified that breach on the ground, as it argued, that some investors were building or purchasing dwellings for rental. These investors applied the interest costs of the borrowings involved against the income from those dwellings, thereby in many cases showing a negative net income. Nevertheless, those taxpayers-and this was the Government's argument at the time-were able, perhaps some years later, to dispose of their dwelling investments at an increased capital value and to retain the capital difference without its being subjected to taxation, since at that time no capital gains tax existed in Australia. The fact that in this measure the Government was singling out one area of investment-namely, an investment in dwellings-for this particular form of treatment, not so much as a means of imposing capital gains tax by the back door but as a means of preventing or dissuading people from seeking capital gains in that area of the economy, appeared not to occur to the Government at the time. However, it was pointed out very strongly by the Opposition at the time the Government made that error.

The second reason, of quite a different kind, why the Government's decision to introduce its so-called anti-negative gearing provisions in relation to rental dwellings was flawed was that, by discriminating against that particular form of investment, without the slightest doubt it laid the basis for a decline in investment in that area of the economy. Clearly, it stands to reason that, if investors have alternatives in areas in which to invest and one particular form of investment is subject to a harsher taxation administration than the rest, investment capital will tend not to flow to the first avenue. That is precisely what occurred in this instance, as was predicted by the Opposition at the time. One does not need to be a Rhodes scholar to work that out, but I leave that to the Senate to decide. It was obvious to all concerned at the time that that would be the outcome, and indeed it was.

I suppose that one must give some credit to the Government for at least finally seeing the error of its ways and moving to correct its original error. Of course, that error was not costless to the Australian community, in the sense that, while the provision was in force-and I do not necessarily attribute these results entirely to that provision, although it obviously had a very considerable influence-there was a major decline in the dwelling construction industry in Australia, particularly in the area of rental dwellings. By definition it was not the owner-occupier who was disadvantaged by the anti-negative gearing provisions: rather, it was those who sought rental dwellings for occupancy and who suddenly found the new supply of such dwellings drying up and the existing stock being affected by gradual sale in the normal course of events. Naturally, the Opposition welcomes the return to sanity in this area of the taxation law but, in so doing, one must note that this episode was very costly to the Australian dwelling industry and, more particularly, to the people seeking rental dwellings who suddenly found the supply drying up.

With a New South Wales election looming in the not too distant future, the problems of the rental dwelling market in Sydney became so acute that this Government's friends and associates in the Unsworth Government brought their views very forcibly to bear on the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in order to bring home to him the severe political consequences for the Labor Government of New South Wales if that very serious error of judgment, for which he had been responsible and which the Government had endorsed, was not rectified. Rectified it has been and, as I said, the Opposition welcomes that fact.
I now turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill 1987. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

``, but the Senate expresses its objection to the Labor Government's iniquitous fringe benefits tax while noting that a more efficient and equitable revenue collection system requires that obvious tax avoidance procedures, where benefits are not related to legitimate business activities, must be adequately dealt with''.

I make my position and that of the Opposition on this subject crystal clear. I suppose that no one would have deplored more strongly than I, particularly in my earlier career not far from here, any suggestion that taxpayers in this country were avoiding the payment of tax in any illegitimate manner. In that connection, no one would have deplored more strongly the presence of elements of the tax law which had given rise to what I can only call dubious procedures in what has come to be called the fringe benefits area. It is true that for many years the Income Tax Assessment Act has contained a provision-I think section 26 (e)-which confers on the Commissioner of Taxation the widest possible authority to tax everything in the fringe benefits area. The problem was not a very large one, but over the years it mushroomed, originally making it very difficult for the Commissioner of Taxation to police that provision in an effective manner.

However, it is worth noting in passing why that problem mushroomed in the way that it did. If one understands the reasons for that outcome, without condoning it, one will understand a great deal more about what is wrong with the taxation system in this country and why it has become increasingly necessary to begin to reform that system in a serious manner and not merely to talk about it, as this Government has become so proficient at doing. The major reason that the fringe benefits industry grew to the magnitude that it undoubtedly did was the extraordinarily high marginal tax rates applying in this country and the extraordinarily low levels of income at which very high marginal tax rates had begun to cut in.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the failure of the Taxation Office to police the Act.

—Senator Watson reminds me that it also had to do with the failure of the Commissioner of Taxation or the Australian Taxation Office to police the Act. To a degree I go along with that comment from Senator Watson, although, perhaps in line with the implication of my earlier remarks, I have to say that the magnitude of the problem had become so great that it would have required an army of taxation assessors or auditors, or whatever they are called these days, to do that to the degree which eventually became necessary. The fundamental reason for the growth of the fringe benefit industry was, as I said, the fact that income tax rates had become very high and had begun to become very high at relatively low levels of income. Naturally, and I think totally predict- ably, that put strains upon the tax system and upon the system of remuneration, which led to employers entering into compacts with their employees to remunerate them more and more in non-monetary forms of income but in ways that were acceptable to the employees.
