While many of these arrangements initially were perfectly proper exercises in formulating agreements between employers and employees, it is undoubtedly the case that over time there grew up a certain sleaziness about this particular industry which members of the Opposition deplore no less than, as we are continually told, members of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's response to this situation was not to deal with the root cause, not to address the situation of very high marginal tax rates and not to address the fact that, after all, these benefits were being received by employees. They were not being received by employers, although no doubt employers were benefiting from them as well, otherwise they would not have entered into them. The employers were benefiting in the sense that they were able to pay in net effective terms lower total rates of remuneration to their employees. The Government ignored both of those fundamental considerations. It moved to do very little about the basic problem of our income tax structure. It is true that over a period of, I think, 12 months the top marginal tax rate has been moved down from 60c to 49c-indeed, 50.25c if one includes the Medicare levy-and there have been similar movements in the other marginal rates. It is also true that these marginal rates, nevertheless, remain extraordinarily high. Therefore, they continue to provide, quite predictably, a set of incentives for people to enter into these arrangements.

Although evidence on the matter is still fragmentary, nevertheless the volume of such evidence is still growing. I think I am correct in saying that in the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation, which was tabled in this place not so long ago, one finds reference to evidence that the Commissioner has so far assembled suggesting that in many areas of the fringe benefits industry the actual number of fringe benefits being given by employers has not been reduced to a great degree. I think the number has been reduced in all cases, but the degree of reduction has varied significantly, except in one or two cases where there has been a major reduction. No doubt from the point of view of the Commissioner of Taxation that is welcome.

That is my first point. The Government in seeking to rectify what was on all sides agreed to be a serious problem, did not, first of all, significantly address the basic reason for that problem, namely, the very high level of marginal tax rates. Secondly, the Acts which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his Government introduced in this area did not address the fact that these benefits were, after all, received by individuals, by employees, but sought instead to penalise the employers for the fact that these benefits were given. The fallacy in that approach is also evident from the facts that I cited a moment ago in relation to my first point. Under the circumstances, employers are between the devil and the deep blue sea. I do not wish to refer to one of my previous colleagues, the present Commissioner of Taxation, as the devil; nevertheless, that particular mephistophelian figure represents to employers to some degree the figure standing in the background who forces them to pay tax upon the benefits they offer their employees. One might say that the employer has a very ready remedy to avoid that particular satanic figure: he can simply cease to provide the fringe benefits.

Although I could cite many such examples, I shall give the Senate one example at random: what happened when the banks in this country sought to remove from their employees the long-standing fringe benefit of so-called low interest loans. That benefit has been extensively available to employees throughout the banking industry for decades. Indeed, that benefit is available extensively not only to employees throughout the banking industry but also to employees throughout the finance industry generally. At that time the Australian Bank Employees Union brought the strongest pressure to bear upon the Australian Bankers Association, and more particularly the banking employers concerned, by threatening the gravest and most widespread industrial action if any such action were carried out. The result has been that nothing much of the kind has been done. The banks for the most part have simply maintained the benefits in being. I think from memory they have effected some minor reduction in the cost of those benefits to them by slightly increasing the low interest rates provided. But, for the most part, those benefits remain as they were. That, so to speak, is the deep sea on the other side of the employers concerned in this case. As I said, that example could be multiplied.

The reason why that was the outcome was, as the Opposition said at the time, that the Government's measure in this area was directed not at the recipient of the benefit, not at the employee, but at the employer. Therefore, the employee is untouched by the law. The employee can in fact still obtain the benefit and is not affected by the law; he is not the person who is affected by the fringe benefits tax arrangements. It is the employer who is affected by those arrangements and who pays tax on the emoluments-on the non-monetary emoluments, if that is what they are-involved.

Let me go on from there lest it be inferred that the Opposition in any way endorses or continues to support the status quo ante. We never did and we do not now. At the last Federal election the Opposition demonstrated that its policies were superior to those of the Government in one particular respect; and there has been some debate in recent days about that. The Opposition made it very clear that had it been elected to government-and, regrettably, it was not-it would certainly have abolished the fringe benefits tax and, equally certainly, it would have put in its place taxation provisions which were specifically directed to blocking the rorts-a favourite word of the Treasurer-which had grown up under the system which previously obtained. The Opposition had also made it clear that where benefits were related to legitimate business activities-subject perhaps to various forms of ceiling in order to provide additional safeguards and controls-it would remove the fringe benefits tax and deal with the matter through, in effect, making section 26 (e) of the Act, appropriately amended and enhanced, operative in a way in which it had ceased to be operative for many years previously.

The last of the three Bills with which we are dealing today is the Sales Tax (Off-shore Installations) Amendment Bill 1987. That also is a Bill of some complexity. Questions have been raised about it in the debate in another place, but at this hour and given the pressures upon the time of the Senate, I simply repeat that the Opposition will not oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills that is before us today consists of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill 1987 and the Sales Tax (Off-shore Installations) Amendment Bill 1987. Unlike Senator Stone, it is my intention to concentrate mainly on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which is notable for its reintroduction of negative gearing for rental properties.

SPEECH.PARA: In the two years since negative gearing was removed from property investment or speculation, the Government appears to have had a remarkable change of heart. In 1985 and 1986 the Hawke Government described the negative gearing of rental property as a tax rort-a tax shelter which gave the biggest tax break to investor landlords who had the highest incomes and faced the highest marginal tax rates. Of course, negative gearing enabled these sorts of people to borrow heavily to buy a property, to run the property at a loss essentially so that the interest on borrowings exceeded the return from rental, and to use that loss to reduce their tax liability from other income sources. It was a nice little system, particularly when there was no capital gains tax operating in this country, for those people on substantial incomes to reduce their taxation through this form of investment and later get a tax free capital gain.

The Treasury's Draft White Paper on Reform of the Australian Taxation System in 1985 substantiated the justice and equity for disallowing negative gearing for rental property by showing that in 1982-83, 14 per cent of individuals would have had taxable incomes of over $100,000 if negative gearing had then been disallowed, while fewer than 2 per cent would have had taxable incomes below the then average wage. So that White Paper quite clearly indicated that negative gearing was of benefit only to those who had potential taxable incomes of over $100,000 and who were using the system to diminish their tax liability quite considerably. Of course, in this year's Budget the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the reintroduction of negative gearing for rental property, having apparently seen some kind of light that was not there for him in 1985-86.

He gave two justifications for this massive somersault. Firstly, he argued that since negative gearing-that is, borrowing to acquire assets and using the cost of the borrowing to reduce a tax liability acquired from other income earned-is allowed on other activities, such as share purchases, the disallowance of negative gearing for rental property merely encouraged investors to negatively gear other transactions, such as share purchases, to achieve a similar tax benefit. Having watched the spectacular lack of success of a number of people in speculation on the stock market, I would have thought that, rather than removing negative gearing in the property market and allowing it to remain in the area of share purchases and so on, the Government would have removed it from the area of share speculation as well, having realised that all it was doing was encouraging speculation. So the strategy would have been far better put into effect if the Government had disallowed negative gearing on other transactions, instead of using the existence of it in that form as a reason to reintroduce it to property speculation. Instead of giving up an estimated $24m this year, rising to $80m next year, to enable those on the highest incomes to acquire a property and reduce their tax bills, this Government could have kept that revenue and added to it substantially by abolishing the general practice of negative gearing.
In a recent issue of Australian Society an article outlined the cost of tax shelters created by our tax system. It stated:

If the same negative gearing restrictions as were introduced for rental real estate had been applied to purchase of company shares, annual tax collections would have been at least $1 billion higher annually.

The author then went on to argue that the figure might well range as high as $2 billion. Instead, we have a Labor government reducing the living standards of average and low income Australian households while restoring the rorts of the rich that it took away only two years ago. In this it is supported, as it is in most other things, by an Opposition which is reportedly planning to cut up to $7 billion from assistance programs to the unemployed, the sick, widows and sole supporting parents as part of its radical Budget agenda for the 1990s-at least that is if we believe the reports in the Australian of last November.

The second reason that the Treasurer gave for reintroducing negative gearing-giving this rort back to the already well off-was that by restoring negative gearing the Government would ease the rental crisis, particularly in Sydney, which, quite coincidentally, happens to be the centre of an election next year for a State government. It would ease the rental crisis and somehow-in some unstipulated way-provide affordable accommodation for currently homeless or low income Australians. So from an equity point of view the Government is giving away $104m over the next two years with most of it going to the wealthiest Australians, without being able to guarantee that that money will be used to alleviate the housing problem faced by the poorest Australians. Why? Because negative gearing applies equally to people who invest their large amounts of income in luxury apartments as to those providing low cost rental accommodation. It does not take a giant IQ to work out that if somebody wants to make a capital gain and get a secure investment that will appreciate, either in the long term or the short term, the benefits for that person will not derive from investments in low income properties. In fact, the Government should have insisted that the money it was saving in removing the negative gearing rort was put into the public housing sector, which would have directly and accurately targeted the money towards solving the problem that has become something of a crisis for low income families.

Instead, in the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless the Government has decided to squander money on subsidising the rents and incomes of the wealthy rather than using it to provide affordable accommodation for low income Australians through rental subsidies, through the provision of more public housing or through joint ventures with the private sector to provide affordable public housing. In an article in the Melbourne Age on 17 September of this year, Bishop Peter Hollingworth, the Executive Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, accurately described this decision to restore negative gearing for rental property as providing a tax shelter for rental investors but little or no gain for low income tenants. He believed, quite rightly, that the money could have been and should have been better used to expand the work of public housing authorities. Not surprisingly, the Tenants Union of Victoria said:
The whole scheme will just bring more buyers into the market. Those with money to spend will be fine. But first home buyers will find themselves forced to rent again.

Within days of the announcement of the reintroduction of negative gearing we saw property prices go up in the major capitals and advertisements in the real estate sections of Australia's major newspapers, particularly Saturday morning newspapers, gleefully indicating that negative gearing was being reintroduced and that the investors could come back into the market. I might add that the advertisements were not aimed at selling homes in the low price range but were aimed at getting investors to purchase units and homes for rental in the much higher brackets. So there occurred almost immediate rises in house prices. This, of course, means higher mortgages and higher rents. Many tenants are going to be forced out of their arrangements and into accommodation of a lesser standard if that occurs.

The Government should be pouring money into housing and assisting low income earners instead of turning that assistance towards investors. It is another clear example of how this Government is turning its back on social welfare and encouraging corporate welfare at a time when there are increasing numbers of people in poverty and increasing numbers of families with large numbers of children living in poverty. Julian Disney, responding to the Budget on behalf of the Australian Council of Social Service, said:
Tax changes directed to private rental market are not well targeted.
Abolition of the prohibition on negative gearing for housing investment is likely to stimulate investment only at the top end of the market.

In New South Wales a spokeswoman for the Housing Information and Referral Service said that the 67,000 applicants on the New South Wales public housing waiting list would not be helped by the return of negative gearing. She said:

The fact the Hawke government is willing to allow landlords to virtually steal $150m of government revenue in order to secure the tax rort of negative gearing clearly showed their lack of concern for those in housing need.
Public housing waiting lists in New South Wales are going to go through the roof.

Whether that has happened in the ensuing couple of months I am not aware, but obviously the return of negative gearing in this area is not going to help the accommodation needs of those individuals and families on low incomes, particularly those in poverty.

What has the Federal Government done to public housing in the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless? Precious little is the answer to that question. In 1986-87 the Commonwealth made $584.7m available to the States to spend on public housing. This year, allegedly a year of some significance as far as shelter for the homeless is concerned, it made available about $385.6m; that is, it cut funding and, on top of that, reintroduced negative gearing-a quite spectacular lack of sensitivity to the international year that we are currently in.

This Bill also reduces from 4 per cent to 2.5 per cent the annual rate of deduction available for capital expenditure on the construction of new income producing buildings with effect from 16 September 1987. Investors are no better off than they were pre-1985 and government coffers are even further depleted. The introduction of the 4 per cent deduction for capital expenditure on the construction of new income producing assets was in part at least compensation for the abolition of negative gearing. It was designed to encourage the production of new commercial, industrial and residential property when negative gearing was removed. One is forced to wonder why, when negative gearing was reintroduced, the 4 per cent was not removed altogether. Instead, it has been reduced from 4 per cent to 2.5 per cent to provide a revenue saving to compensate for the revenue loss of reintroducing negative gearing, estimated to cost something like $24m in 1987-88 and $80m in 1988-89.

The reduction in the write-off rate for the new income producing buildings is estimated to save $3m in 1988-89, over $500m after 25 years, money which, I point out, would be better spent over that period on providing affordable housing for low income Australians, a group of people who are quite clearly bottom of the list of priorities not only as far as the Opposition parties are concerned, which is only to be expected, given their commitment to New Rightist policies and the advancement of the wealthy, but also to this Labor Government, which for years chirped merrily that it was the only political party that was ideologically sound as far as social and economic policies were concerned.

The legislation will also close a loophole which, as in another area, of course, allowed foreign investors to provide a low capital base for their investment in an Australian company and to provide more working capital in the form of interest bearing loans. This is aimed at preventing income generated in Australia from being taken out of the country as the deductible interest payment, subject only to a 10 per cent withholding tax. That is all the Australian Government imposes-a 10 per cent withholding tax. This move by the Government is something that the Democrats have been calling for for a long time, and indeed we commend the Government for finally closing off this loophole. It certainly is not speedy in acting to close off some of these loopholes, particularly those involving foreign investors.

The legislation essentially will restrict the interest deduction for foreign investors who gear their Australian investments over a prescribed debt equity ratio of 6 : 1 for financial institutions or 3 : 1 for other investments, and it is expected to save at least $50m in revenue. As I said, that is something that we welcome. At the time that the Treasurer foreshadowed this legislation I put out a statement indicating that the Democrats had in fact been insisting for several years that the Government move to close off tax avoidance loopholes under which foreign companies operating in Australia have avoided tax through balance-sheet manipulation of prices, profits and intercompany borrowings.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats I welcome this legislation as a belated admission by the Government that, first of all, tax revenue which is currently lost because corporations exploit tax avoidance loopholes should be recouped and, secondly, that this revenue can be recovered by a government prepared to legislate to close those loopholes. The legislation will apply where a foreign investor or associate who can trace 15 per cent or more equity in an Australian enterprise also makes an interest bearing loan or its equivalent to that enterprise and the debt amount exceeds either three or six times the amount of equity, depending on the system that is operating. If the Government is prepared to close this loophole, I am surprised that it is not prepared to take up the Democrats' suggestion of closing a few other loopholes, which would guarantee still more revenue and make a far more equitable economic system than the one we currently have.

It is high time governments and others acknowledged that corporate welfare is, as I said, alive and well in this country, while all and sundry are trying to kick social welfare to death. It seems that this Labor Government, which is supposed to be assisting those who are in need, is spending more of its time ensuring that the wealthy get wealthier without doing anything to provide assistance to those who are on low incomes or who are struggling for one reason or another. I would have thought that closing off some more of those loopholes, such as the one that the Government has moved to end in this legislation, thereby raising additional revenue, would have been a better alternative than doing things like taxing milk products, postponing the indexation of pension increases, introducing tertiary fees, trying to throw an ID card down all our throats or cutting funding for public housing.

So, in a spirit of economic generosity, I therefore suggest to the Government that it look at, for example, taxing superannuation and life funds that chose to invest the savings for Australians overseas. There is a very good argument that the cost of the present superannuation tax shelter is about $5 billion annually. The superannuation tax concessions, as with negative gearing, provide the biggest benefit to those on highest incomes. There is no reason at all why the big superannuation and life funds should retain their tax-free status when they invest off-shore, depleting this country of investment and internal revenue which it desperately needs.

The Government could also look at abolishing negative gearing for companies that borrow overseas to take over existing Australian companies, transactions which increase our foreign debt, which is now over $107 billion and of which in excess of 60 per cent is owed by the private sector. We are all being told to tighten our belts because of the level of foreign indebtedness that is largely the responsibility of our home grown corporate raiders with the enthusiastic co-operation of a so-called Labor Government. They borrow overseas, add to our foreign debt and, through negative gearing, they reduce, if not actually wipe out, the profits of the company they take over. They are then in a position to diminish considerably their tax liability and, in doing so, diminish the amount of money in Consolidated Revenue that the Government has to put into the services that Australians deserve and need. So we have a modern Labor Party Government that seems to be specialising in helping the already well off, while expecting the average and low income Australian family to tighten its belt and to be punished, in effect, for the economic problems that have been caused largely by the corporate sector.

The Government might also like to turn its attention to transfer pricing, particularly given the recently released report from the Auditor-General. During the election campaign, as well as prior to it, I raised something that was raised again recently by the Director of the Australian Taxpayers Association, namely the fact that the use of overseas tax havens is costing the nation at least $1 billion in annual revenue. Transfer pricing essentially involves the abuse of current tax law which exempts from local tax income derived by non-residents of Australia. Companies and trusts established abroad are used to shift profit-taking activities by Australian companies to subsidiaries and related companies in low tax countries. Paragraph 2.6 of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report makes the following point:

An indication of the significance of tax havens and the magnitude of the problem they pose for tax authorities can be gleaned from the amount of foreign deposits currently held by banks in six of the major tax havens namely, Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Singapore, the Bahamas and Hong Kong. These six countries together currently hold approximately $1,000 billion of foreign deposits in nominated bank accounts for non-residents.

So the use of tax havens as a way of diminishing tax payments, and hence reducing a government's consolidated revenue, is certainly alive and well and flourishing. Paragraph 2.10 of the Auditor-General's report states:

Transfer pricing is a method of reducing a corporation's total tax liability through the manipulation of prices between countries with differing tax rates and legislation so as to realise the largest proportion of profit in the country with the most favourable tax regime. It can also be a method used by corporate management to facilitate other management objectives . . .
The report stresses the fact that transfer pricing is primarily intended to ensure that taxes and duties are minimised. Paragraph 2.15 states:

Transfer pricing is facilitated through the use of associated corporations overseas and tax havens. The potential impact of transfer pricing on Australian sourced profits and therefore on taxation revenue is indicated by the significant value of Australia's international trade conducted between associated corporations. Statistics issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for 1984-85 reveal that approximately 30 per cent of total Australian import and export trade, valued at $17,571 million in that year, was conducted between Australian branches and subsidiaries of foreign companies on the one hand and their foreign parent and related companies abroad on the other.
Paragraph 2.16 states:

These statistics do not reflect the volume of trade conducted between Australian owned enterprises and their subsidiaries and related companies abroad, nor do they include transactions of the banking sector. Inclusion of such data would undoubtedly establish that an even greater proportion of total Australian imports and exports of goods and services, now estimated by Audit to be in excess of $20,000 million annually, is conducted through intra-corporate trade. There is, in Audit's view, little doubt that transfer pricing associated with such trade results in very significant losses of taxation revenue.

And still the Government makes no move to close off this loophole. The Commonwealth Auditor-General, in his report, also estimated that more than 40,000 companies may be avoiding tax by shifting profits off-shore. The 40,000 companies identified by the report account for more than 30 per cent of Australia's overseas trade. Through the use of overseas parents and subsidiaries these companies have the potential to minimise their total tax on world-wide earnings through profit shifting. Yet, with 45,000 corporations known to be in a position to shift profits, the Australian Taxation Office conducted only 251 international audits in 1985-86. Although the Taxation Office obviously is increasing its audits of large companies and this is netting some more revenue to the Government, it is a lengthy process, assisted by the low tax countries which have well developed structures and financial institutions to facilitate tax avoidance.

The Government must lift the withholding tax from 10 per cent to something closer to the current company tax rate of 49 cents in the dollar if it is really serious about putting an end to tax rorts. Not only is it not doing this, but also it is not taking the sorts of steps necessary to collect all the revenue that is due and necessary to provide the services that Australians need.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) facilitates yet another means by which corporations can reduce their tax liability. It does so through the amendments to the group loss provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act in clauses 16, 42, 44 and 45 of this Bill. I do not have time to go into the workings of this system. Suffice it to say that it is predicated on the use of shelf companies, usually set up by a firm of solicitors, specifically to be sold. It is a rort that ought to be ended rather than facilitated. In other words this Government is continuing in the main to facilitate corporations to seek to reduce their tax liability. In doing so it is denying itself revenue. Given the enthusiastic way in which the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Treasurer are cutting funds to the needy in order to balance the Budget, it is extraordinary that the Government is prepared at the same time to deny itself revenue by allowing to continue to exist a variety of tax rorts that it should have clamped down on in 1985 and must pay considerably more attention to in the next year or so if Australia is to have a truly equitable taxation system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is something almost disgusting about the desperate search of the Australian Democrats for some kind of constituency, particularly when their rhetoric is aimed, I must say almost deliberately, at damaging the economic basis of the economy, driving more and more people, for example, into public housing rather than private housing and diminishing the ability of Australian corporations to compete with their rivals overseas. We have heard a litany of the same sort of nonsense that we have heard consistently and which would be massively damaging to the whole of the fabric of Australian society. But, of course, it is aimed at the cheap purchase of some votes in order to keep their party, which is always desperately searching for some constituency, capable of maintaining at least some representation in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: That was a ludicrous speech by Senator Haines. To attempt to attack the return of negative gearing in the way she did was to miss one essential point, which at no stage did she address in her speech; that is, that with negative gearing one provides an incentive for the private sector to provide in the end the great bulk of the funds involved in building new homes. Senator Haines wants the public sector to undertake the total burden, which would mean that, under her ludicrous scheme,. we would get a tiny fraction of the number of houses built that we would get by providing a financial incentive for the private sector to build them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense.

—That simple economic fact is never allowed to intrude itself into the narrow and self-seeking political position of the Australian Democrats, who come here and lower the nature and standard of debate in this chamber--
—Why don't you look at the figures?
—Order!

—They lower the standard and nature of the debate in this chamber by consistently seeking to appeal, if I may say so, to those Australians who cannot recognise reality and who are unaware of the fact that every prescription by the Australian Democrats would lead to disaster-in this case would lead to a reduction, and has led to a reduction, in the volume of housing available.
—Absolute nonsense. Why don't you look at the figures?
—Order! There are far too many interjections.

—The incredible incompetence of the Australian Democrats in almost all matters economic is self-evident. The facts speak for themselves. But it is interesting to see that at last we have managed to convince the Australian Labor Party that it was equally incompetent. I remind the Senate of what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in 1985 about negative gearing, which he was then abolishing. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot believe that any leader of a major party would come into this Parliament and seek to have restored one of the most blatantly abused tax shelters in the system . . . To try to defend this behaviour, this outrageous rort, on the basis that it helps some renters is extraordinary. The great majority of rental properties are not affected by negative gearing and negative gearing has not succeeded in providing an adequate number of rental properties.

That was the Treasurer in 1985, sounding like an Australian Democrat. He has now found out what economic reality is all about and has been obliged to change his mind. He was totally wrong. The Democrats persist with their nonsensical view in an attempt to win some votes from people who respond with their hearts instead of their minds. That seems to me to be the only motive of the Democrats in this area. The sort of nonsense that the Treasurer was speaking before has now, clearly, been replaced by a recognition of what economic reality is all about. That is why we now have the Treasurer changing his stand.

I believe that this was one of the issues on which he was pushed over the top by the Australian Taxation Office which, quite frankly, is now getting a bit out of control. I am glad to see the Treasurer now moving back and trying to restore some sanity. I must say that I am greatly concerned about that issue, which I will raise in a minute. But I would just like to say one other thing specifically about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which is to stress the Opposition's support for the averaging of income for artists, writers, sportsmen and other people who have highly variable incomes on a yearly basis.

There are some people who continue to be unfairly treated in this matter. They are not high income earners; they are low income earners who, for example, as a result of a court action-I have one particular case in mind-receive back pay for say a year and a half or two years. They receive the back pay in one lump sum and end up paying tax on it at an extraordinarily high rate because the Taxation Office adopts the view that that salary has been received in that year and should be taxed at that year's rate. I know the situation of a former warder in the New South Wales prison system. He was not on a high salary. He had a two and half year fight, which he won in the end through the courts, for back pay. He was taxed at a rate that was absurdly high because he was taxed as though that income had been earned in one year.

If it is good enough for the Tax Office and the Treasurer to allow averaging for sportsmen and so on, why can it not apply the same principle to people who, through no fault of their own, have been massively inconvenienced, find that their earnings are lumped in this way and taxed grossly unfairly? I notice in another part of the Bill that the Government, presumably on the advice of the Taxation Office, is taking the view that the Office should look at some income as it accrues. The explanatory memorandum to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) state:
. . . to make clear that the investment return on certain financial instruments described as annuities is taxable as it accrues . . . rather than when it is received . . .

If the Government is prepared to bend this principle when it suits it so that tax is paid only when income is received, why cannot it bend it when it is to the advantage of some income earner who is being massively disadvantaged by what I believe to be a quite improper exercise of the taxation power? I hope that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), will take this up and that we will not see the Treasurer and the Taxation Office continue to take positions which are to the disadvantage of taxpayers and to the advantage of the Office.

I must say that that is one of the pleasant factors in the legislation. There are many items in this huge collection-I think it is 140 pages of legislation, or something enormous-which correct situations which have acted to the disadvantage of taxpayers. That is a welcome move. But I must say that it comes in a context of what seem to me to be continual problems with the Tax Office, which seems, as I said earlier, to be getting a little out of control. This bureau- cracy, which has the commendable motive of maximising the proper collection of tax, seems to me to have very little awareness or concern of the consequences of what it does. I quote, for example, this week's news:

New Tax Office rules may increase sales tax by 10 per cent on a wide range of consumer goods and will drastically alter accounting practices for retail stores, increasing pressure for price rises to cover the additional costs.
The Australian Financial Review had a large item on this matter this week. It said:

The new rules, released a week ago, are further evidence of the gung-ho approach of the new tax regime in Canberra, which increasingly regards practices which minimise tax as arrangements to avoid tax.
It went on:
. . . the Tax Office believed that it was losing revenue in the sales tax area and it had to tighten the application of the law.
Tax accountants are highly critical of the new rules which they argue are preventing arrangements that have been accepted or even recommended by the Tax Office for the past nine years.

What is happening is that Mr Boucher is in effect introducing a rule of thumb for imputing the value of goods subject to sales tax in those instances where the wholesaler is in fact associated with the retailer. The reality, of course, is that this is yet another example of the Tax Office increasing costs and working to the disadvantage of efficiency. These non-arm's length companies were introduced only to prevent a grossly unfair situation from persisting. What normally happens is that the customer buys goods from the retailer. The retailer has bought them from the wholesaler. Tax is paid at that point of sale between the retailer and the wholesaler. Of course, when the wholesaler bought them from the manufacturer he did not pay that tax.

The situation I have outlined is the normal situation. However, if a retailer seeks to make this operation more efficient-and many retailers these days buy directly from manufacturers, particularly when they are dealing in some bulk-it is quite reasonable to ask: Why should they be obliged to pay tax at a far earlier point than a retailer who buys from a wholesaler? The whole point of the wholesaler's operation is that he holds the stock until the retailer needs it, and the tax is not paid until that wholesaler disposes of that product. If a retailer deals directly with the manufacturer, why should he be massively disadvantaged by having to pay tax at the point of purchase when he may well be holding the stock himself? Exactly the same situation takes place in terms of the time gap between the manufacturer making the product and the consumer buying it. But, under the method that the Commissioner is now forcing on the Australian taxation system, he will make it more expensive-it is not a question of equalling out-for those retailers who deal directly with manufacturers. What many did was seek to diminish that disadvantage by creating their own wholesaling operation. The benefit that they had will now be diminished because the Commissioner will apply some notional mark-up which may well have absolutely no relation to reality.

As I said, it seems to me that there are continual examples of the Commissioner getting a little out of control. These Bills constitute another of those great packages of tax laws which are aimed at fixing up things which have emerged-either mistakes or messes in this great volume of tax law that has hit us. Instead of a simplification of the tax laws as we were promised, there has been a massive increase in their complexity. There has been an increase in government by Press release. Some of these changes to the fringe benefits tax date back to announcements made in August 1986. Why on earth has it taken the Tax Office and this Government so long to fix these things up?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hopeless.

—As the honourable senator said, it is a hopeless situation. In the days when the Tax Office was inundated with paper schemes aimed at getting around clear tax law which existed at the time-back in the late 1970s-one could understand why it did take time for those statements of principle about cutting off particular forms of use to be converted into law. But, for heaven's sake, what would have happened had any of these clauses in these Bills been knocked out by the Senate? We are dealing with measures dating back to announcements on 26 August. It is simply an unacceptable situation. People who have been making commercial decisions based on a view they formed in August 1986 about what the tax law would be could now find that these measures do not come to fruition in exactly the way they expected.

SPEECH.PARA: I restate that, despite the nonsense from the Australian Democrats, we certainly welcome the restoration of negative gearing. It follows the line we stressed at the time it was abolished. In conclusion, I point out that negative gearing removes the ludicrous situation of rents being forced to rise. Under negative gearing someone who builds or buys a property can get the interest cost deducted from his tax, so in fact the effective rate of return he gets is far higher than the 6 or 8 per cent which is the maximum he is likely to get from a rental property-particularly in Sydney; I do not know about other States. A 6 to 8 per cent rate is, of course, grossly inadequate, because one could buy a Commonwealth security and get double the return that one could get on buying or building a rental property.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much would it cost you to borrow the money to put into it?
—As Senator Messner says, one would have to borrow the money at 14 1/2 per cent from a savings bank-that is the best rate one can get-in order simply to get a return of 6 or 8 per cent.
—By definition, it is negative gearing.

—Exactly. Obviously this would be ludicrous. In other words, rents would have to rise, as they did, in the absence of negative gearing. When this factor is combined with the effect of the capital gains tax, one would have to get a substantial return from one's rent-in other words, rents would have to go up-to make it worth one's while to build anything. That was why there was a shortage of rental accommodation, why rents in Australia were going up and why the Government had to act. What happened was exactly as we forecast.
—It would affect social security payments too, because renters would have to get more social security to cover the cost.

—Absolutely. As the honourable senator says, once there is a high average level of rents, pressure for increased welfare payments naturally follows-apart from the impact on the cost of living, because rent is a significant component of the cost of living. The Government, having flown in the face of economic reality, has at last recognised that reality. Naturally, the Opposition supports that. I also express my support for the amendment moved by Senator John Stone, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

``, but the Senate expresses its objection to the Labor Government's iniquitous fringe benefits tax while noting that a more efficient and equitable revenue collection system requires that obvious tax avoidance procedures, where benefits are not related to legitimate business activities, must be adequately dealt with''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate, in discussing this tax legislation deserves a far bigger audience than the four people who are listening to the debate in the parliamentary galleries. I remind them that the amending Bills represent an apology by the Government for its past mistakes. The Bills rectify many things that have gone wrong in the tax area over the last 18 months. The amendments tidy up what we term many of the legislation's previously unintended consequences. I remind the Government and my colleagues that, since the Labor Government announced its program of so-called tax reform in 1985, the Liberal-National Party Opposition has had cause time after time to condemn the Government for creating a maze of tax legislation that is excessively complex. Is it not harder to fill out one's tax returns nowadays? The tax Act is gargantuan in its proportions. It is highly ambiguous. If one has a business, one requires constant reference to rulings by the Australian Commissioner of Taxation and to tax accountants. It is riddled with unintended consequences that continually require revision. This package of amendments-there are literally hundreds of amendments in this package of Bills-tidies up unintended consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: We have arrived at this intolerable situation despite a commitment from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-another commitment-to develop a simpler tax system that more Australians could understand. And what do we have? To anyone who has had anything to do with tax it is patently obvious that that admirable aim-there is nothing wrong with the aim-has not been achieved. Here we are three years down the track since the statement with such an intricate and ambiguous system that the average Australian could not even hope to be able to understand it. Today we have before us more amendments which make the tax Act even more complex. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987 is the fourth amendment to the Act this year alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is another one coming.

—Senator Stone is right. There will be not only one, but more next year. The legislation amounts to another 221 pages to be added to the fine print of 1,356 pages that we already have. Depending on which printer prints it, it could be twice that number.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Bills are welcome in only one sense; that is, they attempt to cobble up the patchwork of existing legislation and take some steps towards correcting a few of the inequities that presently exist. At the same time, they reverse a lot of what we term ill-considered decisions that resulted from haphazard drafting in the first place. It is just not good enough. Indeed, I would go so far as to say that it is ironic that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill come hot on the heels of an announcement by taxation officers of a major review of taxation legislation and administration that will aim to-and here is a repetition of the Prime Minister's 1984 promise-make a more equitable and simpler system.

For those accountants and financial advisers who are responsible for the unenviable task of interpreting this country's tax laws, such a review will come as good news and will be welcomed, but this Government should be condemned. Well, let me pay the Government a compliment. It should be complimented, in the first place, for at least recognising its errors in this field and taking some steps to overcome them. I suggest that our tax system is in such a state of disarray that it will take some considerable time for decisions to be made and for action to be taken to simplify the situation. It will not be done overnight or in the next 12 months.

The complexities of tax legislation are not the only area to be subject to review. It seems that the Government is beginning to be beset by doubts about the efficacy of the tax law it has introduced. Reviews of the tax system will also canvass the possibility of lowering the corporate rate in an attempt to boost business confidence and encourage investment that is vital to Australia's economic recovery. But what will it do to achieve this reduction in the corporate rate? While Keating was overseas he was told by bankers and financial experts that the money that could come into Australia was being limited by our high corporate tax rates. He has been told that, if he wants this money in, he has to lower the corporate tax rate. The avenue that the Government intends to use is to deny certain depreciation allowances for manufacturers. Senator Button is trying to encourage firms to buy new plant-to upgrade their investment in more efficient plant-which is difficult because of high interest rates and the fact that a lot of the plant has to come from overseas, and the devaluation, as a result of the poor economic management of this country, makes it much more costly; yet they will be deprived of certain depreciation allowances. What is the rationale for that?

The other aspect involved is even worse. The Government seeks to attack the area of superannuation. Superannuation flows to individuals. It flows not to the corporate sector but to you and me. The Government intends to tax superannuation funds in order to lower the corporate rate, to the benefit of companies. The people who will have to pay the bills are the ordinary John Citizens of this land. How inequitable that is. That is the rationale of this sort of government. Having been told of the problem nearly two years ago, it hiked up the tax rates from 46 to 49 per cent, which caused major difficulties; it imposed a fringe benefits tax on companies, and imposed extra costs. Look what happened to the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Because of these two measures alone, it will lose 5,000 employees-in the interests of Australia, the Government says.

In three of the past four years business investment has fallen. That is not surprising. The outlook for 1987-88 is that, in real terms, there will be no, or little, increase in investment. If that is the case, investment in that period will be less than it was in 1981-82. Whether the good sense in initiating the inquiry into the level of the corporate tax rate will be carried through to the creation of a healthier climate for investment is yet to be seen. It is welcome, but we do not like the way the Government is going about it. In September 1985 Treasurer Keating, in his speech on the reform of the taxation system, told us:
The Government's tax reform exercise is completed.

The Government was getting pretty embarrassed by its results and blunderings. But three years on, it has changed its mind again. It says that the tax system will be reviewed again, despite Keating's earlier assurance in 1985. The real impact of this decision is finally becoming apparent to the Government. It has to change. The fact remains that if the Government had taken notice of the views of the Opposition and of the people in this chamber, these reviews would not have been necessary, legislation to withdraw and amend many ill-considered initiatives would not have been necessary and these Bills would not have been here today. Without these initiatives Australia would have been a lot more prosperous than it is at the moment.

The Government now seems to be in something of a rush to put things right. The July 1987 decision to increase company tax to 49 per cent is now under review. That is welcome. But I hate the mechanisms the Government will use to get down that tax rate. With the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the July 1987 decision to abolish negative gearing is to be reversed. By cripes, we took a hammering when we opposed the Government's decision. Today it seems to be an unintended consequence. It is to be reversed. The legislation provides a mass of exemptions from the fringe benefits tax which the Government introduced. We told it of the problems and the unintended consequences. The Government said, `Oh, no, you are wrong. You are protecting the tax avoiders'. Down the track, the Government has now admitted that it was wrong and it has had to open up the extensions and exemptions.

This package of measures will also amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987. Honourable senators will recall that the Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill was in the Senate only a few weeks ago to remedy certain technical and drafting defects. Why the Government did not amend the defects in the legislation before it passed both Houses is a mystery-unexplainable. It is yet another example of the haphazard approach this Government has taken towards taxation legislation, superannuation legislation and any sort of legislation. In the rush to have legislation passed, little thought has been given to the full implications of its implementation. Important details are continually being left out or are to be filled in at a later date by regulation or by rulings issued by the Commissioner of Taxation. Already, because of the complexity of legislation, tax rulings in the last few years have numbered 2,500 and they are growing at a frightening rate.

The time has passed when we can expect to see Bills that are clear in their objective and meaning and are sufficiently detailed to allow taxpayers to act on them without having to search out sources other than the legislation to establish the Government's true intention. That is sad for Australia. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) by and large contains a wide-ranging collection of unrelated amendments to taxation laws. Most of them are consequential changes the content of which at this stage of history are largely non-controversial.

However, there are two further points I wish to make with reference to this Bill. The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill has only recently passed through the Senate, as I mentioned earlier. During the debate on that legislation I had cause to comment on the excessive reliance on delegated legislation. In other words, a number of important matters, such as portability of benefits, investment of assets of superannuation funds and the disclosure of information, amongst others, are now subject to regulation. This legislation is just a hollow shell and will remain so until regulations that govern much of the substance are brought forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they now?

—As my colleague Senator Parer asked, `Where are the regulations?'. We are now taking away legislative provisions under the income tax law, as they affect superannuation, and we have a void, because no provisions have been promulgated under this new legislation. The Minister promised we would have them before the end of this session and we have only a few days left. We still have not seen them. I reckon that they will be introduced on the last day when there is no opportunity for debate. It is rather poor that the Government is withdrawing substantial conditions in the form of legislative requirements and putting them in the form of regulations and yet those regulations have not yet been put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations should have been put down first and then the withdrawal of provisions, by virtue of this amendment Bill, could have been agreed to. In other words, the Government has the matter back to front. The legislation was passed through the Senate despite vigorous opposition from the Liberal-National coalition. It was rushed through ostensibly because of the urgent need for industry to have some legislative basis on which its business could proceed with certainty. But how can one proceed with certainty if there is nothing on which to proceed? There are no regulations. A month later we find that there are no regulations and we are being asked to pass additional legislation amending occupational superannuation standards. What sort of certainty can industry draw from this series of events? It must be little comfort for it to see more amendments to what is supposed to be a firm legislative basis upon which to operate.

In relation to negative gearing, if there is little else to be excited about in the legislation, it is certainly encouraging to note that income tax restrictions associated with negative gearing on rental property have been removed. The abolition of negative gearing in July 1985 has contributed significantly to the problems many Australians are facing in merely finding affordable accommodation. The capital gains tax and high interest rates have further compounded this problem. Rental accommodation has been very scarce in many areas, particularly in Sydney where rental vacancies have been approaching record lows. Private rental costs have been increasing at a rate in excess of the consumer price index.

People wanting to buy their own home can expect to pay around 27 per cent of their income towards achieving this goal. The high cost of accommodation affects all sections of the community; those who rely on pensions, low income earners and, increasingly, people who receive middle incomes. All these people are feeling the pinch brought about by the high cost of accommodation. It is high time that the Government acted in this matter. The abolition of negative gearing acted as a barrier to investment in the housing sector for too long and with devastating results.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill will implement a multitude of exemptions to the fringe benefits tax which was introduced last year and, again, which had many unintended consequences. We drew those consequences to the attention of the Government. It largely ignored the representations until the force of public opinion was such that the Government had to issue a Press release-government by Press release. I acknowledge that these exemptions are welcome but they are overdue and far too late. I suggest that they should never have been the subject of taxation in the first place.

For example, the exemptions will free from liability the benefits in respect of certain relocation costs. If a bank transfers a guy from one State to another the Government talks about a benefit because he got some relocation costs from his company. Fortunately, the Government has now recognised its error. Another example is compensation for work-related injury. A poor bloke gets injured on the go and the Government reckons it is a benefit because he was injured on the job. It took weeks before the Government could acknowledge its error. Unfortunately, it was only a few serious accidents that made the Government wake up. But it has taken it a long time to put the change on the statute books.

The number of safety awards is under 2,000. Honourable senators would think that Senator Button and his friends would be interested in trying to make the industrial work place a lot safer. There was little benefit for people trying to introduce safety award schemes. The Government made the schemes taxable. They were benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Weren't they abusive when we drew it to their attention?

—I acknowledge that comment from Senator Parer. Let us look at accommodation and food provided for live-in help to care for the elderly or disadvantaged persons. It took hundreds of cases-and I am sure Senator Parer would agree we all heard of hundreds of cases-of people who were bedridden and who had to have care for the Government to change its mind. This help was deemed to be a benefit. So the list goes on. These amendments were foreshadowed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 26 August and 29 October 1986, which is over 12 months ago. Once again, it is a case of legislation by Press release, which has become an all too familiar trade mark of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The complexities of the fringe benefits tax legislation are numerous enough without further complicating them with uncertainties arising from piecemeal announcements which may or may not be followed by legislation. On a number of occasions the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has reminded the Government of the impact of using Press releases as a form of ad hoc legislation and it has condemned the practice. More often than not, the ad hoc presentation of legislation by Press release simply increases the confusion surrounding the issues, especially when the legislation passed by the Parliament is different in substance from the original Press release. That is a real indictment of this Government. However, it appears that this is one practice that the Government will not give up-this ad hoc presentation of Press releases-despite constant and vehement protests from the Opposition, from taxpayers, from tax consultants and from Bar associations.

In his second reading speech the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) informed us that we can expect even more amendments to the fringe benefits tax legislation, and some of these amendments will relate, for example, to liabilities arising from discounts, or purchase price under home ownership schemes in remote areas and arrangements under which employers may be reimbursed by employees or a third party for whole or part of the fringe benefits tax liability attributable to the employee's benefit. We have been told that there will be another amendment Bill next year and that is right. We will have not only one Bill but, I venture to say, many amendment Bills as these unintended consequences are finally acknowledged by government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister said that he wanted a simpler system.

—That was in 1984, but three years later the Commissioner of Taxation recognises the same thing, but we are not making much progress because, as I mentioned earlier today, we are adding another 221 pages to the legislation. What guarantees are there that the legislation ultimately will reflect these conditions of a simpler and fairer taxation system? Only recently during the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) it was shown that the final draft of legislation was different in some respects from that which industry had been led to expect and that resulted in parts of the legislation having a retrospective nature. Despite the changes that we have before us, fringe benefits tax legislation still will have many items that could not be described as tax avoidance as such. It will remain true that the Government's fringe benefits tax is placing an excessive burden on business and reducing funds that might otherwise be used to boost investment in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Surveys conducted by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce reveal that 72 per cent of those businesses that were surveyed were forced to retrench staff as a result of levying this fringe benefits tax. I am sure that honourable senators would agree that 72 per cent is a high rate. Another big retrenchment will take place next year. The Commonwealth Banking Corporation-that favourite of the socialists opposite-reported in its annual report a 32 per cent reduction in after tax profit on the previous year. What did it say that result was largely due to? It was largely due to the imposition of fringe benefits tax and a higher corporate rate. That is the effect. Hot on the heels of this announcement concerning reduction in profits came the news that the bank would reduce its work force by 5,000 people. That is the effect of this fringe benefits tax and the increase in the corporate tax rate. That is the effect that those two impositions are having on the Government's friends in the Commonwealth Bank. Hot on the heels of that profit reduction announcement due to those two factors, the bank announced that it would shed 5,000 people. Where will those 5,000 people come from? Rather than coming from the head offices, they will come from the branch network out in the sticks and smaller parts of Australia where it is harder to get a job. The effect will be 5,000 lost jobs.

The degree of responsibility that the Government should shoulder for these staff reductions is a matter for some debate. I have mentioned only one corporation. Its decision is being repeated everywhere around Australia at the present time, but, unfortunately, with less publicity. However, it appears that the impact of this fringe benefits tax was very significant in that decision. In an environment where investment is vital to Australia's economic recovery, the fringe benefits tax, the increase in the corporate tax rate to 49 per cent, the capital gains tax and a host of other imposts are creating barriers to development in this country, but this Government has the effrontery to congratulate itself on the fact that receipts from the fringe benefits tax in the past financial year were some $200m more than the originally estimated $535m.

TALK.START.PARA: —And hardly anything from the farming sector. Despite all the nonsense you people talked about, 97 per cent of the farmers did not even pay the tax.

—Senator Maguire's interjection is quite irrelevant, because not once to night have I mentioned the farming sector. I would like a comment about those 5,000 people who will be retrenched from the Commonwealth Bank. Further, I would like a comment from the 72 per cent of companies surveyed that said that they had shed labour because of this Government's fringe benefits tax. Senator Maguire should comment on that, because that is significant. I do not talk about the farmers, because the poor farmers do not have any money to pay tax.
—In 1985-86 you complained about the farmers all the time.

—As an economist, Senator Maguire would have to acknowledge that this Government is the biggest taxing government in peacetime. He should acknowledge that for the people of Australia, because that is a fact of life. Historically, this Government is expanding its tax regime, but at what cost to the Australian community? Let the Australian people judge, and I believe that they will do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.28 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill 1987 and the Sales Tax (Off-shore Installations) Amendment Bill 1987. Taxation is guaranteed to sharpen the minds of some seven million Australians from paper boys to heads of business corporations. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill that is before us tonight-I think this was alluded to by my colleague Senator Stone-has 75 more pages of Australian law and 126 pages of explanatory memorandum. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill has 100 pages of law and another 146 pages of explanatory memorandum. The understanding of the tax laws today is beyond the average Australian taxpayer. All he seems to understand is that his gross income is also his taxable income.

SPEECH.PARA: We are all aware of the fact that in the last decade the point at which the maximum rate of tax takes effect has decreased from something like 17 times average weekly earnings to 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill includes the following proposed changes to the income tax law: the removal of negative gearing, a limitation on rental property investment, a reduction in the rate of write-off for capital expenditure on new income producing buildings, introduction of income tax averaging arrangements for artists and sportspersons, and a range of provisions to deal with avoidance of income tax payments. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill seeks to implement changes to the fringe benefits tax announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 26 August and 29 October 1986 and income tax changes announced on 29 October 1986.

As Senator Stone has pointed out, the Opposition does not oppose the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) because it presents a small step towards shifting the massive tax burden that the Hawke Labor Government has imposed on all Australians. But I think some comments should be made about this piece of legislation. The Government is fond of telling all and sundry how simple and equitable the taxation system is. This is clearly absolutely untrue. What was supposed to be a reformed tax system-a system that offered equity and simplicity-has in fact gone almost in the opposite direction. I take as an example the simple and equitable stance of negative gearing. The Hawke Labor Government has performed some amazing about-faces and back flips in its time, but the one that takes the cake is its decision to reintroduce negative gearing in this Bill. We should compare the Government's present position on negative gearing with its earlier position on exactly the same issue. For example, on 17 October 1985 the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said in the House of Representatives:
I cannot believe that any leader of a major party-
he was referring to Mr Howard-
would come into this Parliament and seek to have restored one of the most blatantly abused tax shelters in the system.

That is what the Treasurer said about the Opposition's suggestion to reintroduce negative gearing because of the adverse effects its removal was having on the house market, particularly the house rental market. He went on:
To try and defend this behaviour, this outrageous rort, on the basis that it helps some renters is extraordinary.

Earlier this year the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, when launching the Australian Labor Party's women's policy, condemned the Liberals' proposal to reintroduce negative gearing among other things. She described it as `a rort for the rich which would be paid for by cuts in essential services to women'. Only a short time ago that was the attitude of the Treasurer and senior ministers of the Labor Party. We will see whether that is what happens with Labor's change of mind.

The reintroduction of negative gearing in this Bill highlights the major blunder the Government made when it abolished it in the first place. Honourable senators will recall the abuse that was hurled at the Opposition by the Government when the Opposition first drew attention to the problems with negative gearing. It was a classic example of assuming-which the Government did-that all people are tax evaders or potential tax evaders and thus introducing legislation which devastated the innocent bystanders. Ordinary Australians paid very dearly for this Government's decision to abolish negative gearing. This was yet another unintended consequence of the various tax measures of this Government. It has been compounded by the Hawke Labor Government's high taxing, high interest rate policies.

I heard Senator Haines in here previously talking about the problems of capital fleeing Australia and of investments being made overseas. But at no time did Senator Haines ask the question why. It is a very sad reflection on Australia today that we have not had the recovery in manufacturing industry, for instance, that one would have expected with the collapse of the dollar-probably the quite deliberate collapse of the dollar as a quick fix for the problems we had. The sad thing about it is that if one talks to corporate people one finds that there is nothing these people would wish to do more than to invest in their own country and to have their investment at home.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what John Elliott said.

—They are forced to look elsewhere, to look in competitive countries. I am pleased that Senator McKiernan made that interjection. It is not that John Elliott would like to do that; he was forced to do it. If one talks to any sensible investor he will say that regrettably every investment decision we make in this country today is predicated on the tax effects. Once those decisions are made simply on tax effects something is seriously wrong. As I said earlier, we do have one of the highest taxing and highest spending governments this country has ever seen.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986-87 housing starts per 1,000 population slumped to their lowest level in 30 years. The chronic shortage of rental accommodation which resulted from the decision to get rid of negative gearing meant that people either were unable to rent properties or had to pay through the nose for houses. Other amendments which are part of this legislative package are related to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill passed earlier in these sittings. In this instance the Opposition had the same complaint as it raised in regard to the previous Bill. There is no substance to it. Once again we have to rely on Press releases as there are no regulations. For how much longer must the superannuation industry rely on Press releases for guidance and wait for vital regulations which in many cases can be quite different from the Press releases issued at that time?

I will now move to the fringe benefits tax. The situation is the same for the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill. It has been tabled for only a short time, yet the Government says that everyone was acquainted with the changes. They were mentioned in two Press releases-one on 22 August and the other on 29 August 1986. Another example of the Government's simple and equitable tax system, this Bill brings about 147 pages of amendments. The fringe benefits Bill was introduced only last year, but the Government has now been forced into 147 pages of amendments. What an extraordinary example of muddle-headed legislation! This Government is being forced to make amendments to correct a situation which it should never have been forced into or have forced on to long-suffering Australians.

I shall give a few examples of the changes, and there are pages and pages of them. Again, there are unintended consequences. Let us look at a few of them. The private use of unregistered motor vehicles used principally for business purposes will now be exempt. I think Senator Maguire interjected earlier on Senator Watson when he said, `What about the farmers?'. Obviously this will enable farmers to use their unregistered utes to go to the letter box and pick up the mail without paying fringe benefits tax. The use of an employer's business equipment on a non-working day or away from the employer's business premises is another change. Why that was ever brought in in the first place is beyond me. One could not take even an electric drill home without being charged fringe benefits tax.

Also exempt will be benefits provided to employees of a government body who are employed in a public hospital, of all things-another unintended consequence. Benefits in respect of travel costs incurred in attending job interviews are another exemption. The fact that that was covered in the first place is absolutely extraordinary. Benefits in respect of specified relocation costs for a person transferred from one place to another will be exempt from fringe benefits tax. The changes go on and on. Compensation for work related injuries was one particular area that I drew attention to at the time because of a very tragic event in Queensland. I incurred the wrath of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself on the television. He said, `What nonsense. Who is this person? He is making it up'. We now have an amendment that allows compensation for work related injuries to be exempt from the fringe benefits tax.

Another change covers medical services provided in work site medical facilities that are operated principally for the treatment of work related injuries. There are another two pages of them. A few of them apply, for instance, to the mining industry. There are more exemptions, such as the one to replace the statutory formula for valuing remote area housing by a statutory value of $60 a week per unit of accommodation or $15 per week for single person's quarters. Everyone is aware of the reason the Government decided that it was going to charge a fringe benefits tax. In areas where a company does not provide housing, it will not be able to get workers, so it is a compulsory expense for a company. In addition, the union representatives of the people who work in those mining areas will not allow them to go there unless there is housing. Of course, if the Government had felt inclined, it could have charged the fringe benefits tax to the user, to the person who receives the benefit, which would be the principle one would expect. But I think the Treasurer has admitted quite openly that he did not do that for political reasons. He knew that he would not get away with it. The mining industry is already in great difficulties, particularly the coal mining industry in Queensland, where the market has collapsed, yet the companies are still being charged the fringe benefits tax-in all cases in underground mines where the company is not making a profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Higher rail duty is the other damaging thing, isn't it?

—Yes, I agree with you, Senator. There are a whole lot of government charges. This happens to be just another one, just another nail in the coffin. While that is going on, the Government is handing out $40m to get a part of the coal industry out of trouble. It does not make any sense.

SPEECH.PARA: There are pages and pages of changes. The list is endless. At least this Government is righting some of those petty mistakes-the unintended consequences. But how did it manage to impose the penalties on an unsuspecting public in the first place? Unfortunately, fringe benefit taxes which have hit some in the community who can least afford it will remain. For instance, we could hardly call shop assistants in the retail industry the wealthy in our community, but recent figures have shown that the numbers of workers who are able to buy goods and services from their employers at discount prices have now fallen by almost 30 per cent-and by almost 20 per cent over the last year.

One method the Government has employed to boost its revenue, one which I would normally support, is the desk audit. But there is growing revolt in the community about the way in which desk audits are now being conducted. My constituents in Queensland tell me of the anger they feel over the way in which the audits are conducted. For instance, last financial year 20,000 taxpayers were subjected to desk audits and the number was expected to grow to some 31,000 this year. Ann Lampe has written two revealing articles on the subject in the Sydney Morning Herald. She quoted the Taxation Institute of Australia, which represents 9,000 professionals working in tax law and law practice, and wrote that the Institute had serious concerns about the way in which tax audits were being conducted. She stated that taxpayers were not made aware that it was not compulsory for them to attend an audit, and that they complied for fear of breaching the law.
Her second article, on 2 December 1987, quotes a tax audit officer who has been assessing with the Australian Taxation Office for the last three years. She wrote:

Auditors are not encouraged to outline the taxpayers rights when they were called in for an audit, particularly regarding taxpayers bringing accountants or tax agents with them. The auditor also said that their promotion prospects suffer if they were perceived to be soft on the auditee. He went on that the whole idea of the audit is rather like a guerrilla attack. We beat them (taxpayers) over the head when we get them in and leave them reeling.

It is quite a different story from the information I received from the Australian Taxation Office as part of a reply to a question I asked during Estimates to which I waited over a month for a reply. I was told, amongst other things, `The taxpayer is always advised that he or she may be accompanied by a tax agent or adviser at any interview. From information I have received, more often than not that is just not the case.
