This Labor Government simply has an abominable record on taxation. As a proportion of gross domestic product, income taxes have increased alarmingly. They have risen by around 70 per cent. Tax revenue collected has risen from nearly $41 billion in 1982-83 to $65 billion in 1986-87. Income tax collected from individuals has increased from $23 billion, when this Government came into power, to $41 billion in 1987-88, after the tax cuts effective from July this year. Despite the rhetoric to the contrary, this is the highest taxing, highest spending government in the history of Australia. Australians are being bled to death, and the government runs around the country using the same language that the Whitlam Government used and saying, `You have never had it so good'. The Australian people know otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill 1987 and the Sales Tax (Off-shore Installations) Amendment Bill 1987. These Bills deal with a wide range of areas, such as sea installations, the taxation of annuities, tax deductions for donations to certain veterinary organisations, fringe benefits and shelf companies. The aspect of the cognate debate to which I wish to confine my remarks is the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, because it is in this Bill that the Government has finally reversed its decision to outlaw negative gearing. This is a proposal which the Opposition very much supports, and it was and still is part of the Opposition's taxation package. It is something which the Opposition has always supported, despite criticism from the Government and from the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who introduced this legislation. As we know, negative gearing occurs when a taxpayer who owns a rental property under a mortgage has greater outgoings than the level of rent receipts. He thus makes a loss. He is then able to claim that loss against any and all other income. That is the total amount on which he is taxed. The taxpayer is thus taxed only on his negative income.

SPEECH.PARA: In the tax reform package the Government abolished negative gearing. Loss on rental properties had to be carried forward until subsequently it was able to be offset against profits from rental properties. Investment in housing simply dried up. Housing as an investment became a great deal less attractive than any other form of commercial fixed asset investments. A poor, but a very real, analogy is if a taxpayer owned a service station and two taxis and the service station made a loss but the taxis made a profit. He would be able to deduct the losses from his service station against the profit from his taxis and would be taxed only on the net result of the amalgamation of those two businesses.

In the case of the abolition of negative gearing the Government chose to deny the same opportunity to those who were investing in housing. Clearly, the fabled blind Freddy could see that by placing a special taxation burden on housing, returns on investments in housing would inevitably fall relative to other investments. It necessarily followed that rental housing became scarce. As was predicted by the Opposition, rents rose automatically. This was pointed out to the Government by the Opposition at the time. On 18 July 1985, John Howard, the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, issued a Press statement headed, `When Soaking the Rich Harms the Poor'. It stated:

Mr Keating's crackdown on negative gearing is a classic example of the fact that when a government attempts to soak the rich it invariably harms the poor. Last night's announcement by the Treasurer will directly discourage the construction of low cost rental housing by increasing the cost to the investor. The end result will be an even greater shortage of low cost rental accommodation combined with a rise in rents.

The Government was clearly and unambiguously warned of the consequences of abolishing negative gearing. The Government took no notice. The Treasurer, in particular, took absolutely no notice. In the second reading speech of the legislation which abolished negative gearing, Mr Hurford said:

The Government takes the view that the taxpaying community should not have to subsidise the acquisition of investments by a particular group of taxpayers in this way. Competition for the purchase of residential property between these investors has been reflected in increased prices to the detriment of ordinary home buyers.

The Government obviously regarded the deduction of losses as a subsidy by the balance of the community. If it were judged as being a subsidy, accordingly-if logic were to prevail-every other form of investment in the same category was also to be considered a subsidy. The facts are that there was no subsidy at all. Negative gearing was perfectly in accord with the normal taxation principle that taxpayers should be taxed only on their net income.

The other claim that negative gearing had an adverse impact on home buying clearly overstates the case. Whilst it is true that investment demand for housing contributes to a proportion of the total demand in the housing market, it is only a proportion. A significant proportion comes from the people who are purchasing homes in which to live. In contrast, negative gearing affects almost every newly purchased house purchased for the purpose of rental. It is, therefore, plainly obvious that, whatever effect the abolition of negative gearing will have on housing prices, it will proportionally have more effect on the housing rental market by reducing the returns on housing investment and ultimately, as I said earlier, will increase rents. This was precisely the point put to the Government at the time by our shadow Minister, Jim Carlton. The Opposition kept up the pressure on the Government because it was so obvious that negative gearing was going to do exactly what subsequently it has done. The Treasurer, least of all, was convinced. He said in October 1985:
I cannot believe that any leader of a major political party would come into this Parliament-
he was referring to John Howard or Andrew Peacock-

and seek to have restored one of the most blatantly abused tax shelters in the system where people can minimise their income by running interest cost deductions against property. To try and defend this behaviour, this outrageous rort, on the basis that it helps some renters is extraordinary. The great majority of rental properties are not affected by negative gearing and negative gearing has not succeeded in providing an adequate number of rental properties. By contrast, we have wiped out that outrageous rort and introduced accelerated depreciation for new buildings or major renovations in order to create more rental property and more opportunties for renters.

As much as anything, that statement explains to me how divorced this Government is from reality and from commercial decisions. One might well ask how the Treasurer's statement compares with the facts. Let me remind honourable senators that, since the abolition of negative gearing until September of this year, rents have risen by an average of 43 per cent in Sydney, 23 per cent in Melbourne, 27 per cent in Brisbane and 36 per cent in Perth. That is the benefit of the Government's accelerated depreciation. That is the wonder the Government has cast upon the rental market. The truth is that that is the manifest result of the Government's decision selectively to abolish negative gearing in the rental market. In November 1985 in Perth the rent for a two-bedroom house ranged between $70 and $80 a week. By July this year the rent for the same house ranged from $100 a week to $160 a week. These figures were provided to me by the Real Estate Institute of Western Australia.

At the same time, as if it were not enough to abolish negative gearing, the Government introduced a capital gains tax and this community, past and potential home buyers, was labouring under record interest rates. It was no great surprise to anybody who was able to get two and two to come to four that the number of housing building permits crashed. The number of new houses being constructed fell dramatically. In the financial year 1984-85, 160,459 approvals for new dwellings were given. Twelve months later, this figure had fallen by 20,000 to 140,655 and, at the end of the 1986-87 financial year, it had fallen by another 20,000 to 120,780. So much for the economic geniuses of the Australian Labor Party. Inevitably, the queues for public housing rose dramatically.

The Government opposite claims to be a government of care, concern and compassion. It has said that by 1990 it will have abolished child poverty. This is the same Government which sent 40,000 people on to the queues for public housing because, thanks to its macroeconomic decisions, those people could no longer afford their own home. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from a document titled Commonwealth State Housing Agreement Background Information and Statistics, published by the Department of Community Services and Health, which shows the increase in the public housing queues.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. While the entire real estate market was crashing around it and families were being relegated and children left homeless, what was the Government doing? Well, one and a half years later Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer in this place, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I was asked what benefits would necessarily flow on to people seeking rental housing. The answer is that no benefits would necessarily flow on.
He had been asked a question about negative gearing, of course. He went on:
What Mr Howard proposes to do is to restore the old situation-
that is, Mr Howard was going to restore negative gearing-
under which it was not necessary to construct new accommodation to exploit the loophole.

So negative gearing was described as a loophole. What Mr Howard had said was that negative gearing would apply to new homes and second-hand homes. Perhaps Senator Walsh is not conscious of the fact that the average family seeking to own a home for the first time-or own it in part at least, having paid a deposit-would be quite happy to live in a second-hand home. But, at that time, when Senator Walsh could see no virtue in negative gearing, Barrie Unsworth, Premier of New South Wales, was faced with an election. When writing to the Prime Minister, he stated:
There can be no doubt that genuine investors have moved away from the rental property market.
There is a dire need for more private investment in the rental market.
With rents rising at the rate of 14.5% per annum and with the current vacancy rate at below 1% (its lowest point since the war) the situation is critical for many families.

Soon after that we were told that the Government was going to reinstate negative gearing. Suddenly, the Government was struck by a great outpouring of common sense, compassion and logic and it suddenly understood the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have always had those things.

—Senator Ryan said that the Government has always had them. Well, if I can put just one caveat on that, it always shows that when there is a State election around the corner. That is what is happening in New South Wales right now. If Johnny Citizen had written to the Government, I do not believe that we would have had a reinstatement of negative gearing. But when big, ugly Barrie wrote and said--
—I think you should withdraw that remark, Senator Crichton-Browne.
—The `big' or the `ugly'?
—Do not be smart with the Chair. Withdraw the remark.

—I withdraw the remark. When the temporary Premier of New South Wales wrote to the Government, he got an immediate response. The Government buckled and, properly, said that it would reverse its decision on negative gearing. Was it a revelation of logic? Was it that the Government had sat down and done its arithmetic? Was it that its economics had been wrong in the past, or was it simply that it wanted at any price to win an election in New South Wales?
—Brian Burke also asked for it. There is no election in Western Australia.
—But Brian Burke asks for everything all the time. He wants to be all things to all men.
—And women. He has a very good program for women also.

—I will take Senator Ryan's word for it that he has a good program for women. Let us just look at the revelation that occurred. Perhaps it is best exemplified by an answer that the Treasurer provided, through Senator Walsh, to a question asked by Senator Powell. Senator Powell had asked about the effect of negative gearing on housing rentals. Senator Walsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The ability to offset interest against other income accorded to rental property investors by the Government's decision on negative gearing can be expected to increase the after tax rate of return on rental housing investment and thereby lead to some increase in the supply of rental housing.

The same Treasurer said that the abolition of negative gearing would have no effect on supply and demand and that, if it did, it would be overcome by depreciation provisions. Then, suddenly, he said that the reinstatement of negative gearing will increase the supply of rental housing. He went on to say:
The negative gearing arrangements apply equally to investors in all types of rental housing.
As a result, the arrangements could be expected to provide a stimulus to the supply of rental accommodation in all sections of the market including the lower end.
This increase in supply should have a favourable impact from the renter's point of view on both the availability and price of rental accommodation.

So the Treasurer is now saying the exact reverse of what he said when he abolished negative gearing. He is now saying that the reintroduction of negative gearing will ensure an increase in the availability of homes and a decrease in the levels of rent.

The homeless families and the rising rent queues could make no dent in this Government's resolve. Nobody could persuade the Treasurer that he was wrong. If I am correct, when speaking about tax in the House the Treasurer said that he would never back down on something in which he believed. With the passion and fury with which he attacked us when we opposed him, I assumed that he believed it. On 17 October 1985, reported at page 2350 of Hansard, he said that he would never back down on anything in which he believed. Well, why did he back down on this? Was it because he did not believe in it?

TALK.START.PARA: —A State election.

—There was a State election around the corner. Every time there is a State election the Australian Labor Party sells its soul. It compromises itself, compromises its principles, compromises the taxpayers, compromises the economy, compromises our balance of payments-all for the single-minded ambition of holding government at any price. One may well ask why the Government is now expanding this rationale which might have been lifted straight from the Press release of John Howard to which I referred earlier. I invite honourable senators to compare the two. It might even be that the Government and the Treasurer have changed their minds. It is not only the case that Mr Unsworth is about to be defeated at the polls; as best I am able to tell, he is also a member of the same faction as the Treasurer. Whatever the reason for the change of policy, Mr Unsworth certainly carries more weight as one man than do all the rest of the voters in Australia who opposed the Government's position on the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Premier of New South Wales has an election around the corner and he has some explaining to do. He has to explain why the rental market in Sydney is so tight-perhaps the tightest of any capital city in Australia-and why interest rates in Sydney are going up higher than in almost any other capital city in Australia. He has to explain why, for instance, in the three months to April of last year, approvals for the construction of home units and flats fell by 43 per cent. Home units and flats are essentially the prime areas of investment for those investing in the rental market. That was the greatest fall over a similar period that this country has seen since Gough Whitlam. The New South Wales Government at the time had nothing to say about it; but, of course now with an election coming it has something to say. I really wonder whether this Government or the Government of New South Wales has compassion or whether this measure is simply due to the fact that an election is coming. If it is not that, why was the decision made in the first place, and why did the Government of New South Wales not complain bitterly at the time? The difference is--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the fourth time you have said that.

—Do I hear from a failed candidate for the Federal seat of Moore in Western Australia? Was that the honourable senator who ran as No. 1 on the Senate ticket and got the worst vote in the history of his political party?
—Could we perhaps get back to the Bill, Senator.

—Yes, indeed, Mr Acting Deputy President. The difference simply is that now political expediency prevails. Now we have an election and the hide of the New South Wales Government is on the line. No concern is shown for the hides of the poor souls queuing up to get public housing. If it is only the families getting the chop, of course, Mr Hawke and Mr Keating do not much care. They sit on their hands while the Federal Government rakes in this short term revenue. It is not long term revenue, because at the end of the day the cost of public housing to the Government goes up and the cost of outgoings in terms of social security and social welfare goes up. Suddenly there is a personal stake, a personal interest, in this matter for this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The reversal of the decision, of course, is welcomed. It removes an anomaly; it removes the unique discrimination against the housing industry as distinct from every other sector investing in fixed assets. The removal of negative gearing should never have taken place. If we had a government that was driven, as it falsely claims, by logic and common sense rather than an uncontrollable desire and thirst for revenue from taxpayers, these thousands of people who have already had to suffer over the intervening period would not have had to do so. It is just a pity that it is only when this Government finds its mates on the line that it has the heart and the commitment to reinstate negative gearing. It is regrettable that it was ever removed in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address my comments to two of the Bills before us: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill. The interesting thing about these particular pieces of legislation is that they add some 221 pages of new legislation. There are 92 clauses and 75 pages in the first Bill and 75 clauses and 146 pages in the second. This has come from a government whose Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Treasurer (Mr Keating) both said in 1985 that they were going to devise an easier and simpler taxation system. It was to be far less complicated. It has been a nightmare. It has been a nightmare for the Australian Taxation Office, for tax accountants and accountants generally, for the private sector and for the individual. Yet this Government said in 1985 that it would have a far easier and less complicated taxation system. What a joke!

SPEECH.PARA: Since the National Taxation Summit, the gabfest that the Government held here in 1985, there has been a 57 per cent increase in the number of pages of tax legislation. That is making it easier! It is an absolute joke. It is typical of the style of this Government that such complex legislation as that which we are debating tonight should first be introduced on 29 October in the House of Representatives and a little more than two weeks later be rammed through that House in the space of one evening. It is almost like the Bill of Rights re-trotted and various other pieces of important legislation that have just been rammed through the House of Representatives without due consideration or debate.

It is also a matter of general concern that the growing complexity of our tax laws gives more and more scope for discretionary decisions by the Commissioner of Taxation and the Australian Taxation Office in general. Since the 1985 Taxation Summit the number of pages of tax legislation, as I said before, has increased by 57 per cent. Not in one's wildest dreams could one imagine that that would make it easier to administer. Therefore many man hours have been wasted by the private sector in trying to come to grips with things such as the fringe benefits tax. Business people were getting conflicting advice from their accountants and the Taxation Office. What were they meant to do? They just had to wear it and they had to waste those man hours. This growing complexity of tax laws may reflect not only a bureaucratic approach but also a conscious desire to coerce more taxpayers through a legalistic jungle. It seems a long time since mid-1985 when the Prime Minister laid down those nine principles of taxation reform, the fourth of which, as I said, was simplicity. We are seeing the result of that simplicity yet again today.

But the most significant feature of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which covers a number of separate issues, is of course the restoration of negative gearing for rental property investments. This subject has been very well covered by many of my colleagues today. Immediately prior to my speaking, Senator Crichton-Browne laid out a very compelling argument as to why we opposed the abolition of negative gearing originally and why we have advocated its reintroduction ever since. This measure that has now been taken by the Government is, of course, the reversal of the action that it took back in 1985. From the outset the Opposition warned that this action against a so-called tax shelter would make investment in rental housing unattractive and so hit the low income earners-the people whom this Government purports to look after and whose protectors and minders it purports to be. But they are the people who have been so adversely affected by this measure. The Government should be ashamed of itself.

At the same time, the shadow Minister for taxation matters, Senator Messner, noted that the pressure on low income earners would in turn require a rise in the supplementary rent benefit. We as an Opposition advised the Government continually about this problem. Yet the Government took the view that it did not matter at that stage and would not matter further down the track. But obviously it now matters greatly when a New South Wales State election is around the corner. The $55m tax revenue gained by abolishing negative gearing was to be outweighed by increased welfare spending as more Australians became priced out of the private rental market and were forced to depend on public housing. That was something which we stated right from the word go and it is something that has been proven to be true.

We must not forget that the abolition of negative gearing was not the only major disincentive for investment in rental accommodation introduced in 1985. The dreaded capital gains tax ensured that new buildings would incur a tax on profit from eventual sale. So the two things combined put the nail in the coffin for low income earners and the rental market generally. It was simply stating the obvious to predict that the supply of new accommodation would dry up and that rents would rise in response both to the shortage and the need to recoup losses incurred by the loss of the tax concessions. Of course, when the Liberal Party pointed that out, we were cast in the mould of friends of the tax avoiders, the tax cheats and such people. How many times have we heard Senator Walsh, in his most abusive style, call us friends of the tax avoiders and tax cheats purely and simply because we were aiming at highlighting what a dreadful mistake the Government was making in abolishing negative gearing and introducing a capital gains tax? The Government even tried to claim that the move would not affect the rental market. If that is so, why, other than for a New South Wales State election, is it now changing its tune?

A city such as Perth, with a steady influx of new arrivals, has suffered particularly from the effects of the Government's action, with the rental vacancy rate falling from 2.4 per cent to one per cent in the two years to January 1987. We must remember that a rate of below 3 per cent represents a tight market. That is something that this Government should not be proud of. It should look at its policies and say, `We have caused that. We were advised that it would be wrong. We were told repeatedly by the Opposition that this would happen, but we did not care'. The effect of the introduction of the tax change can be seen in a fall of 3 per cent to 1.5 per cent between May and August 1985. The consequence has been an average rise of 25 per cent in flat rentals across the metropolitan area, rising to 40 per cent in inner suburbs where the demand is greatest. Housing rents have risen by 27 per cent both in 1985 and 1986, and rent for a two-bedroom house in Perth has risen by 39 per cent in the two years to 1987. The abolition of negative gearing has the effect of encouraging owners of rental homes to sell them, thus further reducing the supply. Sadly, many people come into my office who do not qualify for rental assistance, but they simply cannot afford the private rental market because of this Government's initiatives and actions.

The Minister for Housing in the State Labor Government of New South Wales, Mr Walker, has stated that the shortage of rental accommodation is due to the end of negative gearing and the effects of the capital gains tax. On 20 July, the Master Builders Federation of Australia urged the Government to restore negative gearing to ease the rental crisis. Its own people in other States were begging this Government not to bring in negative gearing, but the matter has been deferred and deferred until such time as it now tries to make it an election carrot for a government in New South Wales that is in more strife than Ned Kelly. While we may be pleased that the impending State election in New South Wales may have finally forced the Government to rectify its error, we are entitled to record that such an obvious misjudgment in the continual quest to squeeze more revenue from the taxpayer ought not to have been made in the first instance.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill is an example of the procedures of this Government to legislate by Press release. Heaven only knows how much of that we have seen in the last couple of years. Measures announced originally on 29 October 1986 have taken 12 months to reach the Parliament in legislative form. While we would concede that there can be some delay in finalising legislation in the taxation field, such a time-lag brings the whole authority of the Parliament into disrepute. But, then again, the Minister responsible for these pieces of legislation does not care about that. He has no regard for the Senate or the institution of the Parliament generally.

The delay may also reflect the difficulties in amending what we in the Opposition continue to regard as a bad tax. It is complex, intrusive and unjust both because it is levied on the providers rather than the recipients of benefits and because it continues to be levied on items that are genuinely work-related. At the time of the initial debate on the legislation, we fought tooth and nail for the Government to try to distinguish between those benefits that had been given to people in lieu of salary and those that were genuinely work-related. But the Government, in its blinkered attitude, had to continue to hit all. The Bill removes some of the more gross anomalies that were identified when the original fringe benefits tax was passed by this Government and the Australian Democrats in June 1986. The Democrats filibustered all day yesterday, calling unnecessary quorums and divisions. Yet, when it comes to debating things such as the fringe benefits tax, which they supported--

TALK.START.PARA: —It's all too hard.

—That is exactly right, Senator-they pack their bags and go home. It is an absolute disgrace that the Democrats supported the proposal originally and cannot, even now, see the evils of what they did back in those dim, dark days of June 1986. Of course, invalids will now no longer pay the tax for live-in assistance-and about time. There is an extra 10 per cent discount on remote area housing and travel-and about time, especially in a State such as my own, Western Australia, where rental accommodation and housing accommodation generally in the north-west and the Goldfields can be very difficult. In many instances, it is difficult to attract people to those areas. Car log-book procedures are to be simplified. As I said before, all of these things were done by Press release and we now see the legislation. These and other measures do not alter the basic substance of the original Act, as the Government has been happy to proclaim.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate should recognise that there is continuing opposition to this tax among the business community. In March this year, a survey of the fringe benefits tax by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce showed that 98 per cent of businesses opposed it. More importantly, I suppose, is the fact that 81 per cent of those surveyed said that they would reduce their work forces as a consequence and 72 per cent said that they had already had to do so. Once again, this Government does not care about that. It talks about job creation-not about the explosion of the jobless. It talks about creating jobs in the Public Service-not about real job creation. Altogether, 51 per cent of businesses claimed that the tax had affected trading viability; 61 per cent claimed to have passed on some costs to consumers, and 71 per cent said that they would need to reconsider investment plans. On an individual level, a letter from Mr Les Howard to the Small Business Letter of 28 September stated that the fringe benefits tax had caused him to cut staff at his car radio service in Sydney and Gosford from 25 to 18. He raised a very interesting question in that letter as to how the books would be balanced. He asked how the reduced sales tax from the loss of his sales and the loss of his business generally should be offset against the revenue gained from the fringe benefits tax.

Once again, the people and the economy are suffering from this high taxing and high spending Government that beats all past records. It was also noted in the same publication of 20 July that that month the Taxation Office was late in mailing out the fringe benefits tax forms to businesses. That is a very interesting piece of information. As we can all recall, July just happened to be the month of the Federal election. They were posted out in Perth between 13 and 15 July; in Sydney, on 16 July; and in Adelaide, on Sunday, 12 July and those dates were all after the Federal election. All forms were posted late. I wonder why. Would it be fair to suggest that the Government was anxious to ensure that the small business community was not reminded of such an unpopular tax immediately prior to the election of 11 July? The date of the election was 11 July, but Adelaide sent its forms out on Sunday, 12 July. It is highly likely that a 10 to 15 per cent increase in management salaries during 1986, as reported in March this year, represents a substantial cashing out of executive benefits, of those who dominated the rhetoric of this Government when attempting to justify the tax. It should be said in passing that, if this supposedly is what the tax set out to eliminate, how can the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have it both ways by denouncing the salary increases that are sought? This also suggests that the increasing returns from fringe benefits tax must reflect more and more a tax not on executive packages but, rather, on those so-called benefits that are substantially work-related and simply cannot be cashed out.

The Budget Papers make it clear that the fringe benefits tax represents a major tax grab and that it is being paid on the work conditions of a wide section of the Australian work force. Despite the cashing out to which I referred earlier, a tax estimated to raise $325m in 1986-87 has exceeded this forecast by $200m, making a total of $525m from the private sector. The estimate for 1987-88 is $750m, which is an increase of 40 per cent on the original estimate and that is boosted by a rise in the tax rate from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. It was reported on 20 November by the Department of Finance that, for the first quarter of the financial year, returns from fringe benefits tax had exceeded forecasts by $45m, so that over a full year the yield would reach $855m and, doubtless, all this revenue is gratifying for the Government as a tax on turnover rather than on profit, but it begs the question as to how well business can afford to pay it: it cannot afford to pay it. It has been telling the Government that it cannot afford to pay it, but this Government has done nothing about it.

On page 362 the Budget Papers show just how widely the fringe benefits tax net has been cast. In total, there are 105,000 taxpayers who clearly represent a big slice of Australian private enterprise and, while there is no total for the number of employees for whom the tax must be paid, given that fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles affects 433,000 employees, that fringe benefits tax on low interest loans affects over 168,000 people and that its application to housing affects over 105,000 people, a large proportion of the work force has attracted the tax. We can hardly believe that all these people are the business executives whom Senator Walsh talked about and condemned all the time, saying that they were the only ones who would be hit.

Another table shows that 47 per cent of those paying the tax have a liability of less than $1,000 and 67 per cent of all those paying fringe benefits tax pay less than $2,000. This shows the extent of fringe benefits tax as an administrative burden on the small business community, whose real cost often is in the paperwork and being an adjunct to the Australian Taxation Office, where the quarterly imposition of fringe benefits tax must be added to the quarterly company tax and provisional tax returns-all at different stages of the year-and monthly payments of group tax, prescribed payments, withholding tax and sales tax. So, this Government considers any more taxes that it can put on to the private sector are well and good. It just dishes them out like lollies to the private sector, but they are not lollies at all; they are a little slice of poison.

At the other end of the scale, 41 taxpayers, presumably corporations, paid fringe benefits tax last year in excess of $1m, which amounted to 24 per cent of the total collection. Even for a large concern fringe benefits tax must now stand as yet another major expense and time consuming effort which it has to put in to comply with this ridiculous measure taken by this ridiculous Government. The business community in Western Australia knows that this tax is an unfair burden. It knows also that many anomalies still will remain after the supposed concessions in this Bill. An employee of private enterprise working away from home receives a living away from home allowance, yet over a week his employer would be liable for $21 fringe benefits tax payable on meals. These employers ask why they have to pay $21 on a person in the private sector for fringe benefits tax on meals when a public servant in the same situation receives a tax free travel allowance. Surely the two should be the same, but that is not so. The public sector is treated completely differently from the private sector. The private sector cops the bills, but the public sector cops a tax free travel allowance.

Employers are conscious also of the fact that some supposed fringe benefits are enshrined in industrial awards and cannot be cashed out. The unions have played a large part in this and they were quite delighted to do so, because they know that the benefits cannot be cashed out. They know that their union members still will be beneficiaries of these types of benefits and that those benefits will not be rescinded. The mining industry is a particular case in point. A discount on the fringe benefits tax liability for remote area housing only acknowledges the fact that its provision is an accepted precondition for work in remote and harsh climates. Should a company elect to sell housing to employees, any concessional element to the scheme is also subject to the tax. Last year I warned the Senate that the fringe benefits tax might cost the Western Australian mining industry $30m annually. The latest estimate is that its total cost will fall between $50m and $75m, despite the concessions announced in October 1986. It is a major cost for our export industries, but once again this Government is not too keen on exporting. It prefers to import more than it exports, hence our balance of payments is right up the creek. A major Western Australian company engaged in manufacturing and timber production has a fringe benefits tax bill of $300,000 annually, even after exact and careful valuation of some housing that would have very little general value. This company returns 51 per cent of its profits in overall tax to the Government. The publisher David Syme and Co. Ltd, in order to meet its fringe benefits tax bill, must earn an extra $1.3m in profit, or in effect generate an extra $8m in revenue. The fringe benefits tax is responsible for the employment of two extra bookkeepers, although in so many enterprises its cost must also have a bearing on decisions to limit the size of the work force.

Of course, various other people have been hit by this tax. Employers who simply want to hold a Christmas party for their staff and for the children of their staff are hit by this tax. Surely employers can do something for their staff and not be slugged by this Government. Smaller councils that do not possess their own dining facilities are hit by this tax and are still hit by it even if they simply go out, buy food and reheat it on the premises. Doctors who provide a free consultation to their staff have to pay for fringe benefits tax, or they charge it to Medicare so that the taxpayer can pay the Medicare bill. It is absolutely outrageous. It was actually after the announcement on 10 November last year of the concessions on the fringe benefits tax that Senator Richardson was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as expressing concern for bank employees. He stated that governments had to make sure the little man was not caught up in such a tax. But now Senator Richardson has his ministerial cloak on, he has changed his tune. Now, needless to say, he would deny that the little man is affected by the fringe benefits tax, despite all the evidence.

It is outrageous that even independent schools with significant boarding facilities must budget for sums in excess of $40,000 to pay their fringe benefits tax on necessary staff accommodation. Even though those boarding schools simply want to have staff on the premises to look after the boarders, the provision of this accommodation is considered a fringe benefit. I doubt whether much of the accommodation they live in could be classed as a fringe benefit. The non-cash benefits provided to enable employees to do their duty should not be taxed, and neither should accommodation provided to employees moving to country areas. Loans of up to $50,000, where it is the practice of an industry to provide them to an employee, should not be taxed. Of course, this would solve the problem which Senator Richardson raised but which he is not now prepared to repeat. On the other hand, non-work related benefits such as the payment of school fees in circumstances where the employee is not transferred overseas or away from a major city should be taxable, but taxable in the hands of the recipient who enjoys the benefit, not in the hands of the provider. The Opposition will not support open slather on executive perks because there are so many that are work related, and the ones that are not work related should be the problem of the recipient and not the problem of the provider.

The Opposition will definitely seek to remove the cost impositions from export industries, small business and voluntary bodies. It is simply a little too late for this Government to introduce these measures now purely and simply because of the impending New South Wales State election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating various taxation law amendments. Normally I do not speak on taxation and the economy, but I was fired up tonight by the screwed-up view the Australian Democrats have on negative gearing. Nothing sets me going more than a kick in the stomach. I have received many of them in my life, and one such kick sent me on my way to this chamber in the beginning. This evening I will direct my remarks, short as they will be, towards negative gearing, the fringe benefits tax and, to a certain degree, substantiation. I had not intended to speak because the Opposition has plenty of good speakers and authorities, in Senator Stone, Senator Knowles, Senator Michael Baume and others.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately I cannot abide what the Democrats have said on negative gearing. Let assure the chamber that when I speak on negative gearing and its effects on private rental housing I talk from experience. I have been a housing developer for at least 20 years and have had vast experience of tenants all through that time. I was accused this afternoon by our friends the Democrats, including their Leader, Senator Haines, and Senator Macklin, of being a no dog, no cat and no children sort of landlord. Knowing the long term tenants I have had over 20 years, I can assure them that that is far from the truth. The Democrats also carried on this afternoon about people buying high-priced units to get a tax deduction through negatively gearing. I will give them a lesson on investing in home units for rental purposes. The best recipe for disaster is to buy a high-priced unit and rent it out. Anyone who does that will soon go down the drain. On a high class unit, starting at around $200,000 to $250,000, there would not be a return of more than 1 1/2 per cent gross, and then there are all the deductions, such as the body corporate fees and everything that goes with owning a unit. Anybody who did that would come out at a loss; in other words, there would be a minus return.

It is time that the Democrats looked at the creators of wealth as well as the people who take. On this earth we need the ones who create as well as the ones who receive. Landlords will put money into buildings if they can see some return, but they will not invest if they cannot see any return at all. A medium sized block of flats, on the western side of the continent, anyhow, will return 6 per cent gross, less outgoings. An average single housing unit-that is, a house-will return 4 1/2 per cent gross. So how can anyone tell me that investing in rental property is a rort? Landlords and investors would usually have such property in the expectation of a gain value in the long run, even though there is now a capital gains tax. It is property bought to provide for or leave something behind for the investor's family.

In 1985 the Government decided, probably on Senator Walsh's recommendation, to eliminate negative gearing. What was the result? There was an immediate drop in the commencement of new buildings for the private sector rental market. I have a graph which shows this, and it is a pity that we cannot incorporate it in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity; otherwise we could have put into Hansard the graph on page 6 of the report on the Forward Estimates.

—I will take that on board. The graph shows building approvals in Australia up to October 1987. In September 1985 building was almost at a peak, and within 12 months it had dropped by 3,000 units per month, a 25 per cent drop. This drop was felt by the building trade, and of course the building trade buys materials from suppliers. As well, all the various building trades employ a lot of people. The effect was felt most of all by apprentices. Tradesmen already in the trade did not have too much to worry about because they could carry on somewhere else, but the intake of apprentices took a great dive. When the Democrats, who are the upholders of the downtrodden in Australia, supported the Government's abandonment of negative gearing they should have been worrying about these apprentices and other people who lost their jobs because of it.

SPEECH.PARA: What else did the dropping of the negative gearing provisions result in? Money that would otherwise have been available for private sector housing went into commercial buildings and into the stock market. It probably helped overheat the stock market, as it has been overheated in the last few years. The money also went into gold bullion, and it went into bank accounts and sat there, doing nothing but creating interest. I have always believed that money is round to go around. Because of all this, private investors withdrew from the rental sector. Of course, the amount of rental accommodation available went down and as my colleague Senator Knowles has told us, the cost of renting went up. There was a steep rise in rental charges. Then the 4 per cent depreciation allowance was introduced to attract money into housing and other investments and to get the building industry going. However, that resulted in finance going more into commercial buildings rather than rental housing. It is quite reasonable to expect a return of 12 per cent in the commercial area, much higher than the return from private rental investments. It is also a lot easier to collect the rent as it is paid up front and all additional outgoings are paid by the tenant. At that stage the housing shortage was still worsening and rents were still rising.

Then the Government somersaulted. Perhaps it saw the writing on the wall. I was not here at the time, but I know that the Opposition was heavily criticised for its opposition to the removal of negative gearing. The Government's illustrious Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who has probably learnt some common sense in the hard areas of the eastern wheatbelt of Western Australia in his time, decided that enough was enough. I congratulate the Government on its somersault, because it was common sense. What has happened since then? Life has already been instilled into the housing industry. The Australian Democrats were grizzling this afternoon about the forgone taxation which will result from the reintroduction of negative gearing. If I read the Budget Papers correctly, as a result of the reintroduction of negative gearing the Government will forgo $80m in tax revenue, the loss peaking in 1989, after which it will reduce gradually then drastically.

This is where the Democrats really screwed their argument up. The Budget provided for a reduction in the depreciation allowance to 2 1/2 per cent to balance the revenue forgone and what was coming in. Again, if I have read the Budget Papers correctly, the Commonwealth will pick up $3m in extra tax in 1988-89, $10m in 1989-90 and $29m in 1990-91, with a total revenue of $500m after 25 years. Following this change in policy, the re-introduction of negative gearing and the cutting of the depreciation allowance on buildings, unless I have my figures mighty wrong, the Commonwealth will still come out in front. Nonetheless, the Government has done the right thing by acknowledging its folly of 1985 and reversing the trend. Hopefully, landlords and developers, with whom I am happy to have been associated over the years, will get back into the market to provide the private sector housing that is so badly needed.

Senator Knowles earlier this evening referred to the rental rises in Perth since September 1985. If I remember her words correctly, she said that a steep rise of 25 per cent occurred in one year. With all the houses that have changed hands, all the money that has come in and the interest that has been shown in housing investment since the reintroduction of negative gearing, rents have not risen, as the Democrats tried to tell us was the case this afternoon. Rents have at least been held in the last couple of months. The rental housing situation during the America's Cup in Perth last year was a fiasco. Nowhere near the expected high rents were obtained, but rentals in the middle housing bracket were forced up. I can assure honourable senators that rental charges now are at least holding or coming back. The reintroduction of negative gearing is already starting to make a difference in rental housing, in Perth at least. I have spoken quite enough about negative gearing. I congratulate the Government, after its great folly of 1985, on the re-introduction of negative gearing. I wish briefly to touch on the fringe benefits tax as it affects the outback areas of at least Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are becoming as verbose as some of the other people over there.
—That is all right.
—What about Marvel Loch?

—Marvel Loch is doing all right. It is a pity that the Minister does not look at Marvel Loch again and see some of the good crops that we are harvesting right at the moment. To get back to the point, Senator Knowles pointed to the results of the fringe benefits tax on the Goldfields of Western Australia. The user pay principle has been referred to time and time again inside and outside this chamber, and I agree with it. Recently, perhaps even today, an inquiry was announced into Telecom Australia and the connections in the outback areas for which the user pays. In some cases it costs about $280,000 to have a phone connection. Everything seems to be operating on the user pay principle. I mostly agree with that, but that did not apply in the case of the fringe benefits tax. It was again the poor old employer who was hit with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite my limited knowledge of the taxation laws, I have been made well aware of certain sections of the tax law under which those fringe benefits that were a rort could have been hit. I refer not only to those who had expensive lunches while others ate their lunch out of a brown paper bag; but also to those who were getting their children's school fees paid even though they were living in Perth, Sydney or Melbourne. There were ways to catch those people without making a broad-based swipe across the country which brought in, according to the figures I hear tonight, umpteen times more than was expected.

If there was anywhere that the Government should have considered exempting from the fringe benefits tax it was the outback generally, particularly in Western Australia. Not only mining companies but also local government had to pay it. When the tax first came in, my shire had just formulated a budget, as no doubt had many of the other shires. Somewhere down the track we were required to make provision for the fringe benefits tax. In order not to overrun our budget and upset ratepayers and the local government Minister alike, we had to cut back on other works to fit the tax in.

I must refer to the question of farmers not paying fringe benefits tax. When I first came to this chamber a discussion arose from a dorothy dix question from a member of the back bench to the Minister for Finance in which the Minister was asked whether he was aware how much fringe benefits tax farmers did not pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bugger all.

—I know that. But why do they not pay it? It is because they have cashed out. For farmers who have only one or two employees, it it hardly worth while mucking around and doing a return once a month, so they cash out. They charged their employees for the accommodation, then gave them more money to pay for that accommodation and this put their tax rate up. The farmers are paying this money, but it is hidden in the cash out system. If honourable senators do not believe me they should make their own inquiries; the facts are there.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on briefly to the question of substantiation. Previous speakers have mentioned how this Government amends taxation legislation by Press release. That has certainly been the case in relation to substantiation. Various Press releases have been issued since substantiation laws were tightened up and as a result more and more work has been created for accountants who file taxation returns. We have now reached a point where these accountants do not quite know from these Press releases how far they have to go with substantiation. Of course, they are now running out of time to lodge the returns. They risk incurring the wrath of the Commissioner of Taxation and they worry about whether they can obtain extensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people forget to lodge their returns!
—That is right, Senator Calvert. Either they get an extension or they are fined. Certainly, it is time that the Government set down far more definite guidelines about substantiation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether my final point has anything to do with the Bills at hand, but I stress that the Government keeps telling us that it is time to save money. I agree with that. I read some figures the other day which astonished me. I believe that something like $5 billion is owed on plastic cards floating around Australia at the moment. Honourable senators should not take that figure as gospel, but nevertheless it is ridiculous. I had hoped that some other senator would have been able to help me out and confirm whether that figure is correct. The fact is that although this figure exists, we are being encouraged to save. When the Government next considers reforming the tax laws I hope it will look at the threshold for the payment of provisional tax. That threshold is still $999, or so the chartered accountant in my family informs me, and it has been at that level for as long as both he and I can remember. This chartered accountant has been in the game, both as a student and as a practising accountant, for about nine years. With the high interest rates of the past 12 months or two years, one does not need very much money stored up in the bank to obtain interest of more than $1,000. This accountant tells me that time and time again when people bring their tax returns to him they are told that they will have to pay provisional tax because their unearned income is more than $1,000. These clients then say, `Well, I had better go out and spend some money and bring my total savings under the $7,000 or whatever it is that generates that $1,000 interest.'. I would have thought that by now the Government should have increased that threshold in order to encourage people to save. I hope it will look at that matter. I do not wish to say any more, but I hope that I have put the Government and the Australian Democrats right on negative gearing. Probably in 12 months or two years they will appreciate the folly of their statements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to delay the passage of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits and Substantiation) Bill 1987 and the Sales Tax (Off-shore Installations) Amendment Bill 1987 any longer other than to say that the Government will oppose the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 4 November.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 November 1987 progress was reported on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1987 in order to allow the Government to review an amendment which had been moved by Senator Macklin on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The amendment proposed a sales tax exemption for general purpose goods when sold for use as `special aids' to persons who are disabled or physically or mentally handicapped. This is a proposition which has been considered by many governments over the years, but doubts over whether sales tax exemption is the best method of providing assistance to the handicapped and the many problems associated with an exemption for general purpose goods persuaded those governments not to change the law in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that points to the general bluntness of the laudable objective of helping particular individuals with general concessions. Recently I have mentioned some concessions that mean the provision of electricity at way below the cost in Western Australia's remote areas. The rationale for this, by and large, is to help pensioners and people with low incomes, but the final income distributional effects are very different from those which the proposers or supporters of such policies probably expect. For example, on the proposal put up by Senator Macklin one problem would be to define who is to be regarded as handicapped or disabled-certainly not an easy decision to make at the margin-or what classes or degrees of handicaps are required to qualify for exemption. In other words, it is extremely difficult to administer such a proposal, even if one agrees with it in principle. The related problem would be the need to establish a system under which persons with the necessary professional expertise could apply consistent criteria to certify that particular individuals qualified for the concession. It would also be necessary to specify the classes of goods that handicapped or disabled persons could purchase free of tax, and to ensure that safeguards were set to prevent abuse of any such concession by eligible persons buying those goods for relatives or friends. In other words, it would be setting up, admittedly probably on a small scale, tax evasion arrangements. In that regard it would be impossible to ensure that special aids which would be of use to persons without disabilities were used by only disabled or physically or mentally handicapped people. Senator Macklin cited the example of a computer. Even if it were provided for in the law, the Commissioner of Taxation could not enforce any restriction on the use of the computer to the disabled or handicapped person where the computer was also available to other members of the family. The Government does recognise that some specific assistance needs to be given to those in the community who find it difficult to lead ordinary lives, but the granting of sales tax concessions is not considered the most appropriate method of granting assistance. For those reasons the Government will not be accepting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh has outlined, the reason for the Governments opposition to the amendment which I moved some time ago. Indeed, the amendment has been the subject of both a private member's Bill at some stage and some discussion and letters with the previous Minister for Social Security.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight Senator Walsh explained essentially-if I have not got him wrong-the reason the Government is opposed to the proposition I am putting, which, for clarification for members of the chamber, is to seek a sales tax deduction for goods for handicapped people, although those goods are not specifically designated as goods for handicapped people. An example of a particular good which is already exempt under the sales tax Bills is a wheelchair. The type of item I am talking about is one which is for general purpose use, such as a computer. If I can use those two as paradigm examples I think it may make somewhat clearer the item I am arguing.

I understood the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to say that it will be impossible to ascertain first of all whether these items are being bought by handicapped people and, presumably, how many items, and secondly, whether it is possible to stop people who are not handicapped from using those items.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a question of confirming first that he is handicapped and then ensuring that only those who are handicapped use them.

—Right. I am happy to address myself to those issues because, interestingly enough, the Bill as it stands permits all those things for other items, and I think this is the problem that the Government is arguing. What the Government has not done, and what is something I had hoped it would have done by now, and possibly the previous Government, is to provide a total review of the current list. Since the Government does not have that, I am quite happy to go through those items to show that each of those things currently occurs.

SPEECH.PARA: The first schedule of the Sales Tax Act 1935 contains and specifies the items under which various classes of goods are exempt. Item 123a in the first schedule of the Sales Tax Act provides exemptions for interactive and broadcast videotex systems, broadcast teletext decoding devices and similar decoding devices of a kind used in or in connection with television receivers, where the system or device is for use and not for sale by profoundly deaf people or persons taken to be profoundly deaf. As all honourable senators would know, those videotex systems are in fact capable of being used for a whole variety of purposes by people other than those who are deaf. Exemption for that piece of equipment, interestingly enough-and here we come to the point of how we know whether a person is handicapped-is on a restricted basis and is available only to persons to whom a certificate as to the extent of the hearing disability has been furnished by the Director-General of Health or by an officer appointed by him for that purpose. Honourable senators may remember that the first time I moved this amendment I suggested the same procedure by regulation-that in fact a suitable medical practitioner would be the person who would certify this. I think there is a clear case to show that there are presently mechanisms available to facilitate the means by which my amendment could be administered. The onus would be on the person who is handicapped to seek that exemption.

Item 135a of the Sales Tax Act contains provisions which require evidence of a handicap before sales tax exemptions are offered to the persons seeking them. Motor vehicles are mentioned under this item. This may be interesting to people who have a friend or relative who has a vehicle equipped so that their handicap is overcome, especially if they have ever driven in one. I have had a lift in one. Members of families one of whom is handicapped travel in them frequently. In other words those items, which were sales tax exempt, are used by other people. So what? Why are we concerned about that? I see no objection to a person who is handicapped and who has a specially equipped vehicle which enables him to drive, driving other people in it. There is no loss of revenue. It is an absurd proposition to say that if we provide this exemption to handicapped people, such as with a computer, which is the item I have used, other people may use it. So what? There is no problem there. I think it is niggardly and absurd to suggest that because other people might have to use it, there is some reason we should not allow it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as it is used primarily by them.

—As long as it is used primarily by the handicapped person, yes. I think we have a very good example of that particular operation here. Item 42 (17) refers to wigs and hair-pieces for people who are clinically bald. Sales tax exemption is provided conditionally--
—Aulich would be interested in this.
—Yes. In fact a number of senators probably do not know about this item and we are shortly likely to have a large jump in sales tax exemption.
—What is the number?

—It is item 42 (17). We thought you might be interested. It is for wigs and hair-pieces for people who are clinically bald. Sales tax exemption is provided conditionally on the certification of a legally qualified medical practitioner, and in fact there are no regulations with regard to 42 (17)--
—It is an offensive personal reflection. Have a look behind you.

—I have already recommended this to Senator Coulter. He is worried that somebody else might wear the hair-piece. The situation is that the certification is provided by a legally qualified medical practitioner. The interesting thing about that section is that there are no regulations governing it. The entire operation of that section is done out of the legislation. What it comes down to is not whether it can be administered. Items are already operating in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the real point is a philosophical one, and the Minister did touch on this although only briefly; there were better ways to help disabled people. It is interesting that there are better ways to help them and that the bureaucrats know better ways to help them. At least the previous Minister for Social Security made a valiant attempt, obviously not good enough with regard to this Government, to turn that whole thing on its head. Disabled people, because they may be physically disabled, because they may be deaf or blind, do not lack intelligence or the capacity to run their own lives or make their own decisions. The bureaucrats know what is best for somebody else.

At least with the establishment of an Australia-wide committee of disabled people, presumably disabled people will be accepted by this Government as having the ability to make those types of decisions. If we accepted this item I think we could do away with every other item relating to disabled people, because it puts the onus on disabled people to decide what will best help them overcome their particular disabilities, rather than having the bureaucrats saying, `We believe that this is good for you'. Let us take that step forward in our philosophical position with regard to disabled people.

I make a specific plea with regard to computers. I shall explain why I became interested in this four years ago. I repeat the story even though some honourable senators have heard it before because I think it is useful. A father came to me about a child who was about to start school and who had been born with his hands attached to his shoulders. His hands were functional but he had no arms. His father was insistent that his child go into a normal classroom. Interestingly enough, he was in contact with a friend of mine. I was able to put him in contact with a couple of other friends of mine who customised the keyboard of a small computer. It was put up on a little stand so that the child was able to operate it. He went into grade 1 with his computer. He is still in primary school and he uses the computer every day in the classroom.

What he was thus able to do with that computer is surely, from his father's and his own point of view, far better than all the bureaucrat designed propositions. It was something the family did. Interestingly enough, the computer was provided by private enterprise without profit. The father had to pay sales tax to the Government, whereas the company he bought the computer from was quite happy to forgo, in that circumstance, the profit it would have made on the equipment.

I make a plea to the Government that if, as it has already indicated, it is unwilling to accept this amendment it, at least agree to review the situation. In 1987 we are not talking about wheelchairs or crutches. We are talking about technology which will enable these people to live a full and productive life in our society. At last technology has come far enough to assist these people in a remarkable way to assist themselves. The technology is available. We are still collecting money on it, saying, `We are going to deny it to you unless you can raise the full amount of tax to pay to the Government'. On the other hand, we give a whole variety of other hand-outs. I am not advocating hand-outs. I am talking about the ability of people to make their own decisions. After this debate had been adjourned and as I was flying home to Brisbane I read a book entitled So Far published by the Apple computer company on its first 10 years. I came across a part on page 45 that I would like to read to honourable senators because I think it sums up the proposition I am putting:

Computers, rigged with a variety of special devices and accessories, allow even severely handicapped children to accomplish tasks most people take for granted. They make writing possible for kids who can't hold a pencil. They make words clear to kids who can't hear a sound. And they make playtime fun for kids who can't use their arms and legs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin has made some sound points about the need for review. It was the Opposition's recognition of the need for a review by the Government that encouraged us to support the proposal that progress be reported the last time this matter was discussed so that the Government could at least reconsider the matter. However, the support we had for Senator Macklin's request for a review of what is clearly a strange mixture of items that are available free of sales tax compared with those that are not does not lead us to support the Australian Democrats' amendment in this case for the very reasons outlined by Senator Walsh. In particular, we believe that there is a need to target those people in need with the scarce resources of taxpayers' money that are available. The targeting of those people in need is not done by a general removal of sales tax from what are, as Senator Macklin conceded, general goods rather than specific aids of a specific nature for people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's policy on this matter is clear. We have a very strong commitment to and support the wider provision of respite care for disabled people living with their families, noting in particular the problems of those in remote areas. Our policy is that, as budgetary circumstances permit, we will move progressively to remove any specific taxes and other imposts from specific aids for those with disabilities. Where the Government determines that there should be support for Australian manufacturers this should be through bounty or subsidy.

Senator Macklin's recommendation is of a non-specific nature. The goods are of a non-specific nature and could be used by or resold to people who would not be using them specifically as an aid in respect of a disability. As a result, whilst supporting the view that there should be a review of the application of these exemptions, the Opposition is not prepared to support this amendment because it does not deal with specific taxes for specific aids. I stress that such a broad sweep is inappropriate at a time when budgetary circumstances do not permit further moves in the direction of general exemptions. However, hopefully, the Government will entertain the view that a specific, purpose-built computer such as the one Senator Macklin mentioned-he pointed out that it involved additional work and I presume that sales tax was paid on the components and work involved in making that computer a specific item of use only for the child who had the disability-should be exempt from tax. I hope that the Government considers the problem Senator Macklin has raised because it fits in very clearly with the Opposition's view that, for specific aids, specific taxes should be removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Macklin. After my election in 1976, one of the first things I had occasion to raise with the then Government was the very question of the need for families with disabled children to choose the most suitable aids for those children and for their particular handicap, having regard to the fact that they and they alone were the ones able to determine the issue. Unfortunately, over a long period there has been correspondence on the issue of sales tax exemptions for such devices and aids. The worrying thing now is that the handicapped are being put into straitjackets by the bureaucrats. Unless the bureaucrats approve of a device, the handicapped do not get anywhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I am really disappointed that members of the Opposition are not supporting this amendment. I appreciate what Senator Michael Baume has said. I have listened to him carefully. But I am disappointed in what he said because he talked about targeting those most in need. That ought to be the object of policy in this area. It is not as though the handicapped and their families are asking for a hand-out. That is not what is being asked for in this amendment put forward by Senator Macklin. All they are asking for is for the Government not to knock them off, not to ask a couple to pay tax just because they happen to have a handicapped child. They would not want to purchase the equipment unless they had a handicapped child.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is non-specific.

—Yes, I understand the point that Senator Michael Baume makes. But it is the parents of a handicapped child who know precisely what is most beneficial, or at least what is most useful, for their handicapped child.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is symptomatic of the attitude of government to taxation. It is as though it is the right of the Government to grab what it can from anybody, particularly from families with children, just because they have children-or, in this case to grab a bit of sales tax from a family just because that family has a handicapped child. It is an extraordinary situation and I really feel that it is something which the Opposition should oppose. I think Senator Macklin has attempted to overcome the other point made by Senator Baume relating, as I understand it, to any problem with a resale of the equipment. Unless I have misread Senator Macklin's amendment, I think he has covered that. But I appeal to honourable senators to support Senator Macklin's amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
