DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bills were returned from the House of Representatives without amendment:
Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987.
Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1987.
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill is to amend the Housing Assistance Act 1984 to authorise an appropriation for the provision of financial assistance for public housing for the years 1988-89 and 1989-1990 and to authorise the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to re-allocate specific housing assistance grants between the States. The amount involved will be a cost to the Commonwealth of $700m in each of the two financial years 1988-89 and 1989-1990. The funding for the current year, 1987-88 ,is also $700m. It is to be made available through Appropriation Act (No. 2). Of the $700m to be provided in each of the next two years, $11m is for expenditure on local government and community housing and $14m for expenditure on crisis accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be opposing this Bill. However, we do have great concern about the deplorable state of the housing sector in Australia due directly to the policies and the mismanagement of the Hawke Government. Accordingly, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) condemns the Government for its further intrusion into State housing programs involving more administrative duplication and waste; and
(b) believes greater responsibility for the provision of housing should rest with the States who are in the best position to address their communities' needs''.
I understand that that amendment has been circulated to honourable members. For the reasons I will turn to now, the Opposition will be taking that amendment to a division, if necessary.

I believe the Government's role in Australian housing should be two-fold: there is an economic or financial role and there is a social role. So far as the economic and financial role is concerned, unless there are overriding reasons, no government should pursue policies that would hinder the growth and development of the nation's housing sector. So far as the social considerations are concerned, in implementing policies governments must respect individual rights and freedoms and assist the genuinely poor and defenceless in the community. How does the Hawke Government's record over the past five years stand against these two fundamental requirements for good government so far as they relate to the housing sector? The short answer is that the record is quite pathetic. Statistics from a range of independent government and non-government sources show starkly that something has gone dreadfully wrong in both the public and private housing sectors. The public housing waiting lists have increased from 110,000 to in the order of 160,000 during the period of this Government. The Government has crucified families seeking rental accommodation. Those families, as we all know, tend to be low income families. Rents have increased dramatically in all States. In the year to last July alone they soared by 23 per cent in my capital city, Melbourne; by 43 per cent in Sydney; by 36 per cent in Perth; and by 27 per cent in Brisbane.

As a share of family income, rents have also increased savagely under this Government. In June 1987, the average rent in Sydney took not less than 38.2 per cent of average weekly earnings. In Melbourne, where rents are lower, it still took more than 26 per cent of average weekly earnings. Figures from the Government's own principal housing advisory body, the Indicative Planning Council, show that last year housing starts were 30,000 below the predicted demand in 1986. This year the shortfall is expected to be 42,000. Because of rising house prices and record high interest rates, home owners are now paying up to 17 per cent more of their incomes in mortgage repayments than they were a decade ago. In Sydney, home buyers are now paying up to 45 per cent of their gross incomes on an average loan repayment. Ten years ago that figure was 28 per cent. In Melbourne, home buyers are now paying 36 per cent of their gross incomes on an average loan and in Adelaide it is 34 per cent.

The overall picture in the housing sector is one of turmoil and, for many Australians, despair. On both economic and social counts, Labor has failed dismally. Labor has also abrogated its economic responsibility on behalf of all Australians, but particularly those Australians seeking to buy homes or requiring rental accommodation. Last night we heard the announcement that a mini-Budget will be brought down in five months time, with no action to be taken in the intervening period. What was portrayed as a major decision by this Government came by Press release at a time when the Parliament was sitting-a complete abrogation of the fundamental role of Parliament in our society, our democracy.

There has been bungling of an economic nature from this Government for the last 4 1/2 years, and the confusion and the hiatus that will be caused in planning prospects in the housing sector and in other areas of the economy over the next five months while we wait to see what the mini-Budget holds will further add to the confusion and to the major problems confronting this economy-problems which this Government seems incapable of understanding and which have led to an overseas debt facing this nation of the order of $110 billion, a three-fold increase over the last four years and, in net terms, a four-fold increase.

We have seen interest rates soar, again having an enormous effect on the housing industry and on people's capacity to buy homes. Those soaring interest rates have been caused essentially by the big spending policies of this Government-a government which has seemingly been unable to keep its spending under control and which has been forced, therefore, to borrow a further $23 billion in the last four years, with high interest payments to match. It is the biggest single borrower in the market. The Government has crowded out, particularly in its initial period in government but the effect is still lingering, the borrowing market and has forced interest rates up to record levels.

Some time ago the Government abolished negative gearing on housing for rental purposes. We told the Government at the time what the impact of that would be on rental accommodation costs and availability because people would no longer invest in housing for investment and rental purposes in the way they had done in the past. We were exactly right. The Government has now been forced in the Budget to reverse that decision, which it should never have taken in the first instance.

I now turn briefly to the more social factors associated with the housing sector. I think it is very important to ask whether the Government has encouraged independence on the part of ordinary Australians. Is it really helping the genuinely poor and defenceless in our community to improve their situation so far as housing is concerned? The answer to both those fundamental threshold questions has to be a resounding no. As I have already pointed out, we have had a dramatic increase in public housing waiting lists to a record of some 160,000 applicants. In November 1987 we have a record number of over 64,000 applicants waiting for home purchase assistance under State programs. There has been a cut of $648m to the States for public housing and capital grants.

The Government says that its policies aim to promote fairness and equity but where is the fairness and equity in rising public housing waiting lists, an ever-increasing taxation burden for ordinary Australian families and higher and higher mortgage repayments? Housing has always occupied a unique place in the Australian way of life. Home ownership has traditionally been the goal of most Australians. Some may argue, in fact, that we have overdone the importance of home ownership. Nevertheless, that goal has been a fundamentally important expression within Australia of individuality, independence, privacy and a feeling of security.

In the early 1980s 72 per cent of Australians owned their own homes, one of the highest percentages in the world. Under Labor, home ownership has now dropped to about 69 per cent and is destined to fall lower. The Australian dream is rapidly becoming a nightmare for many Australians-an impossible nightmare at that. Labor's legislative program in the housing area provides no solution to the malaise in the housing sector. We have more and more of the same approach-tighter and tighter controls, increased interference and fewer funds available. We have more intervention in State housing policy matters and more duplication.

For example, the revised Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement mentioned in the legislation specifies that rental accommodation by the States shall not comprise less than 50 per cent of total Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funds and, as I have said, $700m will be spent over each of the next three years. The funds allocated to rental accommodation will not be less than 50 per cent of total Loan Council borrowing program moneys nominated for housing. The Commonwealth has encouraged the States to put more moneys from the proceeds of sales of public housing into rental accommodation. There is a lesser role for individual States to determine their own housing policies, yet the States are in a much better position to assess the housing needs of their own communities. The States-not the Federal Government-are in a more favourable position to determine how State housing dollars should be allocated.

The Opposition believes that the Government's approach is a recipe for increased levels of dependence on the Government as landlord. It provides no incentive for self-provision or home ownership. This is the sharp end of the Government's philosophy-a philosophy which results in undermining home ownership and fostering greater and greater reliance on the state. This Government's policies are so flawed that they encourage subservience to and reliance on the state. The Opposition believes that there should be provision for public housing for the genuinely poor, the weak and those who cannot otherwise provide their own shelter and accommodation. Our policies, when we were last in government, were designed to this effect, and they will be again when we regain government at the next election.

The Government claims that this legislation will assist the homeless by creating more public housing. Whilst that may be true in theory, although even that is doubtful, in the meantime the Government is creating an army of the new poor-those who would have been able to buy their own homes if interest rates were not so high, if taxation levels were lower, if they had greater job security and if they had been given encouragement and incentive. The Opposition believes that it is well past the time for the Government to face up to the malaise in the housing sector and to work towards rebuilding an environment conducive to growth, development and encouragement for increased home ownership-an environment which this Government has destroyed during its period in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that nothing exemplifies more the failure of economic policies which have been pursued by both this Government and the Opposition for a long period than the housing industry. I refer yet again to the policy of the pursuit of economic growth as the principal direction of government. It is a matter of fact that since 1948 there has been a 2 1/4-fold increase in the per capita gross national product. According to that measure, we are supposed to be 2 1/4 times richer-if either the Government or the Opposition are to be believed in terms of their economic objectives-than we were in 1948-49. Senator Short told us how much poorer we are as individuals in this community, how many more poor people we have who cannot afford even basic housing and how many more are becoming dependent on the state to provide housing for them.

SPEECH.PARA: If one were to look at an example of the failure of the growth system, one could do no better than to look at the increase in gross national product which does not represent an increase in real wealth for ordinary people. What we are measuring-Senator Short gave a good example of this-is the throughput, the using up of things, rather than the stock. If we are interested in housing, we are interested in the stock of housing which is available-the stock of houses which people can use-and the way in which that stock is divided among people. We are not really interested in the number of houses being built in a given year. It was largely irrelevant for Senator Short to say that there were 30,000 housing starts or 17,000 more or fewer housing starts. The importance to ordinary people is how many houses there are, how many people there are and how the stock is divided up.

As I have indicated before, we do not count our individual wealth by how quickly we use up our resources. If we own a house we do not measure how much it costs us in terms of much we have to take out of the bank or how many hours of leisure we have to give up to maintain it. But that is what the Government measures. When it takes economic measures, when it counts its gross national product, that is what it counts and that is what the Opposition would count also because it is pursuing essentially the same policies. We need an economic system which measures stock rather than throughput, an economic system which would be based on optimising that stock while minimising the throughput. In fact, we could have a fall in gross national product and people could well be better off.

Having said that, I turn specifically to this piece of legislation. As already indicated, the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 alters the Minister's authority to reallocate housing grants between the States. The Australian Democrats recognise the desirability of the Commonwealth being able to enforce compliance by the States with its guidelines for grants. The case cited by the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) of ensuring appropriate consultation takes place in respect of Aboriginal housing developments is an important example. However, the Commonwealth must also recognise the differences which exist between the States and their needs. I hope the Minister can therefore assure me that in the committee stage the amendment of section 11 of the Act will not stifle flexibility in responding to local housing needs. Federal priorities should not be taken so literally that the desires of the bureaucrats, removed from the impact of their decisions, prevail.

The Democrats are concerned that the amendment proposed by the Government to section 11 leaves open a loophole whereby the Government could avoid spending all of this allocation on housing assistance. The proposed sub-section 11 (1b) authorises the distribution of any money declared by the Minister to be available for reallocation but the proposal makes such redistribution by the Minister entirely optional. In other words, the Minister may seek not to provide funds to a particular State because that State is not conforming. Yet at the same time he might refuse to reallocate that money and simply resume it into Commonwealth revenue. In view of the statements being made about the decrease in the amount being spent on housing, we do not believe the Minister should have this option.

There is no legislative requirement that such funds be reallocated and, whilst this is apparently the intention of the legislation, the explanatory memorandum presented by the Minister states quite clearly that this legal position will allow `that they be retained by the Commonwealth'. The Democrats would like to see it made more explicit in this legislation that all of the $700m annually allocated to housing assistance will in fact be spent on housing assistance. As it is proposed, the Government legislation leaves the way open for the Federal Government's contribution to housing to be diminished through one State or several States defaulting on the conditions laid down by the Commonwealth. So we will be moving an amendment not to hamper the Commonwealth's power to indicate funding priorities and to encourage State compliance but to ensure that in this area of enormous need the community receives all the help that it can. There is, as indicated, still a large need, an unmet need, for housing in Australia, particularly in the public sector.

The well-publicised supplement to Australian Society, for example, claimed that amongst people renting privately 20 per cent live below the poverty line. Within this group are the 62 per cent of single parents in private rental who are pushed even further below the poverty line by their housing costs. So, with housing problems, poverty is also high amongst the elderly. An estimated 40,000 Australians are homeless and some 150,000 live permanently in caravan parks. The most poorly housed group in Australia is probably our Aboriginal population.

Only two months ago, through the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, this Government reduced general purpose capital grants to the States by $715m in this year. This will lead to an estimated fall in funds for States to spend on capital works such as housing of 56 per cent this year as compared with last year. In 1986-87 the Commonwealth made $584.7m available to the States to spend on public housing and this year it is expected to provide only $385.6m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations Children's Fund: Australian Parliamentary Association-Elimination of Intermediate-Range Nuclear Weapons

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am proud to announce the formation of the Australian Parliamentary Association for UNICEF-the United Nations Children's Fund. It is the first such group in the world and will hopefully be the start of many others. The Association has representatives from all parties in the Parliament and was launched last Tuesday, when UNICEF's Deputy Director, Dr Richard Jolly, gave members and senators a preview of the 1988 State of the World's Children report. The senior office bearers are myself as President; Mrs Kathy Sullivan, MP, is Deputy President; Senator David Brownhill, Secretary; and Senator Michael Macklin, Treasurer. The committee consists of Mrs Elaine Darling, MP; Mr John Langmore, MP; the Hon. Robert Katter, MP; and Senator Jo Vallentine. The patrons are Mr Hawke, Mr Howard, Mr Sinclair, and Senator Janine Haines.

SPEECH.PARA: The Association's charter states that it will; firstly, support and promote the Declaration of the Rights of the Child as adopted by the United Nations in 1959 and support the Adoption of a convention on the rights of the child; secondly, promote in the Parliament and throughout the Australian Government and the Australian community the work of UNICEF for children and their mothers; and thirdly, encourage Australia Governments to give priority support to children and their mothers in Australia's overseas development assistance program. Not only is this association a world first, as I have said, but it is a first for children in developing countries. The quiet carnage of a quarter of a million children dying each week from preventable causes is not a result of a shortage of food or medicine; it is because of the lack of political and social will to empower parents in developing countries with today's basic health knowledge. The role for industrialised countries, the report indicates, is to prevent the greatest burden of world recession from passing on to those who can least afford it: children and mothers in poor countries. Despite a tough economic climate, I am pleased to say that the Australian Government pledged $3.1m in October to UNICEF, an increase of 24 per cent over last year's contribution. In doing so, Australia has demonstrated support for what UNICEF terms a gathering `grand alliance for children'. Thelma O'Consolozarno, UNICEF representative for Australia and New Zealand, says:
This formal alliance of governments, health workers, religious leaders, teachers, community organisations and the media is arming parents with lifesaving knowledge about child health.

The Australian Government is committed to the alleviation of poverty and poor health amongst Australian children, and introduced the family package in the last Budget. The family package puts children first and aims to ensure a decent standard of living for the poorest people in our community. About 60 per cent of Government spending on family assistance now goes to the poorest 30 per cent of families. The Government's pledge is that, by 1990, Australian families will have access to the basic income required to ensure that their children need not live in poverty. As the State Of The World's Children Report highlights, UNICEF has been promoting lifesaving programs like immunisation and breastfeeding. These programs are saving about two million children this year, yet a quarter of a million children are still dying each week from preventable causes.

Let me conclude by drawing the Senate's attention to some dramatic facts from The State Of The World's Children Report. Immunisation coverage for children in the developing world has leapt from 5 to 50 per cent in the last 10 years, and is now saving the lives of 1.4 million children each year. For about the cost of 10 advanced fighter planes, UNICEF estimates a permanent immunisation system could be set up in the developing world. Because a number of senators wish to speak, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a Press summary of the state of the world's children in 1988, which I have shown to members of the Opposition.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Saving two million children

The promotion of immunization and ORT, in the 1980s, is now saving the lives of approximately 2 million children a year in the developing world. Similar low-cost methods could cut child deaths and child malnutrition by approximately half over the next few years, says UNICEF's State of the World's Children report for 1988.

Immunization is the success story of this decade. Ten years ago, less than 5% of the developing world's infants were vaccinated against diseases which were killing 4.5 million children a year. This year, immunization has reached 50% for DPT vaccine and 40% for measles, and is now saving over 1.3 million lives annually.

The UN target of immunizing all children by 1990-considered unrealistic in the early 1980s-is now within reach. On present trends, over 70% of the developing world's children will be immunized against the main vaccine-preventable diseases by 1990.

Citing the example of several countries which have doubled immunization coverage in the last two years-including some of the world's poorest nations-the report argues that, despite the difficult economic climate, there is now no nation which cannot now meet the 1990 target-if the will is there.

The cost of a permanent and universal immunization system for the developing world is estimated by UNICEF to be about $500 million a year-about the same as ten advanced fighter planes. Such a system will also be essential, argues the report, when vaccines are developed against malaria and AIDS.
Oral rehydration

The greatest killer of the world's children-with 3 million young victims a year-is still the dehydration, caused by diarrhoeal disease. Yet dehydration, says UNICEF, ``can now be prevented by a technique which is so simple that any parent can use it, so cheap that any parent can afford it, so effective that it is rapidly becoming the treatment of choice in the most advanced hospitals of the Western world.''

That technique is known as oral rehydration therapy or ORT-and it has been available since the early 1970s. But only in the mid-1980s has the attempt been made to promote the solution on a scale commensurate with the problem. Today, approximately 20% of the developing world's parents are using ORT and the therapy is estimated to be saving more than 600,000 young lives each year. ``It is not nearly enough,'' says UNICEF, ``progress is far too slow. Three million children should not still be dying each year from dehydration.''

Together with other low-cost child protection methods-such as breast-feeding, better weaning, and spacing births at least two year apart-ORT and immunization could save the lives of up to 7 million children a year and protect the normal physical and mental growth of many millions more. ``And if we cannot mobilize the will to put these most basic and low-cost elements of child protection into action,'' says UNICEF, ``then what chance do we realistically have of making significant progress against other, often more difficult, problems which face the world's children?''
A grand alliance

The 1988 report proposes that the greatest opportunity for improving the `state of the worlds' children' lies in informing and supporting all today's parents in applying what is already known about these basic and inexpensive methods of child protection.

To achieve this, the report calls for a `Grand Alliance' of all possible resources-teachers and religious leaders, mass media and government agencies, voluntary organizations and people's movements, business leaders and labour unions, women's groups and health services-to create an informed public demand for, and practical knowledge of, the methods which could now bring about ``a revolution in child survival and development.''

The report cites several examples of this alliance in action. In Turkey, 200,000 school-teachers and 54,000 imams have helped to treble the nation's immunization coverage. In Syria and Egypt, television has succeeded in getting the immunization message into every home. In Bangladesh, a voluntary organization has visited 9 million homes to carry the news of ORT. In Colombia, parish priests are using pre-marital and pre-baptism counselling sessions to advise parents on the importance of breast-feeding, immunization, and growth monitoring. Also in Colombia, 700,000 high school students are being trained to do community service in putting today's child health methods at the disposal of the nation's parents.
Deaths and births

In proposing this alliance of all possible organized resources, the 1988 UNICEF report argues that ``there is no greater cause in which to march.'' In the world as a whole, one death in three is the death of a child under the age of five. Each week that goes by, more than a quarter of a million young children are dying in the ``quiet carnage'' of malnutrition and infection. Many of the survivors, says UNICEF, ``live on with ill health and poor growth, unable today to develop to their full mental and physical potential, unable tomorrow to fully contribute to the families they will have or the communities in which they will live.''

Tackling the fundamental problems of child deaths and malnutrition will therefore remain the priority task for the rest of this century-``not just because of the sheer scale and severity of the problem, but because of the emergence of dramatic new possibilities for its solution.''

Will the saving of so many children's lives exacerbate the problem of population growth? Paradoxically, says UNICEF, the answer is no: ``When parents become more confident that their children will survive, they tend to have smaller families. That is one reason why there has never been a steep and sustained fall in child births which has not been preceded by a steep and sustained fall in child deaths.

TALK.START.PARA: —In conclusion, can I say that the work of UNICEF is vital, and we as parliamentarians can add our support to this new and important association by joining, paying the $5 membership fee, and actively participating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity during this adjournment debate to make a few points on the agreement that was signed yesterday by the super-powers to abolish intermediate-range nuclear force weapons, and give some advice to the Australian Government as to how Australia might react to this changing security environment. I would have preferred to have made these remarks at the more appropriate time of lunch time today, but because of the re-arranging of the business that opportunity was not presented. For those who believe that the world would be a safer place with a mutual and verifiable reduction of the nuclear arsenal of the super-powers, yesterday was obviously an historic day because it was the time of the signing of the first treaty to actually reduce the number of nuclear weapons. It might be said that it is modest in terms of the total number of nuclear weapons that are to be abolished-only 4 per cent of an estimated total of some 50,000 warheads would be dismantled-but nevertheless it is very significant in other ways. It is significant in its symbolism and as a step towards greater reductions particularly in the more critical long-range strategic weapons, and in the decoupling of Europe, to some extent, from the nuclear umbrella.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the agreement raises other challenges that must now be addressed such as how to maintain an adequate deterrent as the debate continues about the adequacy of conventional forces, particularly in Europe, and about the whole subject of the legitimacy of strategic defence in this process. I shall deal briefly with both of these matters in a moment. Nevertheless, it must be said that the agreement is a step towards a more civilised world. Any step taken away from a reliance on mutually assured destruction as the method of protecting civilisation from nuclear catastrophe must be regarded as a step in the right direction.

Therefore, I would say that this is an event worthy of modest celebration by the many millions of people throughout the world who have, through demonstration, said to the super-power leaders, `You must work towards another way to protect us'. I guess that that was the overriding sentiment that someone such as myself felt when, a little over a year ago, I was in Hiroshima and stood in the museum and in the peace park and sensed the absolute destruction and devastation that occurred as a result of the weapon used then, a weapon which, by today's standards, was little more than a toy.

There are obviously lots of reasons why this agreement has been signed, such as, naturally, the desire of presidents to leave an historic legacy and the difficulty of the Soviets economically keeping in the race at the same time as allowing Mr Gorbachev to implement the changes necessary to ensure his legacy. However, I argue that one should not underestimate the influence of mass opinion on the occurrence of yesterday, or the enormous amount of work done over the years in disarmament forums, in the various peace research institutes throughout the world and in other such bodies in moving super-power leaders to the state of confidence that they apparently reached to take this important step.

It is significant also, I would argue, because although the verification procedures in the agreement are complex, they are not foolproof. Therefore, by accepting the agreement, the super-powers have indicated that they are, for perhaps the first time, prepared to accept some good faith on the part of each other. I would not want to rely on the goodwill, particularly of the Soviets, whilst they remain a closed society, having the experience of Afghanistan, the support of Vietnam's occupation of Kampuchea, et cetera. Nevertheless, we all know that so many disarmament conferences in the past have ended with statements to the effect that more could have been achieved but for the very poor relations and deep distrust that existed between the super-powers. So I argue that it is significant that on this occasion such a sentiment did not end a treaty process. One must, therefore, recognise signs of improved understanding which can reduce tension and allow progress towards a more secure and just world. I believe that this change of attitude is just as significant as the actual reduction of the weapons pursuant to the agreement.

In referring to this agreement, I believe that credit should be given to a number of national leaders. President Reagan recognised that successful negotiations with the Soviets would come about only through being able to negotiate from a position of strength. If Pershing IIs and cruise missiles had not been deployed in Europe, the SS20s would not now be going to be removed. I also give credit to Mr Gorbachev, who has shown the enlightenment to realise that his people deserve more than just a strong defence and is therefore prepared to divert resources that his predecessors were not prepared to divert. I commend Mr Gorbachev also for his preparedness to accept exclusion from the agreement of the British and French nuclear forces. Of course, if he had not been prepared to accept that exclusion, it would not have been easy for him in his domestic situation and the treaty would never have been finalised. I give credit to Mr Gorbachev finally for the fact that he was prepared to agree to remove the Asian-based intermediate-range nuclear forces although the United States of America was only to dismantle weapons in Europe. That in a small way, I suggest, brings the sentiment of the reduced tensions evident in this agreement to our part of the world.

Credit also should be given to European leaders, particularly Chancellor Kohl, for the courage they have shown. Arguably, it is the Europeans who have allowed themselves to become more vulnerable as a result of this agreement. One remembers that the Pershing IIs and cruise missiles went into Europe as a result of European fear that the US might stand aside from a Soviet-European nuclear conflict. Therefore, in this agreement, there is evidence on the part of the Europeans of greater confidence in the alliance at lower threshold levels and evidence of their recognition of an improved climate between the super-powers, both of which is pleasing.

I said that this agreement should be looked at as a step towards the challenge of the removal of further weapons. Four per cent of 50,000 has been removed by this agreement. Some 48,000 will remain, including the largest, most lethal and, arguably, the most strategically destabilising weapons because of their accuracy and because of their potential first strike capacity. Unfortunately, in the area of the largest weapons, the arms race has continued unabated. The United States has deployed the MX missile and will be deploying the particularly accurate Trident II submarine-launched ballistic missiles. The Soviets also have new ICBMs either deployed or near deployment. Now, both super-powers seem to be of a mind to progress towards a treaty to reduce these weapons, and this we should encourage. This reduction process will be more difficult particularly because of the asymmetrical nature of each super-power's strategic force structure. But with concessions and good will, it is possible-but they will be necessary on both sides. However, with them, a formula can be worked out for that reduction which will nevertheless preserve the strategic relationship of essential equivalents.

However, a key to this achievement will be verification. Verification of removal of these weapons will be more difficult. That brings in the responsibility of Australia, which I would argue has a continuing responsibility towards verification through the joint communication facilities, and I remind the Government of that fact. In a very modest way through those bases, and through the more positive signs of ship visits and the other ways in which we contribute to the alliance, the strength of the alliance will be maintained. We must be aware that, as gross numbers of weapons are reduced, strength and resolve in other ways becomes more important.

I said that strategic defence initiatives are irrevocably intertwined in the debate. A sentiment impossible to resist by a nation that has the capacity to build a defence to nuclear weapons is that it should not move down that path of relying solely on a deterrent. Therefore, it is not surprising that both super-powers are moving in that direction. However, at the same time, I remind the Senate that each will be developing weapons to defeat the other's defence, and so the arms race escalates yet again into a new field. The fear of either party that defence can become a shield from which a first strike might one day be launched can in fact turn what is a morally commendable approach to super-power defence into what could become a catastrophe. The better alternative is the continued reduction of weapons because, with fewer weapons, the less the need for a shield. With restraint on development of such a shield, it appears that the super-powers--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about some restraint in speech-making?

—That is a strange comment to come from Senator Evans. Perhaps we can calculate how much time he has taken this session. With restraint on deployment which, as I have indicated, looks as though it is possible by the super-powers, the better alternative is that numbers will be reduced to an extent that the super-powers will have confidence not to need to put the shield into effect. If that is not possible, the better alternative is that the shield would be implemented when the super-powers have greater confidence in each other and at a lower threshold level.

SPEECH.PARA: The intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty adds a new dimension to the conventional force reduction talks which have been taking place in Vienna since 1973. There has been little progress in these talks because of disagreements over the existing balance of forces against which any reductions could be measured and over whether armaments and equipment in the mutual and balanced force reductions zone should be reduced as well as personnel. However, because the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) doctrine of flexible response will be be available to the same extent now that INF weapons are to be abolished, that is, in their capacity to have a nuclear response to a massive conventional attack by Warsaw forces, there is an even more urgent need to address the overwhelming superiority which exists on the part of the bloc in conventional weaponry and its invasion capacity. As I have indicated, that now requires to be urgently addressed.

The lesson of the INF treaty is that, to negotiate with the Soviets, one must negotiate from strength. Therefore, as the INF treaty is implemented, NATO must respond with increased and updated conventional forces. The deterrent must be built this time at a conventional level. Regrettably, that is more expensive. It would be more desirable if the Soviets were prepared to downgrade their conventional force. That is the most desirable direction in which the West should be pushing. We should be supporting that move in our own way. As time goes on, and the less we are protected under a nuclear umbrella, Australia must realise that it will be equally responsible for playing a part in the upgrading of our conventional forces and that costs will have to be borne. One remaining inducement for the Soviets to look seriously at a conventional downgrading is the independent nuclear forces of Britain and France, because there is little prospect of bringing these forces into an agreement for reduction and ultimate abolition whilst the Eastern bloc maintains such superior conventional forces.

As to chemical and biological weapons, I hope that the success in reaching an INF agreement will act as an impetus for further progress in restraining the chemical weapons race. Extensive multilateral and bilateral talks have been taking place and much progress has been made; nevertheless, very difficult questions of verification remain to be settled. Australia should continue to use its good offices and its resources in assisting the super-powers particularly in finding a resolution to the problems of verification in this areas, as they have been able to do in relation to chemical weapons, the safer will be the world community.

I say in conclusion-as Senator Evans will be pleased to hear-that the treaty is to be welcomed. The super-powers should be encouraged and supported in extending it into the area of long range strategic nuclear weapons. The nuclear powers should, as a further step, be encouraged towards a comprehensive test ban treaty as a further limiting influence. In a period of wind-down of nuclear weapons, deterrence must be retained and the Western alliance must remain strong both in its military capacity and in its resolve, and Australia must continue to play its fair part in that role. In the environment of vertical reduction, more pressure must be put on nuclear threshold states not to go down the nuclear weapon path. In other words, we must now use this influence to restrain further horizontal proliferation and we must also use influence as an impetus for progress in other negotiations for reduction of weapons such as chemical weapons.

—Senator Wood, there is no point of order. I have a list provided to me by the Whips for the adjournment debate. Senator Teague was on it. He stood, and you stood at the same time. You will certainly get your opportunity on the adjournment tonight. I called Senator Teague first because I saw him first.

INTERJECT.PARA: A quorum not being present and the bells being rung-

—Senator Vallentine came in and left.

—Both Senator Jones and Senator Vallentine came in and left. Senator Jones came in and left during the ringing of the quorum bells. Mr President, I really do object to people coming in during the forming of a quorum and then leaving. That is a breach of Standing Orders to which I drew your attention yesterday. —Order! A quorum is not present. I ask all senators to resume their seats while we have a count. I ask the attendants to close the doors. A quorum is not present. We will now record the names of those senators who are present.

—Mr President, I ask what you propose to do about the situation of senators who come in in the course of the forming of a quorum and then leave in defiance of the Standing Orders. If we are not to get proper compliance with the Standing Orders on a matter such as this, then I think the Chair has to take some steps to ensure that the Standing Orders are properly enforced and that honourable senators do not come in here in the course of the forming of a quorum and then, in defiance of the Standing Orders, leave the chamber.

However, I am not saying that that did not occur. PROCTEXT.PARA: The following papers were tabled:
Meat Inspection Act-Meat Inspection (Orders) Regulations-Orders 1987 No. 6-Meat Inspection (Northern Territory) (Amendment).
National Health Act-Declaration made by the delegate of the Minister under section 85, dated 1 December 1987.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 24 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Health Insurance (Variation of Fees and Medical Services) (No. 47) Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1987 No. 160 and made under the Health Insurance Act 1973, which came into operation on 1 August 1987, delete from the earlier fee schedule items 3330 and 3346 dealing with the treatment of keratoses, warts and similar lesions.

(2) Will the Minister for Community Services and Health reinstate these items to the schedule, in view of the potential malignancy of a number of keratotic lesions if untreated and the small amount of fees involved.
(3) Will the Minister give an undertaking that he will announce this modification before 8 October 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) In recognition of representations pointing out problems that could be encountered as a result of the deletion of Schedule items 3330 and 3346, officers of my Department have met with representatives of the medical profession including surgeons, dermatologists, obstetricians and gynaecologists.
In the opinion of my Department, there is a special case for removal of anal and genital warts to be covered in the Schedule as they usually require hospital admission and removal under anaesthetic.
Action is proceeding to have items specifically for removal of anal and genital warts introduced into the Medicare Benefits Schedule.

It is recognised that some keratoses may be precursors to skin cancer; nevertheless, the techniques for removal of these skin blemishes are similar to those for warts and are considered to be reasonably covered under the appropriate consultation item.
Items covering the removal of skin cancer and treatment of melanoma have not been deleted from the Schedule, and the Government recognises the need for separate procedures for those services.
The Government does not intend to reinstate the general procedural items for removal of warts, keratoses and lesions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 4 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Would the Minister for Community Services and Health explain how the Federal and State Governments intend to pressure the alcohol industry into adopting a more ``socially responsible'' position (refer Answer to Question on Notice No. 48, Senate Hansard, 27 October 1987, p. 1345).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In the answer to Question on Notice No. 48, Senator Ryan spoke of pressing-rather than pressuring-the liquor industry to adopt a more socially responsible stand on alcohol advertising. This approach is in accord with the Government's philosophy of achieving agreement, wherever possible, through negotiation and consensus.

It is against a background of concern about alcohol-related problems expressed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Health Ministers on the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy (MCDS) that initiatives such as the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers' Association's nationwide campaign ``Enjoy Wine in Moderation'', ``Enjoy Wine Coolers in Moderation'' and Carlton and United Breweries' ``Think Before You Drink'' campaigns have emerged.

These socially responsible actions by sections of the liquor industry come at a time when the Government is emphasising the need for community education on alcohol consumption-a matter referred to in answer to part (2) of Question No. 48.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1987 (Hansard, page 1116), Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me, as Minister assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question refers to the serious effects which the Federal Government's Medicare arrangements are having on staffing levels in Queensland hospitals. Is it a fact that, under the Medicare agreement, Queensland receives $82.86 per capita whilst the average of the other States of Australia is $198.80? Is it a fact that the South Australian Government receives $257.46, which is more than three times the amount per capita than is received in Queensland? Is the Minister aware that, if the identified health grants are added to that, the total amount received by New South Wales from the Commonwealth is $1,039m whilst the Queensland figure is a mere $205m? Does the Minister not agree that these are serious discrepancies and is she in a position to explain why they have occurred?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On a number of occasions, Queensland opposition spokespeople have raised the perceived inequitable distribution of Medicare and identified health grants payments to Queensland compared with other States. In doing so they conveniently forget how those grants were derived and the overall Commonwealth/State financial arrangements which are negotiated at Premiers' Conferences.

I refer the honourable senator to the 1985 Premiers' Conference where a number of issues relevant to her question were raised. Firstly, the senator may recall that when Medicare was introduced, the Commonwealth requested the Grants Commission, in its review of tax sharing relativities, to specifically identify whether the introduction of Medicare had disturbed the health relativities existing prior to Medicare. The Grants Commission reported that health relationships had been disturbed and an amount of $10m was identified as necessary to restore the relativities for the two years 1983-84 and 1984-85. The Commonwealth accepted the Grants Commission report in this regard and the $10m was paid to Queensland in 1985-86.

At the Premiers' Conference, it was also agreed that the identified health grants would continue as separate payments for the 1985-86-1987-88 triennium. However, in the context of overall Commonwealth/State financial arrangements, adjustments and offsets were made to the general financial assistance grants in lieu of the identified health grants. In other words, the identified health grants would be health grants in name only. This means that when comparing identified health grant payments between States, general financial assistance grants must also be taken into account.
It is therefore not realistic to compare one or two specific grant arrangements, without also including the other untied grants made to States.

Listed below is a comparison of per capita distribution of Medicare, identified health grants and general financial assistance grants to States for 1986-87 which truly reflect those Commonwealth payments which States have available to them for allocation to health. The honourable senator will note that Queensland receives significantly more per capita funding than New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian average.
